PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 10.00 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Mifepristone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned showeth:

(1) That the trials of the abortifacient drug Mifepristone (RU486) are against the public interest in that they use women as guinea pigs for trials of a drug which causes death to the unborn future citizens and adds undue risk to the health of women.
(2) That when RU486 is used with a prostaglandin it exposes women to a disproportionate risk of pain, bleeding and more serious complications.
(3) That when RU486 is used as a `morning after pill' its effect is abortifacient in that it stops implantation of a human embryo, a future citizen, in the womb.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will legislate to ban the importation and use of RU486 in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Olympic Games Merchandise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Urges the Federal Government to bring down legislation that all merchandise bearing the Sydney Olympics 2000 insignia shall be made in Australia from material made in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned urges the Government to press for a total ban internationally on the production, stockpiling, trade and use of anti-personnel devices;
Your petitioners ask that the Senate urge the Government to provide financial aid for the de-mining of countries such as Cambodia.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia asks that the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993 be amended with the application of common principles. To ensure that all parents with dependent children are treated equally, allowing maximum freedom of choice in child rearing.
These Acts need to be amended to take account of:

PETITION.PARA: 1.the fact that 60% of married women in the workforce who have children, would prefer to stay at home and mind their children, but for economic reasons can't afford to (Institute of Family Studies Survey).
2.the failure to provide for equitable choice for women and families in allowing parents the maximum right to choose the most appropriate form of care for their children.
3.that there be recognition of a parent at home as a formal occupation reflecting its economic value and worth to society.
4.the need for equal payment of any subsidies and allowances for the care of children, paid directly to the parent.
5.the recognition that a family with more than one child incurs extra expenses.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate amend the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Recycled Paper
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition undersigned shows:

That we, the citizens of Western Australia believe that the firm policy of support for the principles of recycling of paper as contained in the successive Statements on the Environment by Prime Ministers Hawke and Keating has not been followed up by policies of support for recycled versus non-recycled paper products.

The expiry of supportive transitional arrangements equating to a concessional sales tax rate of 10.5% without a promised review on the continuation of such arrangements leaves the fledgling recycled paper products industry in Western Australia on the same sales tax rate as non-recycled paper products 21%.

The strong commitment by the West Australian community at all levels to recycling will be placed in jeopardy if participants in the industry are forced for commercial reasons to transfer their activity away from recycled to non-recycled paper manufacture.

We believe it is essential that the government, community and industry work together to "close the loop" between the community's efforts to collect recyclable materials and industry efforts to use 100% recycled materials to create value added consumer products. With 600,000 tonnes of office waste paper currently going to landfill in Australia, at a minimum cost to the community of $15 million, we need to redouble our efforts in this area, NOT WITHDRAW SUPPORT.

This emerging recycling industry has come a long way in its first five years—the West Australian community has stopped more than 30,000 tonnes of office waste paper over this period going into landfill by recycling it into tissue products. Over $6 million has been passed back into the community through payments for the office waste paper. Industry has now invested more than $10 million in technology, R&D and infrastructure—Now is not the time for the Federal Government to withdraw support.

Our petition therefore asks the Senate not to impose a 21% wholesale tax on 100% recycled tissue paper products but support the recycling industry by applying the "virtuous products" tax of 11% or giving an equivalent level of support for 5 years.
I certify that this Petition is in conformity with the Standing Orders of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Interpreting Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Italian residents in the Wide Bay Area, and precisely in the cities of Bundaberg, Maryborough and Hervey Bay, in the last two (2) years had benefited from the interpreting services of Gabriela Corridore for the Australian-Italian pensions, for the Department of Social Security in favour of Italian origin residents.

Suddenly, as from August 1994, this service has been changed and this has caused serious problems for the local Italian community, already isolated due to the lack of Radio and Television information in ethnic language.
The elderly Italian represent the majority of the Wide Bay community and many of them cannot undertake a 400 km trip to Brisbane to gain such information.

This disservice will probably cause a damage for the Italian residents and the Australian society because, from March 1994, the Department of Social Security is requiring that all Italians should apply for the overseas pension.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia asks that this service be re-established.

DEBATE.TITLE: CORPORATIONS LAW (SECURITIES AND FUTURES) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Crowley, on behalf of Senator Faulkner) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the corporations law.
Motion (by Senator Crowley) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the bill and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to facilitate the trading of new and innovative products on Australian securities and futures exchanges. It will permit the trading of new products on a more flexible basis than is presently possible under the Corporations Law.

The substance of these amendments was originally included in the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 24 March 1994. Those amendments were intended to facilitate the trading of a new product by the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) from 1 July 1994. The amendments were withdrawn from that bill to allow for further public comment on the proposals and to permit exposure of draft regulations and business rules in support of the amendments.

An exposure package of documents was released on 5 September 1994 for public comment by interested parties. The exposure package included the draft bill and regulations, draft explanatory memoranda and a summary of the share ratio business rules prepared by the ASX. Overall, there has been a favourable response to the proposals. In particular, the Australian Securities Commission, the Securities Institute of Australia and the International Banks and Securities Association support the proposals.

It is Government policy to assist the Australian securities and futures industries to grow and develop. These industries play an integral and important role in Australia's financial markets. They are vital to Australia's future as a mature and stable economy. Through these industries Australia can develop as an important financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region. The ASX and the Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) hold key positions in these industries.

Since the commencement of the national scheme for corporate regulation on 1 January 1991 the Government has endeavoured to facilitate competition in, and promote the international competitiveness of, Australia's securities and futures markets. Through legislative change and the administration of the law by the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) our markets have been encouraged, not stifled, by regulation.

Amongst other initiatives the Government has facilitated the introduction of an electronic clearing facility to enable the ASX to meet best international practice standards in the clearance and settlement of share transactions. Legislation has been enacted to facilitate the establishment of retail screen based trading markets for collective investment schemes. This will provide a new market for investors to trade units in collective investment schemes. The Government has also approved the New Zealand Futures & Options Exchange, a subsidiary of the SFE, trading its products on a screen based system in Australia. It is important to appreciate that the general policy thrust of this bill is a continuation of this policy of encouraging competition in the financial markets.

The Government recognises that the future success of the exchanges depends in part on their capacity to develop and market innovative new products in response to changing financial needs and circumstances. Both the ASX and the SFE have shown that they have the capacity to develop such products. It is important that this activity not be frustrated by regulatory structures which inhibit product development or encourage business to go elsewhere.

Under the Corporations Law trading in futures contracts and securities is separately regulated. Generally speaking, under the current law futures contracts are only able to be traded on a futures exchange while securities are ordinarily traded on a stock exchange. Strict penalties apply if securities or futures contracts are traded in breach of the Law.

The present rigid definitions of `securities' and `futures contracts' in the Corporations Law can operate to prevent the trading of new products on a particular exchange, in circumstances where there may be valid reasons why they should be able to be traded on that exchange.

Those definitions were developed some time ago. There has been significant growth in derivatives markets and development of new financial instruments and products since that time. These developments were not contemplated when the basic legislation was first formulated. For some of these products, the existing regulatory provisions are not the most appropriate.
The Government has therefore decided to amend the Corporations Law to introduce greater flexibility into the definitions of `securities' and `futures contracts' in the Corporations Law.
The catalyst for the introduction of these reforms at this time is the new product, termed a share ratio contract, recently developed by the ASX.
A share ratio contract is a derivative financial instrument. It combines the features of a security and a futures contract.

The ASX is presently precluded from trading this product on its securities exchange because a share ratio contract does not fall within the existing definition of securities. However, there is a close relationship between a share ratio contract and securities which are already traded by stock brokers on the ASX. Share ratio contracts require a knowledge of the performance of individual shares. Stock brokers will be equipped to provide advice about such contracts. They will be required to demonstrate that they have relevant experience and education and have completed a training program conducted by the ASX in relation to advising and dealing in share ratio contracts. All share ratio trading will be supervised by a senior representative of ASX member organisations. In light of these arrangements the Government is of the view, therefore, that in this particular case and, in the context of the regulatory arrangements being developed, it is reasonable for share ratio contracts to be traded on a securities exchange.

To this end the bill will permit the regulations to prescribe particular exchange-traded agreements and to regulate such agreements as if they were securities or futures contracts. The first such agreements to be prescribed, share ratio contracts, will be prescribed and regulated as if they were securities, enabling the ASX to trade its new product on its securities exchange.

The bill will also permit the prescription of other products in the future, thus ensuring a quick legislative response to developments in derivatives markets and the emergence of new products by enabling those products to be approved for trading on stock exchanges or futures exchanges.

The power to prescribe products will be used sparingly. Nor will these amendments have any application to mainstream products which fail to be regulated under the respective regimes already in place. These will continue to be governed by the existing regulatory regime prescribed in the Corporations Law for securities and futures contracts.

However, to ensure that appropriate regulatory standards apply to share ratio contracts and other products that may be prescribed, the bill provides that regulations may modify the application of the Corporations Law to such products.

This will enable the regulations to selectively apply the most appropriate provisions of the Corporations Law to the products to ensure that a suitable regulatory regime is in place for their trading and that investors are adequately protected.

The exposure package for this bill illustrates how this is to be achieved. The draft regulations in that package prescribe share ratio contracts for the purposes of the Corporations Law, and modify the provisions of the Law as they apply to such contracts. The essential features of a regulatory scheme for the trading of share ratio products will include: the licensing of dealers, the conduct of dealers' businesses, dealers' accounts and audit, the handling of client moneys, fraud and market manipulation and fidelity fund arrangements.

The National Guarantee Fund (NGF) will guarantee share ratio contracts traded on the ASX. I am advised by the ASC that an independent actuarial study has confirmed that the resources of the NGF are sufficient to meet any reasonable foreseeable claims arising from trading in share ratio contracts. The ASC has stated that the report confirms that any potential losses from the trading of share ratio contracts would not undermine the financial resources of the Fund. In addition, those provisions of the Corporations Law dealing with investor protection and the maintenance of fair, competitive and orderly futures markets will be part of the regime applying to share ratio contracts.

Other rules governing the trading of share ratio contracts will be set out in the business rules of the ASX. Those rules have been comprehensively reviewed by the ASC in order to ensure that the standards applicable to the trading of risk management products are adhered to. Those rules are subject to disallowance by the Attorney-General.

I reiterate the comments I made during the course of the debate on the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, that the Government does not intend to regulate over-the-counter derivatives markets under these amendments. The power to prescribe agreements, contained in this bill, is limited to agreements traded on an exchange. This bill has nothing to say about the regulation of over-the-counter derivatives markets.

The Companies and Securities Advisory Committee is presently undertaking a review of the regulation of derivatives. It is expected that this review will also address the policy issue of the trading of derivatives on securities and futures exchanges. However, this review process will take some time to complete. Any amendments to the Law arising from it may be some time away.
This bill will assist the development and trading of new derivative products in the interim.

Financial markets and the needs of their users are evolving in ways that were not envisaged during the 1980s. New and innovative products continue to be developed and traded by derivatives markets. Provided adequate safeguards are in place to ensure the protection of investors and the integrity of financial markets, the Government must be able to respond to requests by exchanges to trade new products.

As I have noted, the Government has encouraged our securities and futures markets to compete in global markets. It has sought to facilitate the exchanges by modifying the Law to make the regulatory framework responsive, flexible and adaptable while, at the same time, not reducing investor protection.

The share ratio product has been welcomed by local institutional investors and it is anticipated that it will gain acceptance in overseas markets, thus considerably enhancing the international reputation of Australia's securities markets. This bill provides a mechanism for facilitating the development, not only of this particular product, but other new financial products in the future.
The bill is not expected to have any significant financial impact on Government or business.

In accordance with the Heads of Agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation the Ministerial Council on Corporations has been consulted on the bill.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the bills and move:

PARA.TAB: That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes measures which give effect to certain announcements in the 1994-95 Budget and the Working Nation White Paper of 4 May 1994.

The bill will give effect to the 1994-95 Budget announcement by the Treasurer on 10 May 1994 that employee share benefits provided by an employer to an employee in respect of employment will be subject to fringe benefits tax (FBT). Transitional arrangements will apply so that in certain circumstances the existing provisions of the income tax law will continue to apply to shares or rights to shares acquired after 10 May 1994.

The Government is making these changes to reduce the exploitation of the existing legislation and to ensure that the tax concessions that are available under the new arrangements are directed at share schemes which encourage employees to own shares in the company by which they are employed or a holding company of their employer.

The measures will significantly increase the taxation benefits available under schemes which encourage investment by employees in their employer company and which are available to all permanent employees on a fair and equitable basis.

The bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 (FBTAA) so that FBT will be imposed on employee share fringe benefits which arise when an employee (or associate) acquires shares or rights to shares for an amount less than the market value. The amount subject to FBT will be reduced by any amount paid by the employee or associate.

Two concessions are available which can further reduce the taxable value of the benefit where certain criteria are satisfied. These concessions are referred to as the `exemption concession' and the `deferral concession'.

The `exemption concession' is available where there are restrictions on the sale or disposal of the shares or rights and the restrictions exceed a five year holding period. Where this concession is used the taxable value of the benefit can be reduced by up to $500.

The `deferral concession' is available where there are restrictions on the sale or disposal of the shares or rights and the restrictions exceed a five year holding period but do not extend beyond 10 years. Where this concession is used the taxable value of the benefit can be reduced by up to $1500. An amount will be included in the employee's assessable income in the year in which the restrictions on the shares or rights cease.
The proposed amendments will allow an employer to claim an income tax deduction for the amount of the exemption or deferral concession.
The bill will also amend the capital gains provisions to ensure that the advantage gained by the concessions will not be `clawed-back' through those provisions.
The nature of these measures is such that a reliable estimate of the revenue impact cannot be provided.
The bill will amend the research and development tax concessions to give effect to the changes announced in the Working Nation White Paper.

The first change is that the shading-in rules which currently apply where a company's research and development expenditure is between $20,000 and $50,000 will be eliminated. The full 150 per cent deduction will be allowable for the 1994-95 and later years of income where the total research and development expenditure is more than $20,000.

The second change will extend the concession to expenditure incurred on certain research and development activities undertaken outside Australia. Expenditure incurred on research and development activities conducted outside Australia must be given prior approval by the Industry Research and Development Board. The Industry Research and Development Act 1986 will be amended to give the Board power to develop public guidelines specifying the criteria that companies must satisfy for their activities to be approved by the Board. Some of those criteria are to be set by these amendments.

The third change will amend the Industry Research and Development Act to reduce the expenditure threshold from $1 million to $500,000 for companies registering jointly on or after 1 July 1994 in respect of a proposed research and development project starting on or after that date. This change will facilitate the use of syndicate structures for smaller research and development projects which is expected to benefit small-to-medium-sized companies.

The reduced expenditure threshold is estimated to cost the revenue $2 million per annum from 1995-96. The tax deductibility of expenditure on overseas R&D activities cannot be quantified, but it is expected to have some cost to revenue. The reduced expenditure threshold for syndicates is estimated to cost the revenue $4 million per annum from 1995-96.

In the Working Nation White Paper the Government announced that the rate of tax on income derived by a pooled development fund (PDF) from its investments in small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) would be reduced from 25 per cent to 15 per cent. This change, which is designed to increase the attractiveness of the PDF program to investors, will apply to the assessments of PDFs for the 1994-95 and later years of income.

The bill will divide the taxable income of a PDF into two components—income from investing in small and medium enterprises will be taxed at 15 per cent, and income from other sources will be taxed at 25 per cent.
Simple rules will allocate the allowable deductions and capital gains and capital losses of a PDF between the two components of taxable income.
The measure is estimated to cost the revenue nil in 1994-95, $3 million in 1995-96, $4 million in 1996-97 and $4 million in 1997-98.
The bill contains amendments to give effect to some changes relating to superannuation.

These changes include clarifying the existing treatment of overseas superannuation funds and payments related to them. They will also ensure tax concessions for superannuation contributions and benefits are limited to retirement benefits which accumulate in superannuation funds that comply with Australian regulations and that Australian tax concessions are not diverted to non-residents.

The amendments will recoup tax concessions given to superannuation funds that change their status from complying to non-complying and impose tax on funds which change their status from non-resident to resident.
The Income Tax (Former Complying Superannuation Funds) Bill 1994 and the Income Tax (Former Non-Resident Superannuation Funds) Bill 1994 impose these taxes.
The bill will also subject to fringe benefits tax employer contributions paid to a non-complying superannuation fund in certain circumstances.

In addition, the bill contains amendments to the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 to restrict complying status to resident superannuation funds and resident approved deposit funds and to specify the circumstances in which a superannuation fund could lose its complying status.
The bill also makes minor consequential amendments to the Income Tax Act 1986 and the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992.

As part of the consultative process, the Treasurer released draft provisions for the measures contained in the bill on 30 June 1994. Several changes have been made to the draft provisions to reflect comments received.

In particular, the bill contains measures to specify the exceptional circumstances in which a superannuation fund will become a non-complying fund. The proposal to tax superannuation funds that change their status from complying to non-complying or from non-resident to resident has been delayed until the 1995-96 income year.

In addition, the bill excludes from fringe benefits tax employer contributions paid to a non-resident superannuation fund for the benefit of expatriate employees who are in Australia temporarily for a period of up to four years.
The measures are expected to have a minimal effect on the revenue.
On 9 September 1994 the Treasurer announced retrospective amendments to the income tax law relating to the tax treatment of surpluses repatriated to an employer from a superannuation fund.
The amendments ensure that any payment or benefit from a superannuation fund, other than a payment or benefit to a member, is included in the assessable income of the recipient.

The purpose of the amendments is to overcome arrangements entered into by taxpayers whereby the surplus from an employer sponsored superannuation fund is repatriated to the sponsoring employer, or an associate of the sponsoring employer, in a way which avoids the payment of tax on receipt of the surplus. Those arrangements are in breach of the clear thrust of the existing law and represent a serious threat to the revenue.

To allow surpluses to be repatriated tax free would also give an undeserved benefit to employers at the expense of the taxpayer community in general. Therefore, the proposed amendments apply from 1 July 1988.
The financial impact of the proposed amendments is difficult to quantify. However, the measure will remove scope for substantial revenue leakage.
The income tax law generally taxes certain income of minors at a higher rate to prevent taxpayers diverting their income to children for the purposes of avoiding their proper tax responsibilities.

In recognition that not all unearned income of minors should be taxed at a higher rate, the law was intended to relieve from taxation at the higher rate, income derived by a minor from the investment of property transferred to the minor as part of a legal settlement in connection with a family breakdown. However the law did not achieve this because the words used in the relevant relief provisions are inconsistent with the Family Law Act 1975. Amendments in the bill will ensure that Parliament's original intention to provide relief is fulfilled.

Other amendments will clarify the anti-avoidance provisions relating to a minor's unearned income. Specifically, the amendments will continue to limit the relief from the higher tax rate to ensure that the amount qualifying for relief is no more than an arm's length rate of return on the property transferred.
The amendment of the anti-avoidance provisions will prevent a potential loss to the revenue of around $6 million per year.
Under the existing income tax law, successful cash bids for the granting of off-shore petroleum titles are deductible over 10 years or the life of the petroleum field, whichever is the lesser.
The bill proposes to extend this deduction to successful cash bids for on-shore, and overseas petroleum titles, and onshore, offshore, and overseas mineral titles.

The measures are consistent with the Government's general approach to taxation policy, which is to enhance equity between taxpayers and remove obstacles to worthwhile investment. The bill will ensure that Australian explorers and miners operating overseas are not disadvantaged whether they operate onshore, offshore or overseas in making cash bids: all successful bids will have the same Australian tax treatment, and so no area of bidding will be comparatively advantaged or disadvantaged.
The cost of the amendments to the revenue will be less than $1 million per annum.
The bill will modify the company tax imputation system in two respects.

First, it will introduce new provisions to bring the imputation system into line with the new company tax instalment arrangements. Under these arrangements, companies other than those with small tax liabilities will pay their income tax by quarterly instalment.
The amendments will permit companies to pass on to their shareholders the imputation benefits that flow from the earlier payment of company tax instalments.

The bill also contains provisions to ensure that companies cannot pass imputation benefits on to shareholders without paying the tax that the imputation credits represent. The Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Bill 1994 will impose deficit deferral tax on companies in certain circumstances to ensure the tax is paid.

The new provisions will apply to payments and refunds of company tax relating to the 1994-95 and later years of income for small and medium instalment taxpayers, and the 1995-96 and later years of income for large instalment taxpayers.
The new provisions are not expected to have a significant revenue impact.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Early payments of company tax for 1993-94

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will also modify the operation of the imputation provisions to deal with the early payment of company tax for the 1993-94 income year.
The Government last year reduced the general company tax rate from 39% to 33% with effect from the 1993-94 income year.
The amendment in this bill is a transitional measure which will ensure that total imputation credits attached to dividends cannot exceed the company tax paid.
The amendment will prevent a potential loss to revenue of around $1 million.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Payment of interest on overpayments and early payments

SPEECH.PARA: The bill introduces further changes to improve the self assessment system of taxation by making the interest regime more fair and equitable. It will complement the interest provisions for late and underpayments of income tax by expanding the scope for interest to be paid on overpayments of income tax and providing for interest to be paid on early payments of income tax.

The current law only allows for payment of interest on overpayments of income tax in limited circumstances. The proposed changes will widen the circumstances in which taxpayers will be entitled to receive interest on overpayments.
Interest under the new overpayment arrangements will be payable in respect of the overpayments that relate to 1993-94 and later years.

The bill will provide for interest to be paid to a taxpayer when income tax is paid more than 14 days before the date the amount is due and payable. This will apply to early payments of income tax, provisional tax and instalments of tax.
Interest on early payments will apply to payments made in respect of liabilities for 1993-94 and later years.

The financial impact of the interest on overpayments changes is estimated to be $1.7 million in 1994-95 and $1 million in subsequent years. Interest on early payments is estimated to cost $200,000 in 1995-96 and $130,000 in later years.
The bill contains amendments to ensure that the rate of interest used in calculating the superannuation guarantee charge is preserved at 10 per cent after 30 June 1994.
The amendments will prevent a loss to employees of around $80,000 in superannuation guarantee charges distributed for their benefit.

The bill proposes to make a technical amendment to clarify the meaning of a term used to determine how much tax is paid by a credit union. The term was introduced as a result of amendments made in the budget last year.

The Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1994 proposes a technical amendment to the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 to make small change to reduce by $1 the tax threshold for medium credit unions. This amendment corrects the threshold so that it applies as originally intended, and is consistent with the related provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
There is no cost to the revenue from the proposed changes because they ensure that the law applies as originally intended.
The bill also makes a minor amendment to the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992.
I commend the bills to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President Zakharov, on your behalf, I present the report of the Employment, Education and Training on the examination of annual reports, No. 2 of 1994.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: EMPLOYMENT SERVICES BILL 1994EMPLOYMENT SERVICES (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Employment Services Bill establishes Employment Assistance Australia within the Department of Employment, Education and Training to give effect to the case management system announced in the government's Working Nation statement as a central element to the job compact. The bill also establishes the Employment Services Regulatory Authority as an independent statutory authority within the employment, education and training portfolio.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will not be opposing this bill, but we will be moving some amendments in the committee stage of the bill. The coalition is pleased to see a decline of the appallingly high unemployment numbers this country has been forced to endure. But I do have grave doubts that Working Nation and the programs contained therein will provide any relief to those people who are unemployed, and their families who are also affected by unemployment.

This bill is aimed at the close to 900,000 unemployed people in Australia. I will give some background to these figures. In an article in the Australian of last week entitled `Hard decisions needed to give unemployed hope' Professor Helen Hughes, the director of the full employment project, based in Melbourne, said:

SPEECH.PARA: When unemployed people and those that are so discouraged that they have dropped out of the workforce are included, total unemployment is still well over 10% of the workforce.

There are more than 300,000 long term unemployed Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and immigrants who do not speak English who have more than double the unemployment rates of the community as a whole.

Nearly 60% of the single women heads of households are unemployed. Unemployment has become hereditary. The proportion of young people not working in households where one or more parents are unemployed is double that of households with employed parents. Some 700,000 children under 15 are affected by parent's unemployment.

These figures give some idea of the realities behind the often bland statistics that are bandied around. The social impact of the worst recession in 60 years has yet to peak. Family breakdown, measured by divorce rates, has reached a 10-year high. For the almost 900,000 unemployed Australians, the recession is still a reality.

PARA.TAB: The white paper is not about providing employment; it is about shuffling people from dole queues to training programs and, in so doing, making it appear that the government is actually doing something. There are no real industry initiatives in Working Nation to encourage businesses to take on more staff and, until this happens, the major problems of unemployment will not be solved.

A large drop in the unemployment figures is made up of people between the ages of 60 and 65 years who have gone on to the mature allowance and are no longer required to look for work—another government sleight of hand to maintain the charade that it is tackling unemployment. In response to questions I raised in this place last Tuesday regarding the youth training allowance, Senator Schacht said, `Of course it is not possible to guarantee a young person that the training will necessarily lead to employment.' I am glad that the government realises that Working Nation is unlikely to really help ease the burden of unemployment, although it would have been pleasing if it had actually addressed this issue.

I am sure the government will have read the report by the full employment project, which I mentioned earlier, Achieving Full Employment, which was quite scathing, to say the least, of this government's failure to implement policies which will effectively reduce long-term unemployment. The study reiterates the comments I have just made that the job compact will only shuffle the queues of the long-term unemployed but will still leave in place more than 300,000 long-term unemployed by the end of the decade. As the study says, some of the youngsters leaving school this year—at the end of 1994—will still be unemployed when the Olympic Games come to Sydney. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Birthdays, Christmases and school holidays become guilt ridden as children are deprived of pleasures that other Australians take for granted. A beer, a cup of coffee, having family or friends to a meal have to be forgone—
or seriously thought about. It continues:
Many people's lives collapse under the financial and psychological stresses of unemployment. . .
Among key conclusions of the study are:

Working Nation's `job compact' may seem to be effective as the recovery creates additional jobs, but as the process continues it will be evident that the `job compact' merely recycles the unemployment queues.

The study goes on to conclude that, by the end of the decade, the present unemployment queue might be shuffled by a successful jobs compact program—and success is doubtful—but only to create a different group of more than 300,000 long-term unemployed. The study further concludes:

There is little doubt, however, that a downturn by the late 1990s is possible and even likely. The combination of a downturn with less than sustained 4.75 per cent annual growth would mean a return to double digit unemployment before or by the end of the 1990s. Unemployment could even be higher than the 11% peak of the last recession.

To paraphrase, the report says that only a dramatic acceleration of economic policy reform, a radical reappraisal of work practices and a tripling of Australia's manufacturing exports would allow a return to full employment by the year 2000. I suggest to the Senate that none of these policies have effectively been put in place. The report goes on to say that Australia's growth potential is being undermined by weak macro-economic policies, election cycle fiscal policies and over-regulation of the labour market.

PARA.TAB: The report calls for the abolition of penalty rates, the removal of shift work restrictions to allow 24-hour operation of manufacturing plants and a reinvigoration of post-secondary training and education as preconditions for significant jobs growth in the economy. It is also extremely critical of the Dawkins changes to education.

The report says that Australia's work force is expected to grow to 9.2 million people by the year 2000. To reduce unemployment to at least three per cent would then require the creation of about 250,000 jobs every year for the next six years. On current economic growth projections this will not occur. I quote again from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: If cyclical downturns continue to occur in the Australian economy, unemployment levels are likely to be around 7 or 8 per cent in the late 1990s, and they could ratchet up again in an economic downturn to 11 percent or more.

No amount of training programs or the provision of case managers will aid that projected number—11 per cent of Australians who are unemployed. Small business is the key to increasing employment and yet it is this essential group that the government continues to overlook. I refer to the Yellow Pages small business index, quoted in an article in the Australian on 12 October 1994, which states:
40% of small business complaints relate to labour market policies. Overall, 55% of the small business surveyed thought that federal government policies worked against them.
Dr Marsden, the index's economic consultant, said:

Taken together, labour market issues such as federal industrial relations policy, superannuation policy and employee training and concessions now rank with taxation as the largest single factor behind the negative assessment of the Federal Government.

Small business is reported as being particularly resentful of the termination regulations of the government's industrial relations policies, citing them as a major impediment to hiring labour. Taxation remained at the top of the small business hate list, with 39 per cent of respondents claiming it was to blame for their negative view of the government. The feeling that government did not understand the needs of small business was 24 per cent, compared with 9 per cent in May 1993. Too much bureaucracy was 22 per cent today, compared with 27 per cent in May 1993. Excessive government charges was 17 per cent today, compared with 7 per cent in May 1993. These were also high on the agenda. If these concerns are not addressed, we will never maintain a reduction in the number of unemployed people.

PARA.TAB: In the Age recently, 30 November 1994, David McKenzie reported on the most recent Yellow Pages small business index survey. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The edge has started to come off small business confidence. The latest Yellow Pages small business index survey has found that sales and employment levels among small business grew more slowly than expected during the three months to October.
The net proportion expecting the total economy to improve over the same period was only 30%, a figure which had fallen progressively from the 65% result from the February 1994 survey.

The possibility of rising interest rates—and this has been flagged again by the government this week—let alone tax hikes, will not restore confidence in small business to any great measure. The huge deficit is a significant factor in holding back a rejuvenation of business confidence. The McKinsey report on business investment and regional prosperity released on 30 March 1994 demonstrates how the government's industrial relations laws are damaging the recovery. One business owner stated:
I can name five businesses who are not taking on people because it has become more difficult to sack them if conditions change or they don't work out. I'm the same; I am more conservative now.
I can certainly back up this quotation with all the anecdotal evidence that I receive from businessmen around Australia and Victoria particularly.

PARA.TAB: The second highest ranked impediment to investment was cited as government oncosts, identified as payroll tax, the training guarantee levy, workers compensation and associated compliance costs. It is significant that almost one in three growing businesses said they would hire an additional person if oncosts were lower. I suggest that if every small business in Australia hired one more person tomorrow employment would be reduced to an amazing level.

Labour market flexibility was also viewed as essential to investment growth. Nowhere does the white paper tackle key issues such as labour costs and restrictive award provisions. Getting rid of unfair dismissal laws, for example, would be one way to give small businesses some incentive to employ people, because the unfair dismissal laws certainly act as a deterrent. There are other factors besides micro-economic reform which could be considered in examining ways to reduce unemployment.

In a paper entitled Child Care as a Factor in Understanding Labour Market Participation presented at the EPAC child care conference, the author, Joan Corbett, gave evidence that strengthened the argument that child care is a prerequisite needed to facilitate the entry of women into the paid work force. Ms Corbett suggested that formal child care services other than preschool are the services most importantly related to women's labour force participation. Deborah Brennan in Moncrieff Cochran 1993 also said that `statistics in hidden unemployment also shows that the absence of affordable child care is one of the major constraints to women actively seeking work'. This government, as I have mentioned in this place before, has been far from effective in providing choice, accessibility or affordability in relation to child care.

I would now like to turn to the case management system, which will be provided under the Employment Services Regulatory Authority. That Joan Kirner, the failed former Victorian premier, has been chosen to head the interim board is evidence that the white paper cannot possibly be serious about offering genuine hope to the victims of the recession. Mrs Kirner's lack of business expertise, let alone the creation of massive unemployment and state debt in Victoria, hardly makes her a credible candidate to head such a board. Given this government's past record in giving jobs to the boys and girls, I suppose we should hardly be surprised that qualifications for this particular job seem not to be a prerequisite.

I would hope that ESRA, in its role as an accreditation agency, does not impose tight guidelines on the non-CES providers so that, in effect, they are forced to become near clones of the CES. Such imposition would be contrary to the general spirit of competition. The coalition welcomes the spirit of competition involving the greater involvement of non-Department of Employment, Education and Training agencies, supposing it is competition rather than a very great similarity as previously mentioned. Surveys suggest that as few as 17 per cent of employers make use of the Commonwealth Employment Service and that most job seekers who obtain work find their jobs by means other than the CES.

I am also concerned that some case managers will be working only part time in that capacity. They will be doing a mix of functions, servicing clients in case management and performing other related services in the CES. I hope that each client will get the full attention of a case manager and that case managers with other duties will not find that this distracts them from their clients.

I understand also that some clients will be dealt with on a team basis. Again, I hope this does not lead to the wasting of resources as clients get shuffled from one case manager to another. I find it quite appalling that there are currently 82,000 people on a waiting list for services from case managers. I find it quite strange that there are projections for people to be case managed but there are no similar projections for the number of case managers. How does the government know what services should be provided?

I am informed that the notice given to each client of the opportunity of an interview will depend on the load of each case manager. Some people will not get notices at all, I am informed, because they will be told when they are in the CES, perhaps being interviewed for another reason. That does not seem to be a particularly good way of getting notification about interviews to people. Some uniformity of procedure might have been desirable.

Taking into account the number of case managers and the number of unemployed, the load for every case worker works out at approximately 125 clients per year, or about 1.5 working days per client per year. That includes one-on-one discussions between clients and the case officers preparing the activity agreement, arranging program placements, follow-up, and all the associated paperwork. Let us hope that this is sufficient. It hardly seems like a particularly long time in which to help someone who may have been unemployed for two years or longer. Case managers are expected to match employees to employers, but there is still no attempt at tackling the real problem, which is how to allow and encourage businesses to employ more people.

In summary, as I said at the start of my remarks, the coalition will not oppose this bill but we have serious doubts about the ability of this government to effectively reduce and maintain a real decline in the number of unemployed. Without real job creation facilitated by micro-economic reform, any number of case managers and training programs will be ineffective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, this legislation is a disappointment. The jobs compact could have been a huge step forward. The fact is that what we have in front of us is not a huge step. It may be painted as such, but it does not achieve it.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats started talking about some form of compact between the community, the government and the unemployed back in 1992. We envisaged that a community commitment to the unemployed in the form of a jobs levy, a government commitment in the form of large-scale active employment programs, and an unemployed commitment in the form of a preparedness to have a go were reasonable things to seek in such a program. But when the government went cold on the jobs levy, the thing rapidly deflated, so much so that when I look at these bills I come to the conclusion that the obligations flow pretty much one way. These bills are full of all the things that the unemployed are required to do but the only new commitment from the government is the provision of case managers to make sure that they do them.

The government has pointed to an extra $6.5 billion over four years, but on even a cursory examination that number does not really exist. It is a mirage of funny money. It cannot be described as anything else because the truth is that all the money being spent on the jobs compact is a reshuffling of money that is already being spent in one form or another on labour market programs and the like.

When people look carefully at the figures, as we have done, they discover that over the next few years the government will spend less on the unemployed than it did in the last financial year. The jobs compact is a huge public relations win for the government. It sounds good; it projects an image of actually doing something. But, for the unemployed, it means that they have to be prepared to be pushed around a lot harder to receive the same or even less support from the government.

I would ask the Senate to look at the figures. When we add up the white paper expenditure on employment related programs—including training, industry and infrastructure spending—the government's claim of a $1 billion boost this financial year actually turns out, in real terms, to be a cut of $437 million. That is, in real terms, the government will be spending $437 million less on alleviating unemployment this year than it did last year.

In 1995-96—the first full year of the jobs compact, when the government claims it will be costing over $1.7 billion—the real cost will be a saving to the budget, in real terms, of $1.3 billion, rising to $1.5 billion the following year. On more conservative assumptions, Professor John Piggott of the University of New South Wales predicts a $342 million improvement to the government's fiscal position due to the jobs compact. So it is not only the Democrats who are questioning the figures; we are not the only ones who claim that the government has jiggled these figures.

What about the actual jobs? There are not too many jobs coming from the proud package that we have before us today. The vast bulk of subsidised job compact places will come through jobstart and the youth training initiative. On the government's own statistics, 80 to 85 per cent of these subsidised places will come at the expense of unsubsidised workers. According to Professor John Piggott, the jobs compact will create, at best, a net reduction of 50,000 in the number of unemployed. That works out to be one extra job for every 16 Australians who at the moment are unemployed.

So what good will this package really do? I believe that it makes sense every now and then to have a good hard look at what the government is doing in its programs and work out where it could have been done better. To its credit, the government has agreed to do that and has decided that its employment program should be weighted more favourably to the long-term unemployed. This legislation will have the effect of maybe shuffling around that queue a little bit. The hope is that, by doing so, by making the long-term unemployed more employable, we will reduce the rate of unemployment at which full employment, as measured by employers' preparedness to employ, kicks in and pushes up wages.

We support that general aim, but we are concerned that part of this government's solution is simply redefining `long-term unemployed'. It is quite simple to see through that. If people who are presently defined as long-term unemployed embark upon a training course then, of course, they are no longer long-term unemployed. But are they employed at the end of the training course? That is the question. Senator Troeth raised this matter earlier and I cannot see any reason for changing the direction of her concerns. We agree with her. The question is: at the end of the program, has the person who is no longer long-term unemployed changed into an employed person? While we question that, we do support the general aim of improving the situation of the unemployed, but it is a question of how it is done.

We believe that the jobs compact should become very much more a genuine compact, a genuine agreement—I deliberately stress that word `agreement'—between the government and the unemployed. The obligations must be more reciprocal; more balanced, one to the other. It is our view that the present bill weighs too much against the unemployed person, giving the government and its new policemen, the case managers, too much power. We will be moving amendments in the committee stage to address this imbalance. In particular, we want to make sure that a case management activity agreement is just that: an activity agreement.

The current bill contains some outrageous clauses, one suggesting that the terms of the case management activity agreement are set by the case manager and that a failure to agree to those terms by the unemployed person, a refusal to accept a fait accompli, would lead to immediate loss of benefits. We think that provision is outrageous and we will be seeking to amend it. We also want to look at the outcomes of case management, remembering that a large part of this bill privatises much of the case management function of the CES and that there will be a large payment by results approach to case management.

We are concerned about the unemployed being tipped into jobs that do not have a future, just to satisfy the payment by outcomes requirement. Given that many of the jobs they are placed in will attract jobstart subsidies, I would be particularly worried about the employers employing them until the subsidy runs out, then—having qualified through achieving an outcome—getting rid of them and seeking another subsidised worker. I realise there are a few impediments to following that course too readily but I suggest that in the real world those impediments are hopped over quite often. We will be moving amendments to require placements to be quality placements and to lead to sustainable long-term employment.

A further issue we will be seeking to address by amendment is the recognition of the wider definition that productive employment, producing something of benefit to Australia, whether social or artistic, need not be paid employment. I thought that by now the government would be aware of a whole subeconomy of unpaid employment in this country. Work performed in the home is a classic example. Voluntary work performed in the community sector is another and the artistic community, in some respects, is a third.

The notion of what employment is is vital to an understanding of what we value as a community. While this bill partly recognises this, in a begrudging sort of way, I do not think it goes far enough in recognising that the nature of employment is changing. We will never again in this country have the situation where everyone who wants a full-time paid job can have one. This bill is the medium through which we should be seeking to encourage and expand the various alternatives. But we do not see leadership in that direction from this bill. We should; but we do not see any notion that this has been seriously considered. In a very limited, traditional and prescriptive way we see the outcomes that the case managers will be paid for. The Democrats will be moving some amendments to seek to achieve a more enlightened and flexible approach in that area.

I also want to note the nasty little swiftie the government has tried to pull in the consequential amendments to this bill. Careful observers and those most directly affected will know that only a few months ago the Democrats successfully moved an amendment to the Social Security Act requiring two payment periods' grace before a breach resulted in benefits being withdrawn. That, we believe, was an equitable amendment which provided some more justice to the system and one which was of considerable assistance to those directly affected. It will avoid the current situation where often the unemployed person does not even know an activity agreement has been breached until the benefits are failed to be paid.

The government, in an employment bill, has sought to sneak back into the negative the amendment which was supported by the Democrats and the opposition. We concede that there were some problems with our earlier amendment and there may be some breaches, but this backdoor approach to negativing an amendment by the Senate which achieved a good outcome—this sneaky backdoor method—is a bit steep. I am sure we will say a bit more about that in the committee stage. It bears signalling that the government has failed to pull this little stroke at this stage and that we will be making a bit more noise about it.

I take this opportunity to urge the government to ensure that those on a disability support pension have full access to the jobs compact, if they want it, without losing their pension. I understand that the government is looking at a means of ensuring that a pensioner who registers with the CES is automatically fast-tracked into the `at risk' category and given access to case management. I will be seeking an assurance from the minister that that is the case and that there is a mechanism for ensuring that.

The disabled, if they feel capable of participating in the work force, should be given every assistance. Having said that, if people do not feel capable of participating in the work force they should not be forced to do so. I believe voluntary registration with the CES, tied to fast-track access to case management, could be a good means of achieving that assistance.

In conclusion, it is readily apparent that this bill will achieve only a tiny proportion of all that which the government hype and the taxpayer funded advertising claim it will. For some categories of long-term unemployed, it carries the potential for great benefit. For that reason, we are treating it seriously and are not being pernickety about particular clauses and phrases. We are looking very generously at the overall thrust of this bill because we recognise the potential for great benefit for some people. But the balance in this bill is not right—there is no way the government can claim that it is right—and it is up to the Senate to correct it. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to say the reason we are dealing with the Employment Services Bill 1994 is that at this moment there is an attempt being made to usurp the democratic processes of this chamber behind closed doors. The Greens will be supporting this bill because we believe case management has the potential to deal with the complex issues of long-term unemployment. However, we would like to take the opportunity to highlight the innumerable problems associated with the government's proposals for this type of case management.

PARA.TAB: There are many community concerns and concerns from people who deal with the most disadvantaged people in the labour market that this new move to case management which is outlined in the Employment Services Bill will not help the people who need it the most. Organisations such as Centacare, ACOSS, the Welfare Rights Centre and the Victorian Social Justice Council believe that, although case management and individual treatment may be a valuable concept in principle, the way the government has set up this scheme under the preferred model of case management is too imbued with economic efficiency measures at the expense of quality service which disadvantaged people most need.

The preferred model of case management that the government has chosen to adopt has a number of inadequacies. It fails to have the flexibility that community service organisations need to implement case management according to their mission goals. It fails to provide funds for case management according to regional need. It has limited regulation of entry of private providers. It fails to recognise the psycho-social aspects of unemployment, and it fails to provide an independent advocacy service for unemployed people receiving case management.

The message from community service organisations is that they must be allowed to expand on the model of case management set forth by the government that would allow them to provide additional care which is more in line with their mission goals of treating the whole person and not just a part. Those who work with a holistic approach to case management believe that this system proposed by the government is too limited and focused on quantitative and economically defined outcomes.

Other public service providers feel that, in order to maintain service quality to unemployed people, private providers must be rigorously regulated to ensure that they are always working in the best interests of the unemployed individual. Measures need to be in place to make sure that such organisations are focused on empowering unemployed people to make their own decisions rather than making their decisions for them and therefore increasing corporate profit at the expense of their welfare. In line with this, it would be advisable for the government to consider a code of ethics for ESRA to use as a guide for public and private service providers.

The point about building economic efficiency measures into the management of unemployed people is that it can work at odds with the provision of quality services, which cannot be defined in dollar terms. This is a fundamental problem in this thinking that economic efficiency is the main function of service provision because it instigates competition instead of cooperation. Services will compete for the most employable and work ready for the workplace because those people are the most economically efficient unemployed people to deal with. So economic efficiency measures will enhance the process of creaming where labour market programs constantly cream 20 per cent of the most work ready people out of the labour market and consistently leave those who need assistance, time and care at the bottom of the heap.

What will happen is that the private providers will manage the most employable of the unemployed and leave the long-term unemployed with pre-vocational and self-esteem needs, which pre-empt vocational needs, to the community service providers. These organisations work on a different level and are extremely concerned that private providers will be allowed to get away with profiteering behaviour such as creaming referrals, clients being manipulated to take jobs that are unsuitable and skimping on the provision of services. It would therefore be more productive if ESRA takes a role in encouraging cooperation between agencies to stimulate quality service.

It is also important that case management be varied by region and that disadvantaged regions lacking support services be taken into consideration for more resources for unemployed people. In terms of the quality of the case managers who are delivering the case management services, we need to make sure they understand the complexities of long-term unemployment and the high expectations placed upon them as case managers. They need to be trained and responsive to the issue of long-term unemployment. They need to be able to provide to their clients social and emotional support with the help of community organisations if they need it. They need to take the time to give post-employment guidance, and they most of all need comprehensive guidelines for assessment of people who are unemployed.

It is also evident that the dual roles of providing support and acting as assessor for the activity test are mutually exclusive and incompatible. Because the case manager will be delivering a service on two contradictory levels, the person who is receiving the service will question the genuine nature of the assistance and will not receive the emotional, psychological and social support he or she needs which requires trust and sharing.

Also, this legislation, in the way in which it is written, takes quite a functional and utilitarian approach to the management of human beings. It denies any other barriers to employment for psycho-social hindrances and therefore makes no effort to address them but deals in terms of skills deficits as if that will solve the world unemployment problem.

As we all know, there are many barriers to employment, such as discrimination by employers; disabilities; language and ethnicity; low self-esteem; mental illness; depression; loss of personal power and dignity; poverty; homelessness; and drug and alcohol problems. There is no consideration for the people with these problems who are deeply disadvantaged in the labour market. No softly, softly approach or affirmative action is built into this bill for them.

It is true that this new system also maintains the myth that unemployed people are either a threat or victims, that they need to be helped as drop-outs or that they are a threat to society and should not interacting in the same activities that mainstream society indulges in. It is interesting to reflect on some of the figures provided by the Victorian Social Justice Council, which says that the limits to the debate about services to the unemployed are well articulated in the government's own figures published in the green paper.

In 1992, following newstart's initiation when there was increased pressure on the unemployed to use CES services, CES secured only 3.1 per cent of all jobs secured by unemployed people. At that time, private agencies secured only 0.6 per cent of successful jobs granted to unemployed people. But the largest percentage figure of the people who secured 38 per cent of jobs secured was gained by so-called `cold canvassing' of employers; that is, by unaided job search of unemployed people themselves.

When we can see that much labour market activity can occur without the help of professionals from either the public or the private sector, we must make sure that any new service we bring in to help unemployed people is not at the expense of their doing it themselves and empowering themselves in the process but is not falling back into the old patterns of treating unemployed people as not wanting to work, being lazy, needing assistance or someone to do it for them, et cetera. These are harmful old myths about the unemployed that it is time to discard. If we treat these people as equals, then we may be able to help them rather than hinder them and make them feel resentful of our demands at the same time.

The Greens will be moving a number of amendments—that is, if the democratic process of this chamber is not further usurped to stop us from being able to prepare them. These amendments, which we will be moving at the committee stage of the bill, are based on the amendments moved for the youth training allowance. They deal with the negotiating ability of the unemployed person in the case management process and different treatment for those who are deeply disadvantaged in the labour market. The consequential amendments deal with leaving two days pay before a person is cut off from an allowance, which we think is a fairer measure.

I hope honourable senators will give these amendments serious consideration at the committee stage of this bill. I hope the government allows the various parties involved time to make sure that this important debate is carried on in the way that is fairest and will give the best hearing to these important issues.
