SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When progress was reported on Thursday I had begun to speak on amendment 11, which was designed to include technology transfer to the Third World as reasonably responsible of the public in patent law. As in any case under this section of the act, this does not mean that all companies must act in this way. It means only that, if a company does not ensure that there is some provision for technology transfer in line with international agreements to facilitate it, another company can challenge its right to exclusive control and perhaps get a licence to produce the technology to facilitate such transfer.

PARA.TAB: It is not a big thing for the company. It does not say that the company must allow anyone access to its technology without paying. It does not say that the company must allow competition in the open market. All it says is that, if a court decides that technology transfer is an important issue in respect of a certain patent in a certain country and the court decides that the company is not meeting its humanitarian and development assistance duties in respect of the public, the court can order the company to address the situation or allow a licence on the patent for another company to do so. This amendment does not guarantee that the situation in which a company uses patents to prevent development goals held now as a common interest of humanity will be resolved. It simply sets up an option to make some resolution possible.

In the context of this, we should note that many former colonial nations went through protracted periods where their technology was actively suppressed by their colonial masters. Nations like Britain worked to destroy industries such as the Indian textile industry as well as protecting the British industry through trade barriers. As a consequence of active suppression, including the literal destruction of factories—not as a consequence of technical productivity—India, which had been a cloth exporter for centuries, became an importer of British cloth and clothing.

GATT was born in part as a consequence of the same forces that gave rise to the United Nations. These were forces in social perspectives borne out of a struggle against militaristic, imperialistic aggression and non-democratic nations. The International Trade Organisation and the United Nations were both designed to break down colonial barriers and foster cooperative development. The UN quickly got bogged down in Cold War polarisation, but the agenda of political decolonisation proceeded. The ITO never got up because of lack of support from the United States, but its original agenda was to break the trade stranglehold the imperial nations had on their colonies and the barriers that the Eurocentric empires had against each other.

One of the concerns raised in the ITO was that the commodities fetch proper prices, instead of the distorted prices established to benefit the masters within empires. This move was later echoed in calls in the United Nations by the ex-colonial nations. The use of development and trade, including what is called the strategic trade policy, to support distorted prices has continued to be of concern. The need to remedy this situation was a major plank of the new international economic order—a policy ratified by the United Nations in 1974.

The problem persisted and was pointed out again by the Brandt report entitled North/ South and later by the Brundtland report. Another major problem has been, and continues to be, the transfer of technology. Technology transfer was identified as a crucial component of sustainable development. While that term and what it means is contentious, anyone reading Our Common Future should clearly understand that a major aspect of the report was the focus on poverty.

The Brundtland report stated the link between poverty and environmental degradation. Corporate vested interests have made the most of that link, stating that the way to environmental protection is through growth. This is not quite what it said. The report said that poverty and the attempt to rise out of it increasingly resulted in degradation of the environment.

Like the Brandt report, the Brundtland report also noted that development can result in increased environmental destruction and, under laissez-faire market conditions, can and often does result in greater human poverty and suffering. It pointed out that at this point in history environmental degradation occurs on such a scale that the whole planet is affected. It is therefore a situation where humanitarian goals, the goals of bringing all people out of the most desperate poverty, coincide with our common global environmental goals. That is the message of Our Common Future.

It is said in that report that there should be growth. The report said that the growth must be an entirely different sort of growth in which nations work cooperatively to assure social justice, equity and the development of environmentally sound technologies. It said that the need for growth was primarily in the developing nations and primarily to meet human needs. It said over and over that the essential ingredient in this technology transfer is that if growth is to benefit anyone it must be just and equitable growth and must involve meeting needs through the most technically advanced means without destroying the environment. It said that the developing world cannot develop along the exploitative path we have followed, that most advanced technology will be required to allow it to develop along more sustainable pathways and that many new technologies will be required.

The report says that developed nations have a role to play as the nations with wealth and that we need education with an industrial base to work on the new technology. It did not say that this was to become a licence to print money—a new means of exploitation of the South. It did not say that the South should be required to produce an ever increasing volume of primary products and manufactured goods for the North at ever decreasing price. It did not say that the North should agree to lower some of its trade barriers in return for a complete stranglehold on technology through trade related intellectual property regimes.

What the report did say is that technology transfer is crucial. It means the best available technology must be available to the developing nations at a price which allows it to be used in an integrated way in all national development. The Brundtland report made that point clearly and the issue has been seen as vital in agenda 21. It is seen as vital in effective action on climate change and other global problems. The TRIPS agreement goes the other way.

Patents and other forms of intellectual property are new ways of ensuring that developing nations cannot develop without assuring someone else a major property. It will grant monopoly control of ideas and technology and exclude the developing world. Developed nations hope they will get advantages out of this, through having companies patent and produce high-tech goods in their nations. They hope this corporate monopoly on technology will benefit them at the expense of the developing world. Perhaps it will, although this is not certain.

It is certain that it is not likely to benefit the developing world. One of the things that developing countries have been able to do in the past is simply use what they cannot pay for. Nations like India and China have simply used ideas and technology as well as they could in their efforts to develop. If they needed a medicine which was too expensive and a company would not make it or sell it in the country then, if possible, they made it themselves. If their balance of trade would be thrown out completely by the need to import basic technologies and companies would not set up plants, developing nations set them up and allowed them to be set up regardless of patents and licences.

This has not resulted in huge unfair international competition. The goods are rarely exported successfully, unless to other developing nations willing to ignore intellectual property. It may have resulted in unfair domestic competition within these developing nations, depending on how one defines fair. It has resulted in medicines and goods being available much more cheaply in the developing world. Anyone need only visit a pharmacy in India to see that virtually everything from aspirin and medicine to antibiotics is much less expensive—often a tenth or less of the cost in our pharmacies, in spite of the subsidies government here pays on medicines to assure their availability.

One only needs to look at the cost of most anything from car parts to movies to stainless steel pressure cookers to understand that things can be made, distributed and sold much more cheaply than they are in the north. Looking at Indian prices was, for many years, a good gauge of the profit margins companies put on their goods. Admittedly, the quality of medicine in India is not as high as in Australia. We can afford more quality than it can, but is the qualitative improvement really 10 or 20 times better? How much price increase is justified for that qualitative improvement?

This amendment is not about the price of Australian goods. It is about the price of medicine and other goods in Africa, India and other developing nations. It is an issue of whether it should be an Indian government or a corporate board room in Brazil which decides what quality of medicine at what price will be available in Indian markets.

The effect of the willingness of developing nations to ignore patents and other intellectual property when corporate interest conflicted with national interests is that corporations found themselves in a position where, to get anything, they had to deal. Many companies did deal, setting up for inexpensive domestic production in developing nations or granting licence for inexpensive, non-export oriented production. In a similar way, copyright holders granted concessional licence on books and recordings as an alternative to seeing their works simply pirated.

What TRIPS seeks to do is eliminate this negotiating power of developing nations. In aggressively pursuing intellectual property, what is happening is that developing nations will be put under threat of cross-sectional sanctions against their exports by nations representing corporate patent holders. Corporations can then make market decisions not to produce in a developing nation, not to produce to their lowest standards and not to grant any concessional access through lower prices or licence arrangements. The developing nations are allowed to sell goods to the former colonial masters in return for granting foreigners and transnational companies on restricted access to come and buy, to control resources, to produce and to export the goods, assets and profits. These nations can also hope that companies might choose them for a site and improve the balance of trade figures.

TRIPS has another unfortunate effect for developing nations. We have seen in situations such as the erythromycin patent I mentioned the other day that researchers in developing nations can be effectively robbed of any return on their work. This is not unusual. In addition to the exploitative treatment of actual employees or researchers, we see a situation where, under various aid or development programs, northern researchers may work alongside researchers from a developing nation.

These southern researchers have usually been through a university of the nation concerned, or they may have either studied abroad or done additional work at a northern university. Yet, almost always, there is a vast differential in pay, although there may be little or no differential in work or talent. It may be weighted on the side of the southern researcher. This frequently carries through in terms of credit given to the intellectual property claims, meaning that the patent goes to the north and the south is excluded. Southern nations and nationals have little effective opportunity to challenge such situations legally in northern courts. Even where a developing nation company discovers or develops a product itself, it is possible it may not be able to effectively press for intellectual patents before some transnational patents the idea.

Under current patent laws we are seeing a whole new realm of exploitation and distortion. The biotechnology and biochemical substances area is the biggest growth area in intellectual property. We now see companies often assisted under `sustainable development' programs to catalogue or investigate biological researchers for conservation, claiming this knowledge as intellectual property. We also see patents granted on naturally occurring biochemicals and/or the genes regulating them and granted on the basis of specific search.

This is a new class of patents based on the principle that in biotechnology the value is in knowing and that the innovative step is knowing what to look for and doing the work to look. This kind of patent is not universally accepted, although the United States and a number of nations are increasingly open to accept such patent claims.

An upshot of this sort of claim is that a company can send a researcher to India to look at traditional medicine and agricultural practices using plants or other biological agents. If that northern researcher does some experiment which indicates that the traditional use works, if the researcher does a chemical analysis of the active agent or even if that person takes a cell line of the biological organism concerned, the company can patent this on the basis of specific search. As a consequence, we now see patents being taken out on practices such as the use of neem as a pesticide.

Neem is an Indian tree that has been traditionally used for centuries. It is known in India as a powerful insecticide and it has been used in that way. Indian farmers developed presses to extract neem oil and use it on their plants. The technology is common in India and Nepal and is promoted heavily as an alternative to commercial chemical inputs. It has recently been patented and is now being marketed and developed in the developing world. I recently saw on TV an advertisement which related to this technology. There has been no recognition granted to the farmers who, through centuries of observation and experimentation, developed the substance that is used for that purpose. Moreover, a patent can be used to block any attempt by India to develop neem as a product and export it or get some return on what is basically a stolen traditional technology.

There is a huge range of issues in the current way intellectual property is being granted and used. International attempts to examine this have been effectively overridden by the acceptance of TRIPS. Most of the intellectual property push has had a regressive effect on southern development, yet we want to expand these property rights without question. I call upon honourable senators to support our amendment. It is not much, but it at least recognises the need for some provision for technology transfer to counteract the effect of intellectual property regimes. It at least provides an option that might be used.

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 13, page 7, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: ``13D. Section 135 of the Principal Act is amended by adding the following word and paragraph after paragraph (1)(a)(c):

`; or (e)there is no concessional level of maximum reasonable licence payment for developing nations for the purposes of their domestic production consistent with Australia's obligations under technology transfer provisions embodied in international agreements, for example the United Nations Agenda 21 program, climate change conventions, and social justice conventions.'.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. We believe it is extremely important that the exploitation of developing countries not continue and that we enable technology transfer to be carried out on equitable terms.

—I welcome the fact that the committee is dealing with this bill. I acknowledge that some of my colleagues, and probably some opposition senators, think I have taken leave of my senses to take people at their word that this legislation will be dealt with in a reasonable time rather than have to proceed by any of the resolutions available to enforce that outcome. In my experience, such agreements have always been adhered to in the past and I guess I am relying upon that occurring again today. I trust it will be the case.

PARA.TAB: The amendments we have before us are motivated by concerns which I think almost every Australian would share. But the problem is, as in effect Senator Margetts said at the end of her contribution, that the Greens' amendment will not solve the problem. Although I do not agree with everything she said, I accept some of the underlying motivation and the concern about living standards of people in what is known in the jargon as the south.

Of course, some minor change to Australian law in this matter will not overcome any of the problems that have been outlined. It is a sort of declaratory statement of no international effect. The only practical effect is to put Australians at some disadvantage compared with their international competitors. If we were as Australians to consider that we wanted to take an initiative in this area, I think it would require a lot more consideration and deliberation than this. It is the sort of matter that might want to be referred at some stage, if people want to pursue it as a priority question, to some appropriate Senate committee or other committee for some consideration, but we would not just do it by this sort of back-of-the-envelope method.

While nobody could denigrate the legitimate concern that there are many people in the world living in abject poverty and that if we can do things to assist them we should, declaratory statements by our Senate under the guise of an amendment will not achieve that purpose. I do not denigrate the motivation but simply suggest that we cannot support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean we are operating on the principle that if we do not get them someone else will?
—No.

That the amendment (Senator Margetts') be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 12.After clause 13, page 7, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "13E. Section 136 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Negotiation positions on international agreements to be consistent with the requirements of the public interest under Australian law

PARA.TAB: "`136. Persons representing the Commonwealth in any international negotiation concerning intellectual property with a view to the formulation of international standards or instruments:

(a)may not in relation to the negotiation agree to, accept or promote any rule, regulation, standard, agreement or other instrumental outcome that may in any way reduce the scope or effectiveness of the provisions set out in sections 133, 134 and 135 in so far as they protect the reasonable requirements of the public; and

TAB.TAB: (b)must use their best endeavours to ensure that principles consistent with those established by section 135 are included in any international agreement or instrument in relation to patents for the time being under negotiation.".

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have tried to ensure that recourse to the provisions for meeting the reasonable requirements of the public found in section 135 is available to the general public. We have tried to include among these reasonable requirements an assurance that the actual innovators would benefit, that technology transfer would be supported in line with international agreements. The government in its amendments has sought to define exactly the conditions under which these reasonable requirements can be pressed, although we feel that the way it has done so has weakened the provisions. Unfortunately, while sections 133, 134 and 135 work to protect the public, section 136 counteracts this. Section 136 says, in effect, that any international agreement can override the public good. This is a situation of great concern and we see the extension of patent powers under GATT.

PARA.TAB: It should never be the case that we sign an international agreement that would override reasonable public interests. Even though the Senate does not support our call to assure that the ambassador to the World Trade Organisation does not argue against Australian law in a way that is counter to the desires of parliament, I believe that there is room for a specific call that in no case should an ambassador agree to a measure that would eclipse reasonable public requirements for patent holders as embodied in section 135. This is not a big thing and the requirements are not onerous, yet the current section 136 sets the stage for such public interest to be eclipsed. Trade related intellectual property under the World Trade Organisation is the vehicle that would accomplish it.

This Senate amendment seeks to reverse this situation. It deletes the existing section and replaces it with a section stating that negotiators on patent should not sign any agreement which would override reasonable requirements of the public. These rights are essential in maintaining some guarantee of public benefit from patents. The amendment goes further and states that, on basic public interest grounds, negotiators should be striving to incorporate similar reasonable requirements of the public provisions in international treaties.

In this debate, I have highlighted several problems in relation to patents. I know that the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine share many of the Greens' concerns and have said so here. That the two major parties seem neither to have concerns nor to recognise any concerns does not seem to reflect public sentiment, academic opinion or international issues in relation to global economic and social change. The requirements of section 135 are simple. They are designed to prevent the worst abuses of granting monopoly control over technology. Such abuses may not be a problem for corporations that hold the patents but they are a problem for any other corporation, small companies and individual innovators, and they definitely pose a problem for society, the public and the people who they are charged to represent.

As a means of ensuring there is some recourse where abuse of monopoly power occurs, the measures here should be promoted and promoted strongly in international negotiations. There would be fewer problems for people accepting the benefits of TRIPS or other regimes if there were some clear mechanism for integrating social concerns. Instead, we have means of overriding them and Senator McMullan cannot understand why people are presently concerned about this. I ask senators to support this amendment. It is simple and responsible to both Australia and a wider social constituency. There is nothing protectionist in this except that it seeks to protect society from abuses of monopoly power. This cannot be a bad thing and is entirely on side with a desire to see healthy competition consistent with granting recognition for development work done.

I also point out to the Senate that, in spite of the large number of researchers of a high calibre in Australia and the innovations that have come from this country, Australia has traditionally been very poor at developing these innovations. Patents, or effective patent control, have all too often gone overseas. As a consequence, Australia is frequently not one of the first nations to benefit from the innovation that occurs here. We remain a small and distant market globally, which may not be worth developing in early stages of production. In such a situation, some protection against the monopoly control granted to companies overseas is all the more important, and the interest of Australian innovators is not served by suppressing public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts's amendment is similar in approach to some amendments she has moved previously which the Australian Democrats have supported on the basis that the public interest must be taken into account by our negotiators and that this parliament has a right to set the standards and the policies which should be followed by our negotiators. I will not take time to address this particular amendment any further. I am as conscious as the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) is of the time constraints that we all operate under. However, these bills are important and I wish to rectify very briefly—in no more than three minutes—some comments that the minister made last week and during the weekend.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats do not approach these bills in an obstructionist way. Further, we are prepared to concede that the minister has some personal concern about the outcome of these bills. Unfortunately, the way in which these bills were introduced and the content of some of them do not appear to reflect adequately the personal concern that the minister has.

The first point I want to make is that it is important for the health of public debate in this country that the other side of the trade deregulation debate gets an airing. There are losses as well as gains from trade and these should be stated. We do welcome the estimated $4 billion in benefits to Australia from the WTO agreement; in particular, the gains to many of our primary producers. However, we do have questions about the price tag on these benefits. This price tag includes both considerable collateral damage and some very real questions about Australia's sovereignty—questions which the coalition has been raising for months with respect to other treaties but it seems to be selectively remaining silent with regard to the WTO agreement.

Let me state quite categorically that the minister is not the only one who has done high school economics. I am quite familiar with Ricardo's model of the gains from trade. Trade analysis did not, however, stop in the 19th century. We have had since then Professor Robert Reich, Professor Hermann Daly, Professor Paul Romer, Susan George, `Nugget' Coombs, Ted Traynor, Ernst Rodeck, John Kain, and many others who have provided critiques of a simplistic acceptance of the neo-classical trade model, each from a somewhat different perspective.

Despite the minister's views to the contrary, it is entirely appropriate that such alternative views are aired in this chamber and are not pushed aside. At a time when the government and the opposition are adopting almost identical ideological stances, it is important for the health of public debate in this country that we do put this other position.

The minister said one other thing on Friday. He argued that the `race to the bottom' was a myth. He cited Burma, Bangladesh, Nepal and Singapore. I say to the minister that he does not need to look to such obscure places to see evidence of the race to the bottom. All the evidence he needs is right here in Australia. The race to the bottom says that unconstrained international competitive pressures will lead to reductions in wages, in working conditions and in environmental standards.

With regard to wages, I suggest to the minister that he should look at the Industry Commission report entitled Impediments to regional industry adjustment. This report looks at the problems faced by some regions in Australia caused by the internationalisation of the Australian economy. What is the solution proposed for the unemployment that has been caused? `Labour market flexibility'—in other words, lower wages. The Industry Commission says that solving unemployment in regional Australia caused by trade deregulation is to have `low wage' regions.

With regard to working conditions, I suggest that the minister should look at a series of articles by Paul Heinrichs in the Age earlier this year. Those articles describe sweatshop working conditions among garment industry outworkers in Melbourne—that is Melbourne, Australia, not Melbourne, Bangladesh. Those conditions arose because garment retailers, facing increased competition from cheap imports based on exploited labour, told their suppliers that they had to supply at lower cost, or else. The only way those suppliers could meet those cost levels was to subcontract the work to immigrant workers working under the most appalling conditions.

With regard to environmental standards, we do not have to look any further than the comments by the then minister for the environment in this chamber earlier this year. In telling us why the government had not moved on implementing measures to achieve Australia's greenhouse commitments, we were told that Australia was not going to do anything which damaged the `international competitiveness' of our industry. So there we have it: pressures to cut wages, appalling working conditions and reduced environmental standards, all directly attributable to trade deregulation.

I would not be so quick to point to the newly industrialising countries as great examples of the benefits of trade deregulation. As Dr Walden Bello pointed out on his recent visit to Australia, Thailand is starting to show the downside of the internationalisation of its economy. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Only 17 per cent of the country remains forested. . . To the crisis of the forests has now been added a crisis of industrial pollution, as waste-water, air quality and industrial safety regulations lie largely unenforced in order to attract foreign investors. The lower reaches of the mighty Chao Phraya River running through Bangkok, on the banks of which thousands of factories are located, are biologically dead. Traffic strangles Bangkok, where 600 new cars hit the road everyday. Workers in electronics factories in one industrial estate are mysteriously dying and many suspect that this is due to poisoning from substances they come into contact with in the work place.

The minister may argue that the gains from trade deregulation outweigh the pain. That is a legitimate position, and he may prove, in the long run, to be right. I hope so, but the simplistic view that there is no race to the bottom flies in the face of too much evidence to be allowed to go unchallenged. I am sure the minister himself would argue that the decision to enter the WTO is a momentous one for Australia. I cannot understand, therefore, why he dismisses serious debate about the issues as obstructionism.

PARA.TAB: The second set of issues I want to raise concerns the price tag of the WTO agreement. I repeat: the Australian Democrats welcome the benefits from the agreement, but the minister comes in here with legislation and tells us, `I am sorry, but to get these benefits you have to pass bills which are going to ruin the lives of hundreds of battling citrus growers, not to mention a few video game and CD rental shops. We are also going to hurt some pork and egg producers, but you don't even get to see any legislation about those people.' In these circumstances, it is legitimate to ask: is this a price we have to pay? Should there be safeguards? Should there be changes? Should there be side agreements on social, economic and environmental issues?

As we all know, our citrus growers are efficient, yet they will be affected by this legislation to the extent that hundreds, possibly thousands, of small citrus growers will have to leave their holdings. I am sure that the minister has concern for those losers. I am sure that his advisers have convinced him that there is nothing we can do for the various losers out of the WTO agreement that is `legal' under the WTO rules, but we are not convinced. The minister cannot expect to bring such legislation in here without questions being asked. Simple fairness demands that someone stands up for the people whose lives are being ruined, and it is a pity that the coalition does not have the guts to do it.

The minister has also been dismissive of our concerns about sovereignty, which are at the heart of this argument. He says that, since we now have the opportunity to vote on these bills, democracy is at work. The way these bills have been brought before us is certainly not a good example of a democratic process at work. No reason has been given for any of these bills except that it is necessary to pass them in order to sign on to the WTO agreement. Was there any domestic policy reason why Australia needed to change its sales tax regime and put growers off their land? Is there a domestic policy reason to change our patent law, our trademarks law, our copyright law and our anti-dumping law? No; all we are told is, `Pass these bills or you will lose $4 billion for Australia.' Some would call that blackmail.

While we welcome the $4 billion, we ask: what effort has been made to change the price that we have to pay? What will happen in the future? Every time our masters at the WTO issue a new instruction, the minister will come rushing in here with a new piece of legislation. Each time we will be told, `Pass these bills or you will lose $4 billion for Australia.' I do not think it is unreasonable for the Senate to baulk at that. If the coalition really believed its own rhetoric about the impact of overseas treaties and Australia's sovereignty, it would also baulk on this bill. All we are asking is that the parliament should have had some say earlier in the process. We do not want our negotiators to agree to things which have important implications for Australia without the parliament being consulted. We do not want to be presented with a fait accompli. We do not want to look at legislation with a gun to our head.

I think the minister should give us a commitment that he will not come in here again with legislation based on international commitments on which the parliament has had no say and tell us, `Pass it or else we'll get kicked out of the WTO.' These are serious issues. If any bills ever deserved more serious consideration, it is these bills. To debate them is not obstructionism; it is democracy at work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lest Senator Spindler's second reading speech in the debate of the committee of the whole be allowed to go unchallenged, I feel it is appropriate to make a few comments about the coalition's commitment to sovereignty and why we are willing to allow this bill to pass. Senator Spindler shows what must be charitably described as a flawed view of the concept of parliamentary sovereignty. The concept of parliamentary sovereignty which concerns the coalition, for very good reasons, is that treaties should not be signed and ratified without first obtaining the approval of parliament.

PARA.TAB: What we have in this process is the government bringing before the parliament legislation to implement the World Trade Organisation agreement. That we do not see as being an abrogation of parliamentary sovereignty. It is one of the few areas of international practice in which I would congratulate the government, because what the government is doing here is bringing before parliament the legislation to implement these agreements. If that did not happen, then we would be concerned. If that did not happen, that would be an abrogation of parliamentary sovereignty.

To address the point made by Senator Margetts the other day when we were debating this bill—and just in explanation to Senator Margetts of our position—whilst we recognise the concerns she has, the important point about this is that the World Trade Organisation is actually an agreement from which any country can choose to withdraw at any time. Mind you, it withdraws at a cost. It is not one of those agreements where we are bound for ever and a day. That is part of the material which the coalition has had to consider in looking at this bill, the agreement and the position on sovereignty. That we do not see this bill as an abrogation of parliamentary sovereignty is the important point.

In relation to Senator Spindler's other points, we certainly do not accept his bald assertion that the coalition is doing nothing for those who are involved in the citrus industry. Senator Spindler full well knows that nobody has been more active in trying to represent the citrus industry than my Senate leader, Senator Boswell, the member for Mallee, Mr Forrest, and other members of the coalition.

For Senator Spindler to come in here, wring his hands and say that the coalition does not have the guts to do anything for the citrus industry really is an affront to my intelligence and an affront to the intelligence of all honourable senators. I do not intend to say anything more, but the bill does need to be passed in a reasonable period of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will resist the temptation to enter into a second reading debate, as it was described. There seems to be a great enthusiasm for attempting to summarise my views and saying that I believe certain things I do not believe, but that is an issue for another day. The amendment that is before us, which has not been the subject of much discussion, is not one that we support, for the reasons that have been outlined in previous debate on similar amendments.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Margetts') be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clauses 9 and 10—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an amendment in the true sense of the word. I will be voting against clauses 9 and 10. Clauses 9 and 10 concern the reversal of the onus of proof. Until now, Australia has followed the principle that someone charged is innocent until proven guilty. The government amendment would reverse that. The defendant is now to be considered guilty until proven innocent.

PARA.TAB: In law the onus of proof is of no consequence in two situations. When a person is clearly and provably guilty, that person is not innocent until proven guilty; he or she will be found guilty anyway. When a person is clearly and provably innocent, the onus of proof does not matter; that person can and will be found innocent. The problem arises when the situation is not clear.

Where there is doubt, what we assume about guilt or innocence makes an immense difference. If we assume innocence, in all doubtful cases that cannot be clarified the defendant must be found innocent. If we assume guilt, in all cases where there is any question of guilt, any shadow of a doubt that the defendant might be guilty, the defendant must be found guilty. Consider that for a moment. Even if the defendant seems, on balance, to be innocent, if a shadow of doubt can be cast, he or she must under law be found guilty. That is what this reversal of onus of proof means.

This makes the things immensely more difficult for anyone challenged under patent law. It becomes almost impossible to defend oneself, because the situation is frequently far from clear. The way patents are being extended to include things that have never been patentable in the past makes things less clear. The United States National Institute of Health patented application on 7,000 pieces of human DNA includes all the unknown genes and unknown gene products. That makes things less clear. The grant of patents to Agracetus—a subsidiary of A.G. Grace—on cotton, peanuts, soybeans and all future developments to these crops makes things less clear. Granting a patent on the genes of a disease makes things less clear because of the implications it has for developing cures for that disease. The difference in real terms between granting patents on human gene lines of DNA and granting patents on people makes things less clear, yet we would drastically extend patent rights.

Let us not be under any illusions. This is a huge extension of patent rights. To reverse the onus of proof is a far bigger extension of monopoly rights than simply changing the period from 16 to 20 years. It will effectively stop many companies from considering working on some problems—specifically, health problems and diseases. Already promising developments for cures to diseases have been abandoned after someone with a gene patent sued. The disease research was not done using the proprietary knowledge of the company suing, yet it could sue. Suits are expensive and time consuming, throwing the viability of the entire program into doubt until they are resolved. Resolution may involve more than one appeal.

Simply put, it is not worth investigating a cure for a disease in such circumstances, since any work done may gain nothing but massive legal bills and the loss of the work itself. Where the onus of proof is reversed, the situation will become almost impossible. It is clear—or should be clear at this moment—that the extension of intellectual property rights under TRIPS has very little to do with ensuring that effort is rewarded; it has to do with control, and that control is more likely to suppress innovation than to encourage it.

It is likely to restrict a technological advance rather than promote it. It is liable to make it so expensive that for many people it can be simply unavailable. This is what is being promoted here—suppression of technology, of innovation, especially in relation to medicine and disease prevention due to the push to patent by biotech companies and the human genome people. It is very sad that Senator Coulter is ill at this stage and is not able to be part of this debate. I know that on a number of occasions Senator Coulter has spoken up strongly about his concerns for these particular issues.

I strongly urge senators to recognise that this tendency towards patent control is frequently neither just nor genuinely good for ecologically sustainable and benign development. The current onus of proof stating that one must be proven guilty is at the heart of our justice system. Do not accede to changing it. If this means going to the World Trade Organisation and fighting it out, so be it.

I would like to point out to honourable senators that if the Democrats support going to a division, in order to save the chamber's time because I know that some people feel this debate is a waste of time—and I think that says more for them than it does for us—then I will also call a division on this bill soon after. The reason I would do such a thing is due to the huge amount of problems remaining in this bill, the mess that has been presented to us to pass quickly and the disgraceful lack of proper consideration that has been taken in looking at these important issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Greens in opposing clauses 9 and 10 on the principle that the onus of proof should not be reversed as well as on the substantive policy issues which the Democrats, as Senator Margetts has acknowledged, have been developing consistently over time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important question for many Australians. On hearing it, they would say, `How would we go about dealing with a matter of reversing the onus of proof in Australia? What a very strange thing to do.' My advice is that what we are doing in this instance is putting into law the existing practice of the Federal Court. There are stringent requirements for establishing what can, for simplification of debate, be called a prima facie case on behalf of the plaintiff. Once that prima facie case is established, the practice at the moment is that the only way in which the case can then proceed is on the basis of the so-called reversal of the onus of proof.

PARA.TAB: It is not unique in this chamber, in circumstances where there is only one party with access to the information necessary to establish a case, that the requirement is placed upon that party. It is not something we should do lightly or often, but it is something which has happened before. It is, I think, worthy of note for those in the chamber who know the procedures in this matter that the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, which is the guardian in this instance, made no comment on the bill. I think that puts some of the concerns in perspective. It is not an issue to be brushed aside lightly but, on balance, it has been developed as the only process for proceeding fairly and it should continue.
Question put:
That clauses 9 and 10 be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That the bill be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

PARA.TAB: After clause 1, page 1, insert the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: "1A.(1) This section commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.

"(2) The provisions of this Act, other than section 1 and this section, are not to take effect before the commencement of an Act which provides that persons representing the Commonwealth in or before the World Trade Organization may not enter into any agreement or arrangement which has or may have the object or effect of altering or overriding any law of the Commonwealth, unless that object or effect or a class of such objects or effects has been approved by a resolution of each House of the Parliament.".

Those concerns came from the Nationals, who seem—strangely enough—not to be here at the moment to participate in the debate. PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The anti-dumping bill does not appear to make major changes. Nevertheless, there is some concern that several of the relatively minor changes are in themselves making it more difficult for industry to have access to the anti-dumping process. The requirement that anti-dumping of countervailing applications must be supported by a major part of the industry concerned could prove difficult in areas where the industry is widely dispersed.

PARA.TAB: The more detailed definitions of dumping, subsidisation and methods for determining the margins of dumping similarly may cause some difficulty. These things—and many others, such as the termination of an investigation into dumping or subsidisation where the value or quantity of dumping is negligible—will require close monitoring as to their effects. But what is negligible? To what extent will that stop Australian companies from taking justified action in this area? We serve notice that the Australian Democrats will very carefully monitor the effect of these provisions and will move amendments next year if required.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because Senator Margetts has to be in another place I will take over from her. I trust my colleagues will be gracious if I do not follow the arguments quite as well as she would. We are presenting four amendments to this bill. Amendment No. 1 has been presented as a matter of routine in relation to the other bills. I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 1, page 1, insert the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: "1A.(1) This section commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.

"(2) The provisions of this Act, other than section 1 and this section, are not to take effect before the commencement of an Act which provides that persons representing the Commonwealth in or before the World Trade Organization may not enter into any agreement or arrangement which has or may have the object or effect of altering or overriding any law of the Commonwealth, unless that object or effect or a class of such objects or effects has been approved by a resolution of each House of the Parliament.".

We do not plan to call a division on amendment No. 1, but I have some general comments to make. My understanding is that we will then proceed to consider amendments Nos. 2 and 4 together. I will seek leave for that at the time. There will be a division called on them and also on amendment No. 3 that the Greens are presenting.

PARA.TAB: The Greens' amendment No. 1 has been moved to each of the bills we have considered in this World Trade Organisation bill debate. I want to raise again the issue of sovereignty in relation to the Customs Legislation (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994. During the debate over the last few days the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) has publicly characterised the Greens as obstructionist for insisting that these eight bills be actually debated.

I recognise that the government and the Liberal Party do not question anything in the bills, no matter what changes may result and no matter who falls victim to those changes. I also acknowledge that the Liberal Party rhetoric on sovereignty does not appear to apply to agreements that will help big transnational corporations and give them more power. The agreements we are making can override federal, state and local laws. They do not seem to care, by the way they have objected to, for example, national treaties. The proposition seems to be that, if it is good for General Motors, Mitsubishi, Daewoo, Unilever, Roche or Royal Dutch Shell, it must be good for Australia. We need to place on the public record that that is not what the Greens (WA) and the Australian Democrats agree with.

The minister insists that there is no problem with sovereignty. He says that Australia can do anything it wants legally and take the consequences. We feel that that choice is about as independent as putting a gun to someone's head and telling them, `Give me all your money or I'll shoot.' We believe it is coercive. That there is some implication of choice is an illusion. We have to accept what is happening and take the consequences. So any choice made with a gun at one's head—whether it is to empty their pockets, give a donation or accept the consequences—is, in our view, a comparative example of the degree of sovereignty we have as we push these bills through this chamber.

The Greens understand that the government and opposition want trade without tariff barriers. If that is the case, there is no problem with our amendment. A resolution from both houses should not be difficult to get on with liberalising trade. Such a resolution would allow our ambassador to pursue that goal without requiring unilateral and pre-emptive dropping of the few trade barriers we have.

There might be problems where an Australian negotiator is strongly pushing for something, like the reversal of the onus of proof we have just discussed in the previous bill or fighting against discrimination, supporting local investment in areas where there is some provision for local control. There might be problems where an Australian ambassador is fighting to prevent the inclusion of environmental regulation of trade or fighting against a social clause. The government may not have a problem there either, but it would have to put that on the table and the opposition would need to support it openly.

We know there is a trade and environment subcommittee to the World Trade Organisation meeting to consider whether the WTO should make any regulations on these issues, but we do not know what position Mr Kenyon or his staff take in this committee. From the minister's periodic statements in the press, I understand that he does not believe the WTO is an appropriate forum for including environmental regulation or for including a social clause looking at labour rights, rights to take action against products of child labour and so on. He believes that these should be handled by the ILO or someone. I believe he has expressed himself quite strongly against these issues being included in the WTO. Does this translate into directions to Mr Kenyon? Does the minister leave Mr Kenyon to his own devices on this issue? Is Mr Kenyon directed to take an opposite view to the one the minister expresses?

The minister claims we are being obstructionist. In the history of the Senate, this must be one of the fastest times for eight important and contentious bills to go from the second reading stage to passage. We may have passed others more quickly, but they certainly did not have the enormous ramifications that these bills have. I am certain that the minister is completely aware that, if the Greens really wanted to be obstructionist, we could use a number of methods at our disposal for delaying the bills. So we take exception to the public remarks that have been made.

This legislation is of vital importance. The fact is that, in relation to the numbers at the moment, whilst there may be what the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) chooses to call an unholy alliance between the Greens and the opposition, I think he would also have to say there is an unholy alliance between the government and the opposition to push through legislation. Even though the Greens and the Democrats do not have the numbers, we still have a right democratically to express our views. We are doing that in relation to each point that arises, and that is an appropriate position. It is not appropriate that bills are being rushed through without these points receiving even the least mention.

We have moved a number of amendments to the bills. They are amendments of substance dealing with actual issues relating to the bills. The more general amendments are the ones we put to each bill to call for some accountability to parliament in a process which can establish regulations to which Australian law must conform or Australia faces the consequences. Putting amendments of substance—amendments, further, which have attracted support of others in this place—is not obstruction. It is responsible parliamentary process. I also note for the record that virtually all our amendments, like our citrus amendment, are World Trade Organisation consistent.

What the minister appears to have problems with is the idea that any discussion or debate at all should occur on these bills. The minister obviously resents having to be physically present in this place. It seems that that resentment means that nobody should question what the government is doing. This is hidden under the rhetorical device of attacks on the person, ad hominem attacks, stating that any question is a sign of self-righteous people who think they have cornered the market on wisdom. We are presenting a legitimate point of view—one which, sadly, is not receiving the attention and the debate across the chamber that it deserves.

The National Party and the opposition have been silent on some of these very legitimate questions that they themselves must be concerned about. Also, I am sure there are members in the government who feel that, if they had the capacity to speak out rather than being put into the usual bloc vote and bloc response to the legislation, they would want some of these matters debated and the implications of them drawn out a little more seriously by the government rather than simply by the minor parties.

These bills are getting minimal attention. The ANL and sports grants get more attention than our joining the World Trade Organisation, which, as the minister says, is one of the most significant steps Australia has ever taken. It is not a considered step. It may have been considered by the ministry and by cabinet, but there has been no broad public consideration and no parliamentary consideration worthy of the name. This is it; this is the whole debate on the World Trade Organisation in the context of these bills—Thursday evening and Monday morning—not an excessive amount of time and not obstructionism.

Other countries have indicated the serious concern within their population about the passage of these bills. I think Australia is doing a disservice to its community for not registering the same kinds of concerns about the implications. It implies that none of the unintended consequences that may result from these bills are of any concern or import, not only to the government but also to the opposition in the Liberal Party dimension. The only value I can imagine the government is getting from such calls is by saying we are making cheap political points. But I think the government must accept that it is not possible for members in this chamber to be silent and simply let these bills go through without comment.

I make the point again today that there is little accountability of the ambassador or the minister in an activity which may result in Australia's having to change its laws or face the consequences. I know there is already a lot of pressure to pass these bills without giving them due consideration. We have already heard statements from some here that they do not like what is being done but will vote to pass it because they must for the sake of the WTO. I have excluded the National Party from my earlier comments about unqualified support, because I believe the Nationals would have supported some amendments that have been put had there not been the pressure of the coalition party room and the pressure to pass these bills for the sake of the WTO in any case.

I feel there is some lack of information because some amendments, including Senator Spindler's second amendment to the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill, were clearly WTO consistent, yet for fear that they were not the Nationals have apparently not supported them. I here give the committee another opportunity to call for some accountability of the ambassador to the World Trade Organisation. I ask my colleagues to consider realistically exactly what issues would not receive joint house support and consider whether those are the issues that they wish no input into. As I said, the acceptance of this amendment will be depend on the voices, but the Greens express very strongly our desire that this amendment be accepted as a way of increasing the accountability of any Commonwealth representative in or before the WTO.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2Clause, 7, page 7, after paragraph (d), insert the following paragraph:
"(da) by omitting subsection (4A) and substituting the following subsection:

`(4A) Where, in relation to goods of a particular kind first referred to in subsection (4), the like goods referred to in that subsection are close processed agricultural goods, then, despite subsection (4), the industry in respect of those close processed agricultural goods consists either of the person or persons producing the processed goods or of the person or persons producing the raw agricultural goods from which the processed goods are derived.'.".
4Clause 15, page 21, before paragraph (a), insert the following paragraph:
"(aa)by omitting paragraph (1)(b) and substituting the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: `(b)there is, or may be established, an Australian industry:

TAB.TAB: (ii)producing components or inputs to like goods; and';".

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to be a serious problem in the current legislation which the Senate attempted to remedy before; that is, there is no direct access to anti-dumping procedures by producers, the growers, whose goods are included as the basis for food products. As I understand it and as was explained in the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, which looked at these bills, the growers of something like tomatoes need to go to a producer of the food product, tomato sauce or paste, and get that producer to take up an anti-dumping case. This amendment is designed to ensure direct access to anti-dumping by growers whose produce goes into a product that is dumped.

PARA.TAB: The issue at stake is that many growers feel that their industry is endangered because of dumping, but for the producers of the food product to take up the issue might mean that they would have to complain against the retailer who is also their customer and who is also the importer. What we see here is a consequence of the concentration of power. The value for corporations appears to be increasingly shifting to marketing. Those who control the wholesaling and retailing operations exercise effective control. They set prices both to the consumer and to the producer. Increasingly, companies are doing what Pacific Dunlop has done. It has shed its canning operations and played two or three canneries off against each other. Pacific Dunlop can then effectively use its marketing position and identity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the chamber for long but there are issues that have not been debated before, so I will respond to those quickly. They were substantially dealt with in the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, so I will not duplicate their consideration. Some of the amendments might have an impact contrary to their intention. Amendment No. 2, in particular, would limit injury analysis in an investigation to either farmers or producers and would exclude a consideration of injury to them both. I am sure that is not the intent, but it may well be what it would do at the moment.

PARA.TAB: With regard to amendment No. 4, it seems very difficult to see how we can justify an anti-dumping measure in the circumstance where someone may be contemplating the production of an input or component that is against an industry that does not exist. They do seem to me to be difficult propositions to sustain. The amendments fall on that basis.

On the more general point of whether there is merit in the proposals as put forward, the concern seems particularly to lie with whether our primary producers will be well treated. I am advised that the National Farmers Federation has had consultations with the Australian Customs Service on these issues. I understand that it is satisfied with the situation that has been outlined.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3After clause 8, page 10, insert the following clause:
"8A. The Principal Act is amended by inserting the following word and paragraph after paragraph 269TAA(1)(c):

";or (d)in the opinion of the Minister a nominal price assigned to a good transferred internationally within a company, or between branches, subsidiaries or associated companies, or to an associate of the buyer, will, directly or indirectly, result in reimbursement, compensation, or other benefit to, the importer in such a way that a subsidy or transfer pricing arrangement works to avoid taxation or anti-dumping provisions.".

I foreshadow for the benefit of the chamber that we will be calling for a division at the end of the debate on this amendment. We will also be calling for a division on the question that the bill be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: This amendment is designed to reduce the possibility of transfer pricing and to address the problem of price setting by a company importing to a branch, a parent company, a subsidiary or an associated company. Such price setting in respect of what are, in effect, internal transfers seems to be difficult to address within the existing legislation. It also may pose a problem for anti-dumping legislation unless it is explicitly considered.

When speaking to a previous Greens' amendment, the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) suggested that it would be difficult to incorporate something. Some kind of recognition by the minister that there are problems would be welcome. We believe that there is a need for explicit consideration.

Australia may not have had too many problems so far with this sort of thing but it has already appeared as an issue in North America. Companies such as Safeway, a dominant supermarket chain, have moved to integrate production and produce vegetables on its own farms in Mexico. This is used to put pressure on United States producers. Safeway, in producing for itself, importing and then going all the way to retail sales, can take advantage of cheap Mexican labour while assigning any price it wishes to imported goods. This allows an abundant field for manipulation in relation to taxes and would allow an effective circumvention of anti-dumping provisions. It is for that reason that we have moved this amendment. I would welcome comments from the minister as to whether there are some good reasons why this amendment should not be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with the amendment is not that it seeks to deal with transfer pricing—an issue that we also need to address with regard to tax legislation. What is already in the act is, in our view, more effective than this amendment in achieving this purpose. I am told that the intent of the amendment is already incorporated in sections 269TAA and 269TAB of the act. I have to confess that I have not read either, but I am sure everybody else in the chamber has so they will make up for me.

PARA.TAB: Those sections allow for an invoice price to be disregarded if it is not considered to represent the true price of the goods. This is a more comprehensive way of dealing with the problem. The Greens are trying to deal with a couple of sub-parts of it; we are trying, through the legislation, to deal with the whole issue. Transfer pricing is a proper issue to focus on. At the moment, it is the government's view that we have it adequately covered in the legislation and the amendment does not add anything to what is already in the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) and I are probably both labouring under the same problem of not fully understanding the clause. What will the government's approach be to any unintended consequences if the legislation does not fully cover the particular aspect that this amendment deals with and the other aspects that have been raised? What is the procedural response that the government is prepared to make in that regard?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I understand her correctly, Senator Chamarette is asking: if we find that our comprehensive measure does not adequately cover the matters, are we free to deal with issues concerning transfer pricing, or is there something, like the WTO, which constrains our capacity? We are not constrained in our capacity to deal with transfer pricing. We think it is adequately covered and, if it is not, we will make sure it is.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Question put:
That the bill be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: COPYRIGHT (WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 1, page 1, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: ``1A.(1) This section commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.

``(2) The provisions of this Act, other than section 1 and this section, are not to take effect before the commencement of an Act which provides that persons representing the Commonwealth in or before the World Trade Organization may not enter into any agreement or arrangement which has or may have the object or effect of altering or overriding any law of the Commonwealth, unless that object or effect or a class of such objects or effects has been approved by a resolution of each House of the Parliament.''.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of the accountability of the World Trade Organisation ambassador, I raise the entire issue of computer software. The granting of copyright on computer programs, in spite of what has been done, is a very strange and contentious area.

PARA.TAB: In many respects, computer programs follow a pattern that is more typical of industrial innovations rather than literary works, although some exceptions may be made for games. However, a program is really more of a tool. It generally has a short lifespan. Arguments about the look and feel of the program are more akin to product design than literature, since no playwrights or authors of whom I know have ever accused another of imitating their emotional tone, theoretical set or typeface and layout of their play or book. It is also highly questionable whether there is any point in providing a copyright with 50 years of control for a computer program. Computer programs tend to have a far shorter lifespan than that.

I believe that some unresolved issues relating to the treatment of computer software will become more difficult as time goes by. I believe that the parliament should re-examine intellectual property in relation to software and use the results as a basis for our negotiators.

Many areas are involved. It is no accident that this is one area where corporations, and the United States particularly, has jumped in and called for changes in copyright legislation. At this moment today—perhaps it has just passed—the journalists in the Parliament House press gallery are discussing the impact of the changes in copyright legislation. It is amazing and tragic that, whilst they and many people have refused to give these issues the coverage they deserve, they are today—the day the changes are trying to be pushed through with undue haste—talking about the implications for them. However, we will move this amendment for each bill. I commend it to the house.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1Clause 3, page 2, proposed paragraph 30A(1)(a), line 37, omit "it will or may be returned", substitute "it will be returned".
2Clause 3, page 3, proposed paragraph 30A(2)(a), lines 11 and 12, omit "it will or may be returned", substitute "it will be returned".

The problem with the bill as it stands is that previously legitimate business operators involved in CD rentals will be driven out of business. The amendments attempt to delete the words `or may' from paragraphs (1)(a) and (2)(a) of proposed new section 30A of the act. In substance they attempt to weaken the sale and buyback prohibition of the bill. The new section 30A, to be inserted by clause 3 of the bill, defines commercial rental arrangement as an arrangement under which a copy of the sound recording or computer program is made available either on terms that it will or may be returned in the course of the conduct of a business and for payment or as part of a service for which payment is to be made.

PARA.TAB: The government is attempting by its provisions to capture sale and buyback procedures through the bill. If you cannot rent a CD to someone for $1 for one night you enter into an agreement to sell it to that person for $10 today if he agrees to sell it back for $9 tomorrow. I understand that this is a fair prohibition. However, it is another thing to stop totally a general offer to buy back which would catch in effect all second-hand transactions. We believe that by deleting the `or may' we are arguing that an arrangement is only a rental arrangement if there is an obligation on the part of the purchaser to return it. Otherwise, as I have said, any second-hand dealer who buys and sells would be caught by the legislation. Given that conversion into second-hand stores may be the only option for CD rental operators being driven out of business as a result of this bill, we believe that the deletion of `or may' is important for them.

I recall the minister actually evincing some sympathy for the argument that rental of CDs should continue to be available. The arguments were that it was not possible; that under the GATT provisions seeing that we have not made any arrangements prior to this legislation and prior to our agreeing to the WTO agreement we cannot help CD rental operators or consumers. That is probably the most important argument—that we are closing an avenue for consumers to obtain CDs on a rental basis. However, it would be appropriate, in view of the in-principle stance taken by the minister, to leave open this possibility, which will enable people to continue to obtain compact discs on a rental basis. We do support the right of performers to get just rewards for dealings in their work but, by not making provision for such a scheme prior to our agreeing to the GATT provisions, the government has unfortunately closed off that option.

Nevertheless, we need to be conscious of the fact that there are 400 businesses across Australia which rent out compact discs. Granting to the copyright owning companies an exclusive right to enter into commercial rental agreements will make the activities of these businesses illegal unless the companies holding the copyright agree to such an arrangement. However, we have on record the developments overseas that, wherever this has happened, the rental operations have not been agreed to by the copyright owning companies. I believe that the government, in acceding to these two amendments, will have an opportunity to enable the rental operators in substance to continue and to enable consumers to continue to take advantage of these arrangements if they cannot afford to buy CDs at the ruling high prices. I commend the amendments to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major purpose of the Copyright (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994 seems to be to eliminate the rental music and computer software industry. However, it goes well beyond that. I have pleasure in supporting Senator Spindler's amendments. People may note that they have the same wording as do our amendments Nos 2 and 3, so we obviously both feel strongly about this issue.

PARA.TAB: The amendments the government wants define a commercial rental arrangement as any situation where an item `is made available by a person on terms that it will or may be returned by a person'. By inserting the phrase `or may' into this legislation, it steps beyond something that is a rental agency to cover even second-hand stores. How many second-hand stores or pawnshops have old tapes and records for sale? Most of the ones I have seen do. Even many flea market stalls have such things for sale. They will sell people records. They may buy them back at some time in the future. They are in business—they buy and sell—but they are not in the business of renting records.

Yet this legislation would declare this to be a rental arrangement unless these businesses make explicit provision never to repurchase a recording or program. How could this be policed? It is ludicrous. It is poorly thought out and poorly drafted legislation. Perhaps it is a mistake brought on by a government anxious to give industry 150 per cent protection, but it is overkill. As a consequence, we will support those amendments of Senator Spindler which are the same as our amendments Nos 2 and 3 to ensure that incidental possibility of repurchase is not covered in the definition. There is no reason for it.

We believe that the legislation is sufficiently clear to allow companies that operate a commercial sell and re-purchase business to define that operation as a rental arrangement for the purpose of the act. `However the arrangement is expressed'—that is the quote from the bill—seems strong enough for me. Proposed new subsection 30A(4) appears to make it clear that such sell and re-purchase can be interpreted as rental. So why is the government so anxious to pursue this? It is very difficult to know. Perhaps the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) could answer us this.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of substance in the debate backwards and forwards about this. It is substantially all on the record as a result of the committee discussions at which these issues were pursued. Rather than take the time of the committee reiterating it, I refer those interested to the Hansard of those proceedings.

PARA.TAB: The key problem for the government with this proposal is that it amounts to a circumvention of that with which we have agreed. On the face of it, that sounds pretty clever—here is a way we can get around an agreement we have entered into. But most importantly we are pursuing, bilaterally and through the Cairns Group, to prevent people who have been dragged screaming into an agreement about agriculture—which is overwhelmingly in Australia's interest and, I think, also in the global interest—coming up with proposals which circumvent the intention of the agree ment.

It does not seem to me to be either proper to be seeking so to do, or very smart, when what it does is arm those who would wish to take action to circumvent the agreements which we, as a result of our efforts with others, have gained and which we wish to see enforced. That is the core problem. But there has been ample discussion. I acknowledge that Senator Spindler has pursued the matter consistently. Rather than reiterate the argument, I simply refer people to the relevant discussion that took place at the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has claimed, I do not think very convincingly, that it has been involved in consultation with industries which will be affected by these changes—these amendments and this legislation. Does the government know how many people may be, in the future, breaking the law as a result of these changes—those people who are involved with second-hand shops and flea markets? Has that industry in any way been advised of the changes?

—I think there has been substantial consultation with those who will be affected. We do not consider that people pursuing bona fide second-hand or, as Senator Margetts called it, flea market activity, will be affected when the legislation is read in its proper context. They have not been consulted because we do not think they will be affected but we have certainly consulted those who we think will be affected.
—On what legal basis does the deletion of the words `or may' provide an avenue for circumvention of the treaty?

—I am not sure that I can start giving QCs opinions here but it seems to me to be both intent and outcome—it facilitates measures which will get around the conscious intention of the agreement into which we entered. If it does not, it is of no value. It is only of value if it does have that purpose. I think it is quite straightforward. To be fair to them, those in the industry who have seen this as a possible source of redress are quite conscious of the fact that that is exactly what they are trying to do—circumvent the intent of the agreement. If it does not circumvent the intent of the agreement, it is of no value.

—Like the minister, I do not want a re-run of the debate that we had at the committee stage but a couple of questions remain. As I said before, the minister said during the committee stage that he was not unsympathetic to the problem of rental stores being put out of business and, more particularly, consumers being prevented from taking that particular avenue. He was asked whether he would consider incentives. What term of the agreement that he has made—he seems to be saying in the spirit of the agreement or undertakings the government has made—would prevent the government from leaving the possibility of rental being continued? The other question is: would the government be open to an amendment which gave copyright owners an incentive by, say, making the income from rental royalties tax free?

—I am not sure that I understood Senator Spindler's first question. Within the foreseeable future, I do not see us entering into agreements that would allow this rental to take place without the consent of the owner of the intellectual property, any more than one can rent something that belongs to someone else, in the physical property sense. Obviously, one cannot, and this is an extension of that principle.
