PARA.TAB: With regard to incentives, during the committee consideration of the legislation Senator Spindler asked whether I would look at a proposal that might provide some incentive to copyright owners to agree to rental. I said then that if he wants to put up a proposal I would look at it. He would know from our past debates on other matters that I am not sympathetic to fiddling with the tax system. I have a general view that income is income, and people ought to pay tax on it however they get it. So I do not think that is a valid proposal. If, over time, someone comes forward with a proposal that operates as some sort of incentive, I remain prepared to look at it. But I do not think that is where we should start.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment allows incidental resale where there is no intention of repurchase. The measures for ensuring sale and repurchase are covered explicitly. If, over time, those people who once again find themselves in a situation of collateral damage in this particular move come to the Greens and Democrats, do I take it that the minister is interested in thinking about an amendment to the legislation at a future date that might help them out if this legislation has unintended consequences?

—I do not know whether that follows from what I said. But, if in any piece of government legislation there are consequences other than those that were intended, it is always appropriate that one looks to see whether it was avoidable and, if so, what can be done to avert it in future. As to whether that will arise on this occasion, let us cross that bridge when we come to it. But I do not rule out looking at anything that the parliament passes. If we pass something which has one intention and it achieves another—conservatives will always argue that that is inevitably so; that is not my view, but I accept that it sometimes happens—we will look at it. I do not want to make a specific commitment that is particular to this bill. Let us just see what unfolds. But as a general principle of public policy, it is not a bad principle.
—Because these two amendments are also contained in the bracket of amendments that Senator Margetts will be moving, I will not be calling for a division on them.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4Clause 3, page 3, at end of proposed section 30A, add the following subsections:

PARA.TAB: "`(5) To avoid doubt it is declared that a lending arrangement in a public lending library or an educational institution is not to be regarded as a commercial rental arrangement for the purposes of subsection (1) or (2).

SPEECH.PARA: "`(6) It is not the intention of the Parliament that a non-conditional used good resale arrangement in respect of a copy of a sound recording or computer program should be regarded as a commercial rental arrangement for the purposes of subsection (1) or (2).

PARA.TAB: "`(7) An arrangement is to be regarded as a non-conditional used good resale arrangement if:

TAB.TAB: (a)it provides for the sale of a used good by a person to another person with no requirement or expectation for repurchase of the good by the second person; or

(b)it provides for the sale of a used good to or by a person in the ordinary course of a business whose primary purpose is the purchase and resale of used goods with no requirement or expectation for the repurchase of those goods.".

SPEECH.PARA: The government's anxiety to push copyright protection as far as possible has led us to what we feel is some uncertainty, and that is what we are trying to clear up in this amendment. Proposed subsection 5 is put forward explicitly to ensure that public libraries and educational institutions are not considered commercial rental institutions. We believe it is important to put that beyond doubt. This should never be a threat to such institutions freely buying and lending recordings.

PARA.TAB: Proposed subsections 6 and 7 assure that the purchase and resale of goods by second-hand shops are specifically protected. The amendment defines non-conditional resale as a sale of a used good without any expectation that it will be repurchased. It may be repurchased, but there is no condition set up to attempt to assure repurchase. Without this, it is impossible that a person could buy a used record and sell to another used record shop. But, if she or he resold to the record shop from which the person bought the record, that shop might be considered a rental shop.

We believe that shops that are buying and reselling on an arms-length basis should not be penalised even where people come back to the same shop. But this right is eroded. It is a short step to acting to close down used book shops and antiquarian book sellers. This amendment will protect those who currently operate used recording shops and rare recording shops. There are a number of these. They are not the same as rental shops, and no confusion should be allowed to exist.

It is not understandable why government would insist on pushing for greater and greater extension of the power of recording companies. These are highly concentrated industries represented by a handful of global marketers. It is little reason to extend their rights in such a way that the only means of access a person can have is through purchase.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to the release today of the names of the six participants in the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research 1995 national outlook conference who were disinvited as a result of the minister's intervention in the conference plans after they were finalised. I ask: why did he wait until this time to intervene? Is it not the fact that two of the speakers were simply replaced on the agenda by people likely to be less critical of the government and the department's policies, and that among the four other disinvited participants were prominent critics of the government's asylum seeker and detention policies? Finally, is this not just another example of this minister's intolerance of differences of opinion or criticism?

—I say at the outset that Senator Short should know better than to ask this question. On Friday he participated in the Senate estimates committee where it was made very clear in evidence that the director of the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research came to me with his staff and basically said, `You're the minister. We're going to consult with you in the program. We are part of your department. We want your advice on the program and on personnel to be part of the program.' That is the starting point. They recognised the relationship between me and them. They came to me for advice. I was invited to give input as to the program and participants. We had a healthy discussion and we had an agreement. They understood particularly the points I was making. Through that flowed continual discussions in the course of a normal relationship between a minister and his or her department. That is the basic starting point.

PARA.TAB: They came to me. I did not bring them in out of the blue further down the track. They came to me and asked for advice and that is what they got; and, in the way that these conferences are organised, they went to other people for advice as well. They went to Senator Short. That is point No. 1. They came to me. Senator Short knows that and it is very disingenuous of him to come in here and forget all of that background and make that assertion of interference out of the dark. They came to me as their minister—they recognised the responsibility—and we discussed the program. As a consequence, there were changes made to the program, to its structure and to the personnel. That also came out last week, but it came out in the context of the responsibility of the minister and parts of my department.

The second part of the criticism—which is quite strange—is that I intervened to take off the program critics of the government. What a joke that is! We see that Senator Short appears three times in the program: chairing a panel on the government's migration program; participating in a panel on the make-up of Australian society; and, further, participating in a panel on future population growth and flows into Australia—full participation. Some people may not think Senator Short is a critic because maybe they have not seen him around the place. But the reality is that he is there, Alexander Downer is there, Judith Moylan is there and Tim Fischer is there. All aspects of the political spectrum are involved and there was absolutely no discussion as to whether they should or should not be.

Secondly, in terms of asylum seekers and other aspects of the program, when we look at the program, we see that there are at least four or five people in it who are critics of the government's agenda and initiatives on and in respect to asylum seekers in this country. Reverend Ian George, for instance, has been a strident critic and was at the last bureau conference. It is a matter of working with the departments to balance a program, and that is what we have done here.

People can look at this program and they can make criticisms of it from all perspectives, but the reality is that whether it is the economic perspective, the humanitarian perspective, the asylum seekers perspective or otherwise, there is a balance in this program—a program that has been developed in consultation. Senator Short cannot throw allegations of interference around when he is such a major player in the conference and when his party is such a major participant. Critics of the government's agenda, apart from—and Senator Harradine was right in respect to this—the population aspect, where I had absolutely no participation, are there; people such as Jennifer Goldie and Australians for Ecologically Sustainable Development are there. There is a broad spectrum. It is just that Senator Short's coterie of mates from Melbourne are not participating and that is really bad luck for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that absolutely and totally misleading answer, which he knows is totally and absolutely misleading, and I ask: did not the minister's office, on his own orders, initiate the six cancellations of previously invited and accepted participants—from the minister's own office and on the minister's own orders? Does the minister agree with the secretary to his department, speaking to the Senate estimates committee last Friday, that the bureau is not `independent' but, rather, is now part of the overall operations of the department? And, as a consequence, does the minister accept Dr Birrell's contention that the bureau has now become a `tool of the minister'? I would add that this is another classic example of the minister really prostituting the proper processes of government administration and corrupting them.

—For my first 12 months in this portfolio I was criticised by Senator Short for not getting involved and for having a department that, as he said consistently, there should be an inquiry into. What happened here, and what Mr Conybeare said quite rightly on Friday, is that, from the start, the bureau has been part of the departmental structure. There is accountability. The head of the bureau is accountable to the secretary to the department. That has been there from the start.
—It is supposed to be an independent body.

—Senator Short is the one who is misleading, when he comes in here and asks, out of the blue, `Did your office make a phone call?' Of course it did; that came out in evidence. But what also came out in evidence was that the bureau came to me seeking advice and in that consultative process we worked out together who would and who should not.
—What? After the question had been raised?
—As part of the process, you lunatic. I withdraw that.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister cannot refer to an honourable senator in such terms, and he should withdraw it.

—I did. The point I make, Mr President, is that right from the start the bureau recognised the chain of accountability. It had discussions with the department—that came out on Friday—and it had discussions with me. It sought them. It is very disingenuous and misleading of Senator Short to be throwing allegations of political interference around like confetti. That is all he is doing.(Time expired)

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of the legal committee from the Zimbabwe parliament, led by the chairman of the committee, Mr Lot Senda. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I address my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in his capacity as the minister responsible for electricity reform. The Senate would be aware that the government set aside $100 million in the One Nation statement for upgrading the electricity grid interconnections between the states as a key component in creating a truly national electricity grid. Can the minister advise the Senate of progress towards the national electricity grid, particularly in regard to the Eastlink proposal between New South Wales and Queensland?

—I thank Senator West for this question on an issue of significant national importance. The creation of a national electricity grid is central to the electricity reform process that this government began and which was, I might add, enthusiastically endorsed by the state premiers on a number of occasions through the COAG process.

PARA.TAB: Senator West has reminded the Senate that Commonwealth support for the national grid has been clearly demonstrated by the allocation of $100 million through the One Nation statement. In the past, I must say, a national grid seemed to present difficulties for some state governments as distinct from arrangements with interstate road and communication links that have long been a fact of life. This is why the December 1993 memorandum of understanding between the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Queensland to examine the grid connection between those states, which is known as Eastlink, was of such critical importance.

The attractions of the link are predicated on the fact that New South Wales has excess generating capacity, and Queensland will soon need to expand its capacity. A link will mean the deferral of new power stations, the sharing of power reserves, the possibility of lower electricity prices, strengthening the reliability of supply, and keeping pressure on the price of gas.

Now, almost a year to the day since the MOU was signed, the link is under public threat. The Senate may be aware that New South Wales has threatened to withdraw from Eastlink unless Queensland agrees to participate in it by the 20th of this month. I am extremely concerned about this threat. I have spoken a number of times over the past week or so with the responsible ministers in both states seeking an accommodation between them that is not caught up in the current overheated atmosphere of an election campaign in New South Wales.

Both New South Wales and Queensland have made significant strides to implementing electricity reform and, more generally, are committed to the introduction of a competitive electricity market from 1 July next year. I firmly believe that the three governments should honour their commitments to examine Eastlink objectively. I welcome the recent comments by the Queensland Minister for Minerals and Energy, Tony McGrady, that Eastlink `would be a reality' and that there was `not one reason why Eastlink should not go ahead'. I also have no doubt about the willingness of the New South Wales government to pursue electricity reform. I am confident that the link will go ahead subject to community consultations and environmental evaluations that are important to the link. The Commonwealth will continue to pursue with the relevant state governments the objective of a national grid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I failed to draw attention to another very distinguished person in the President's gallery, a former President of the Senate, Sir Harold Young. I welcome him back.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is it true that the incoming Defence trade commissioner to Jakarta, Mr John Sayffer, has had his security clearance knocked back? If so, on what grounds was the clearance knocked back? If this is correct, how has this impacted upon the operation of the Defence trade commission office? Is there any link between this and the Fluitman affair, which was examined in Senate estimates recently?

—I will check on the current status of the security clearance. It was unresolved the last time I looked at it, but that was some time ago. As to the second part of Senate Newman's question—is that linked in any way to Mr Fluitman and his contract with the department?—I do not believe so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. A year after the child-care accreditation guidelines passed through this place, can the minister tell the Senate how many centres are participating in the quality improvement and accreditation system?

—I thank Senator Neal for that question. I am delighted to tell the Senate that something like 86 per cent of all child-care centres—private, community based and employer based—are now registered and participating in the accreditation process; that means around 2,800 of the 3,300 centres in Australia. It is very good news indeed for those who are following and concerned about the introduction of accreditation. Today I was able to announce the first 13 centres that have been accredited. They included private child-care centres, community based child-care centres and employer sponsored child-care centres. That is also very good news for an emerging unity of purpose amongst child-care operators. The recognition that all those centres from all parts of the long day care sector are part of the accreditation is very good news indeed.

PARA.TAB: Child care is now employing around 70,000 people. That number is only set to grow. It is very useful that we have this unity of purpose. It is also very important in terms of the promise by this government of affordable, accessible and quality care. It is interesting, in the light of interjections from some opposite, that it is an unnecessary process, that that is not what the private centres, the community based centres and the employer centres are saying.

With 13 accredited centres, not only can we tell centres which are still going through the process—or wondering about it—to ring the National Accreditation Council; we can also refer them to other centres which have finished the accreditation process and which want to speak so highly of it. The report from all those centres is that the process has been a real plus. It has been a very big success for the staff—they have enjoyed the process—and for parents, who have not only learnt in the course of the process but have said that it contributes to increasing their parenting skills. So the news all round is very good.

Today, in announcing the first 13 accreditation centres, we were entertained by children from the Peter Pan child-care centre in the ACT. It is very interesting to note that there is absolutely no substance to the appalling stories about accreditation which were circulating 12 months ago. Boys are still little boys; girls are still little girls. They were enjoying Christmas carols, as most centres are this year.

We also recognise with the accreditation process that multicultural Australia provides for our children music from a whole variety of backgrounds and includes Christmas carols. That is also very important to note when we are looking at multicultural Australia because, as one child-care group in Victoria said, child care provides the `perfect opportunity to include all children right from the start so that no one separate group exists and no-one has to be brought in from the cold'. Multicultural Australia starts with our children. It is reinforced by the accreditation process.
This is a very good news day for the first ever national accreditation system. As far as we can tell, it is the first in the world, and Australia has it. It is doing our child care proud.

In closing, I would particularly like to thank the departmental officers who have assisted, Quentin Bryce as chair of the council and the other council members. They have had the carriage of a very successful outcome in the face of what was 12 months ago a very difficult time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, relates to the actions of the Prime Minister when he was Treasurer in 1990 and approved the sale of 17 per cent of Elders IXL to the Japanese Asahi Brewery Group. My question concerns the timing of the withdrawal of a defamation case against Mr Keating and the further approval of the sale 24 hours later, which Mr Elliott now describes as `a series of coincidences'. I ask: on what date did Mr Elliott first discuss the possible sale with Mr Keating? Were any commitments given? On what date was FIRB advice sought? On what date was this advice given to the Treasurer? On what date was the sale finally approved by the Treasurer?

—I have no detailed information on the particular dates that Senator Kernot asks about, but I can say this: there was no link between the approval in 1990 of Asahi's purchase of Elders IXL shares and the dropping of the defamation action brought by Mr Elliott against the then Treasurer Mr Keating. Any suggestion of a link is malicious nonsense. The matter should rest with Mr Elliott's own reported description of the events, as a series of coincidences. As a former federal president of the Liberal Party of Australia, one would have expected Mr Elliott to have made such an allegation long before now if he believed there was anything remotely improper about the approval of the Asahi deal.
—Will you produce the dates?

—The only people who have tried to make more of this for their own purposes are the journalist Terry McCrann and, of course, Senator Alston. This is exactly the kind of sleazy innuendo that one would expect from Senator Alston. It is not what I would expect from Senator Kernot, not even on her birthday.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I accept the minister's claim that there is no link, but I ask: is there any problem, then, in having the dates, so that we can test the veracity of what Mr Elliott is claiming?
—I will ask the Prime Minister whether he wants to give any further response on this matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Given that a great many nations have been able to market their science and technology capacity internationally over the years through examples such as the Hanover Fair in Europe, I ask the minister whether he is able to inform the Senate as to the Australian policy regarding the promotion to the rest of the world of our science and technology capacity. How would the minister characterise the Australian effort in this regard?
—You cut CSIRO's budget.
—I did not.
—You did that over three years.
—No; why does not Senator Hill add up for a change. If he learned simple arithmetic, he would do a lot better. He should not start trespassing into fields that he does not know anything about.

PARA.TAB: The government is very concerned to promote Australia as the premier location in Asia and the Pacific for science and technology and research and development, and to do so in partnership with the private sector. Therefore, on Friday of last week I was very pleased, in association with the Victorian government and the private sector of Australia, to take part in the launching of a new project called BEST. The title BEST is an acronym which stands for Best Engineering Science and Technology. It is a joint initiative involving the Commonwealth government, especially through the CSIRO, the Victorian government, industry and universities, to showcase Australian science.

The aim of BEST is to become the Hanover Fair, as Senator Loosley referred to, of the Asia-Pacific region. Mr John Ralph, AO, former chief executive officer of the CRA and the past president of the Business Council of Australia and former senator the honourable John Button have both agreed to act respectively as chairman and vice chairman of the board of governors of the association which will run BEST. The inaugural BEST showcase will be in Melbourne in the year 1996.

International conferences under this heading, which are called by BEST as pillars, are aimed at attracting international audiences. A showcase exhibition of technological breakthroughs will be mounted and new products will be fed off those events.

BEST already has strong support from a whole range of institutions and important figures in the private sector. It will be structured along sectorial lines so it can be marketed in a highly targeted way. The initial sectors that have been chosen are those in which Australia has both leading edge research and strong industrial participation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, would you cease that prattle!

—For example, support has already been obtained for events in the agribusiness area through the Australian Institute of Agricultural Science with private backing, the automotive industry through the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers and pharmaceuticals through the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. Support has also been obtained from the mining industry, the chemical industry and the information and communication technology areas as well.

PARA.TAB: There will be ancillary events which will go to promoting this whole thing, including an event organised by the CSIRO with the universities in Australia called BEST through the universities and the CSIRO. That involves the universities of Melbourne, Monash, La Trobe and Deakin, the Australian Institute of Engineers and the Victorian government. It will, as Senator Loosley asked in his question, provide a seminal point for which Australia's excellence in research, science and technology and innovation can be showcased in a partnership way between government, state and federal, and the private sector of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the totally discredited Minister for Transport. Last Saturday at Leichhardt Oval 10,000 people demanded that the government re-open the east-west runway. When is the government going to start listening to them? What is it going to do to avoid the massive civil unrest for which it will be responsible when these 10,000 people and their friends blockade Kingsford-Smith Airport?

—For everyone with an interest in this debate, last week in the Senate Senator Parer invented a brand new opposition policy that did not exist before last week and that is, to quote him, I think in approximately accurate terms—
—Oh, answer the question.
—Shut up!
—Order! There is no need for that level of language.
—If Neanderthal man will just be quite for a minute I will try to answer his colleague's question.
—Mr President—
—Order! I have already made the point, Senator Alston, but those opposite are not making it any easier with constant interjections.
—That new policy expressed by Senator Parer was that the opposition had always supported the third runway—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Has Senator Collins been asked to withdraw that remark? If not, I suggest that you ask him to withdraw it.
—I simply made the point that it was not necessary. It is not unparliamentary but it is not necessary and it is not proper.
—I withdraw, Mr President. That new policy was that the opposition—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on relevance. I asked Senator Collins a very simple question about 10,000 people demanding the opening of the east-west runway and he is making up some story about us reinventing policy. It has no relevance whatsoever to my question.
—It is a bit early for me to judge that, but I hope the minister will get to the question.

—The question I am referring to, on the policy shift of the opposition, is on the east-west runway. The policy, according to Senator Parer, was that the opposition always supported the second parallel runway but not by taking the east-west runway out of service. That, of course, is a public nonsense. The east-west runway will continue to remain—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It must be clear to the Senate that what the minister is doing is debating the issue. That is not legitimate within question time. He has been asked a question as to what plans the government has in place as a result of the government's mess up on this particular matter. That is a sensible, legitimate question and Senator Parer deserves an answer. Relevance requires the minister to answer the question that is asked, not one that he is inventing.
—I do not think there is any point of order; the matter was being debated, both in the question and in the answer. But I would ask the minister to get to the answer.

—As I said before I was so rudely interrupted, the east-west runway, the subject of Senator Parer's question, will remain in service. It will be used when weather conditions at Sydney airport preclude the use of the other two runways; that is, when cross-winds are in excess of 25 knots. That, I might add, was always the position that was going to be adopted with the use of the east-west runway. As the Civil Aviation Authority has pointed out, if we bring the east-west runway back into service—and all this evidence was provided in the absence of Senator Parer, the shadow minister, from the Senate estimates committee—we will have to consider that currently there is an aircraft crossing the east-west runway every 45 seconds from the other two parallel runways. It would be an interesting exercise, indeed, in safety considerations to imagine operating those three runways simultaneously.

PARA.TAB: The position Senator Parer put is a nonsense. The Civil Aviation Authority has made it clear on the record that the decision was taken on not using the east-west runway in simultaneous operations in comparison with the two cross runways—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no problem in Paris.

—You want to bet? On safety grounds it is uncontested: the use of two parallel runways is safer than using two parallel runways with a third intersecting runway crossing the two parallel runways. Apart from anything else, it causes problems—
—It can be done.

—Senator Hill, how many times have you been to Sydney airport? What happens to the aircraft when they get to the end of the second parallel runway? Do they leapfrog across the east-west runway onto the other side? Do they tunnel underneath the east-west runway to get to the other side? As I just said, the Civil Aviation Authority has advised us that the current operations have got an aircraft from either the second parallel runway or the first crossing the east-west runway on those little wheels they have underneath them—
—You have made an awful mess of it.

—Senator Parer, it is called taxiing; I think that is the technical expression for it. An aircraft is taxiing across that airport every 45 seconds. The decision was not one of the minister's. The decision, as the CAA said—
—So Laurie had nothing to do with it.

—which Senator Parer simply refuses to accept—is on safety grounds. Why does Senator Parer not refer his inquiries to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, if he wants a second opinion and he does not want to rely on the Civil Aviation Authority? Operating two parallel runways is safer than operating two parallel runways with an intersecting third runway.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister making an absolutely definitive statement that the government will not open the east-west runway to normal traffic? I would also refer the minister to Hansard of 9 September 1991 in which he stated, as the then minister, that claims that 10,000 houses would be subject to noise levels of 25 ANEF were `absolute baloney'. Does the minister continue to stand by that statement?

—I will restate that the operational decisions for the safe operation of Sydney airport will be the province of the Civil Aviation Authority, not the minister for transport, whoever that may be. In respect of the actions that the government is taking, the minister has made it very clear, publicly and through this parliament, that what the government is doing is introducing noise amelioration techniques that have already been brought into place by the Civil Aviation Authority; I also refer to the acquisition of the worst affected houses and the noise insulation of those not so adversely affected. The minister has said he will be bringing forward to cabinet a proposal to accelerate that action.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to the reforms of the business skills category of the migration program he announced in May this year, in particular the introduction of an investment-linked business migration subclass. Can the minister inform the Senate how this initiative is being progressed and how the states are involved in its implementation?

—I thank Senator Foreman for focusing on a part of the immigration program which is of continuing importance. There is a great deal of activity in respect of it, and it holds great promise for the contribution it can make to the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: Senator Foreman is right: in May I did announce a series of reforms to the business skills category of migration in response to a review by a panel on business migration chaired by Mr Ivan Deveson AO. One of Mr Deveson's recommendations was that the government broaden the range of people who qualify for business migration by testing the concept of a business migration link to capital investment rather than, for instance, hands-on activity in the short time after migrants arrive in Australia. The objective of the subclass will be to offer business migrants the opportunity to make a three-year financial investment in Australia to give them time to consider the long-term prospects of their business strategy and their personal future here.

People in this new subclass will be required to invest a minimum of $750,000 in a designated government security for a fixed term. Additional points can be earned for amounts up to $2 million, but the government's approach is not just to concentrate on the wealth of those coming to Australia but to look for economic play-makers. In doing so, applicants will have to prove a record of achievement in business or investment and pass other criteria, such as English language points based assessments.

The department has been implementing this subclass. We have been researching the range of government securities of the size required for eligibility by all state governments, and we have found that all state governments have suitable investment products. They have all been provided with details and been briefed on the program. Queensland, Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory have all indicated that they are keen to participate and make government securities available for this important potential client group.

The one state that stuns me in its response—the only exception—is the state of South Australia, and the South Australian government financing authority. South Australia has admitted that there are no hurdles or impediments to subscribing to this subclass under our business migration program. Nevertheless, it has said that it is not prepared to tailor its existing securities to benefit the state and the people of South Australia. It was fully briefed on what is involved and on the potential to the state. However, the Brown government remains intransigent and is not prepared to accommodate in a way that is quite easily open to it.

For me, as a South Australian, it is an extremely disappointing response. It is short-sighted and counterproductive and it is a response that the South Australian government cannot afford to take in the interests of the economic and social future of that state. A look at the history of migration in South Australia in recent years reveals that in the last financial year South Australia attracted less than 4.7 per cent of all settler arrivals to Australia. A look at that important part of our migration program—the business migration program—shows that only 40 of the nearly 2,000 business skilled migrants who have come to Australia since 1992 intend to live in South Australia. That is just two per cent.

The message that the Brown government has now given in its response to our initiative, in its reluctance and incapacity to take up the ball in this respect, is that South Australia is closed for business migration. It is a crude and short-sighted response and it lacks the vision that is needed for the state of South Australia to progress. I have made it very clear to that government and the financing authority there that we are prepared to promote and include the South Australian financing authority subscription to our scheme if it changes its position, even at this late stage of the process. My offer still remains the same.

Australian migration posts have the responsibility of promoting business migration, and they will continue to do so. There has been a vast increase in the level of interest, particularly in Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea. I would like to see the scheme go ahead with South Australian participation, not without it. South Australia cannot afford to put up the closed sign for business migration. It should change its position. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories to the Phillip Christou case in which Christou tested positive for a banned substance prior to the Commonwealth Games and received a penalty of suspension for but one month, which allowed him to compete in those games and win a bronze medal. Given the fact that the Australian Sports Commission has found that the diuretic had no acceptable medical use—in fact, Lasix is used by women to treat pre-menstrual tension, not by weightlifters, except as a masking agent—given that the minimum International Weightlifting Federation penalty for a first offence is two years and that the IOC drug charter penalty for a first offence is also a minimum of two years, does the minister agree with the Australian Olympic Federation's medical commission chairman, Dr Ken Fitch, that the penalty given to Christou was a `total joke' and had risked Australia's reputation as being tough on drug use in the lead-up to the 2000 Olympic Games? I quote Dr Fitch:

QUESTION.PARA: We make a lot of noise about China's record on drugs in sport, but when you see circumstances like this it leave a bad taste in your mouth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the case that Senator Crichton-Browne referred to. The Australian Weightlifting Federation instituted a hearing which resulted in this athlete being suspended for one month, as mentioned. That suspension was served prior to this athlete's selection and prior to his departure for the Commonwealth Games. The Australian Commonwealth Games Association confirmed his participation at the games, with knowledge of the positive test. The ACGA executive made its decision in accordance with its doping policy. The ACGA is a private organisation which does not receive funding from the Australian Sports Commission and its actions, therefore, are not subject to government regulation.

PARA.TAB: In respect of action taken by the AWF, the ASC expressed concerns about the hearing process. Accordingly, the ASC has conducted an extensive review involving legal advice. This has concluded that the AWF had followed appropriate procedures but that the hearing committee established by the AWF had erred in some areas. It was a particularly difficult case because legal issues concerning therapeutic use did have to be determined. We recognise the rights of individuals and seek to handle these particular issues in accordance with those rights. On the basis of current information and legal advice, the commission is not going to require a fresh hearing. In respect of the AWF, I can say that it has taken significant action at times and certainly has imposed the maximum penalty on athletes returning positive tests for anabolic steroids. This is the first case of which I am aware in which concern has been expressed.

However, as a result of the ASC review, the AWF has been formally put on notice that, as a condition for continuing funding from the Australian Sports Commission, it must undertake the following specific measures: it must obtain prior agreement from the ASC in respect of making appointments to hearing committees; it must inform Mr Christou that the consequence under the AWF policy of a second offence is a life ban; it is to investigate the supply of banned drugs to weightlifters and take appropriate disciplinary action against any persons found to have contributed to doping infractions; it is to amend the AWF doping policy to ensure that inadvertent usage will not negate appropriate sanctions; and it is to institute an aggressive education and information program in conjunction with the Australian Sports Drug Agency to ensure that athletes are not ignorant of the AWF policy or the consequences of taking banned drugs.

Australia has the best drug testing and drug education program in the world, with over 2,000 tests conducted annually, targeted mainly at high risk sports. I think we can be confident that the use of performance enhancing drugs in Australian sports is minimal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It thoroughly escapes me how anyone could take a diuretic of that nature inadvertently. No doubt it also escapes the Australian Sports Commission. Will the government require bodies such as the Australian Weightlifting Federation, which attracts half a million dollars of taxpayers' money annually, to provide the minimum prescribed penalty of two years, as set down by the IOC in its drug charter and also by the International Weightlifting Federation?

—I think you can see, Mr President, from the response of the ASC that I did request the ASC to take this matter extremely seriously; hence the response and the investigations that have been made on this particular issue. It has not been taken lightly. I think I can confidently say to the honourable senator that because of the new procedures that have been put in place, because of the initiatives that I have outlined, there will be no repeat of this circumstance. I can guarantee Senator Crichton-Browne that the Australian Sports Commission will continue to monitor this situation very closely, as I have requested it to do following my attention being drawn to this incident.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Are any charges levied on exporters by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to cover the costs associated with issuing export licences or monitoring the export of agricultural products such as wool, cotton, fruit and wine; mineral exports such as iron ore and coal; fishing products such as tuna and salmon; or forestry products such as woodchips, round logs, sawn timber or paper? If so, what are they, how are the costs calculated, and what level of cost recovery is achieved? If not, why not?

—Senator Chamarette certainly knows the answer to the last part of her question about woodchips, because the question was asked and answered during a Senate Estimates committee hearing. The answer to the first part of Senator Chamarette's question is: the Department of Primary Industries and Energy does not levy charges to cover costs associated with issuing licences for woodchip exports; neither has it charged for the monitoring of the export of woodchips. Export control regulations applying to the export of woodchips do not provide for such charging.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the other commodities mentioned by Senator Chamarette, licence charges are not levied for coal, bauxite, alumina, mineral sands and uranium exports. For the other commodities listed by Senator Chamarette, licences are not required at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I was aware of that but I wondered about the other areas. My supplementary question is: why is it that after over 20 years of woodchip exports from Australia the department has no idea what it costs it to process woodchip export licences? The department has made no attempt to recover from the exporters the costs of issuing these licences.

—As I think I have just demonstrated, in all of the other numerous commodities that Senator Chamarette has mentioned—not just woodchipping but generally—the practice for a significant period has been not to charge for these kinds of export provisions.
—Why is that?
—These matters are always matters that are considered from time to time during the budget deliberations of government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. I refer the minister to the recent federal government package to restrain Medicare spending through cuts in general practitioner numbers and GP training positions. In a letter to the New South Wales government, the federal government stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The Commonwealth is concerned about possible industrial action by resident medical officers who are likely to feel disadvantaged by a restriction on access to the Royal Australian College of GPs.

Is this not a stupid and arrogant position to take when the minister knows it is likely to cause disruptions to thousands of patients in New South Wales hospitals? In light of the fact that there is an urgent need for a thousand doctors in rural and regional Australia, why is the government persisting with this patently misguided approach? When will the government understand that cutting numbers and restricting trainees without solving the overall problem of doctors in the wrong place guarantees that rural areas will find it even harder to attract doctors?

TALK.START.PARA: —That question falls across a number of areas of concern. It seems that Senator Macdonald has picked up the reforms proposed in the area of general practice and associated them with the difficulties of training young doctors in hospitals. It is a matter of great concern to this government that there is adequate training for general practitioners and a recognition of their importance, particularly as they are the first port of call for people coming into the health system in the majority of cases.

PARA.TAB: The government is concerned that there be a redistribution or assistance for general practitioners to move into rural Australia. There is no doubt at all about the point that Senator Macdonald made: we have a lot of doctors but we have a maldistribution of them, particularly in the general practice area.

I believe that the government's reforms in this area take account of the concerns that Senator Macdonald raised. They very much recognise, firstly, the importance of quality in general practice and, secondly, the assistance to help general practitioners, in particular, to move to practise in rural Australia. If there is anything further I can provide in answer to Senator Macdonald, I will certainly get it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I understand that the new visitors' centre in Kakadu National Park has recently been awarded the Sir Zelman Cowen Award for public buildings. Can Senator Faulkner provide the Senate with some background to this award and details on why the Kakadu Visitor Centre was judged to be so outstanding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reynolds for her continued interest in Kakadu and the enhancement of Kakadu as a great national asset, a tourist attraction and a World Heritage area. I had the opportunity to view the visitors' centre at Kakadu National Park when I opened the new facilities with the traditional owners in August this year. I must say that I think it is a magnificent piece of architecture. It is functional; it is imaginative; and it is totally in keeping with the natural surroundings of Kakadu.

PARA.TAB: So I was pleased—perhaps not very surprised—when I heard that the centre had won the 1994 Sir Zelman Cowen Award for public buildings. This is a national award established by Sir Zelman through his interest in architecture and design in an environmental context. It exists to acknowledge excellence in design and the application of design solutions which improve the quality of the built environment for the whole community. I am sure that any honourable senators who visit the centre would agree with the commentary of the judges for the award, who said:

ANSWER.PARA: This marvellous building has a sense of always having been there—having grown out of the land on which it sits. It is a total design—controlled from start to finish. People swarm eagerly through this building. It draws you in, positively inviting exploration, and leads you on where there is a reward at every turn.

These comments are borne out by the number of visitors who attend the new facilities. They have increased markedly and, of course, the visitors who go there are spending more time there. I think the most important feature of this centre is that its form and function showcase the success of the joint management at Kakadu, which is due to the close collaboration between Kakadu's Aboriginal traditional owners, the park managers and the Australian Nature Conservation Agency from my own portfolio.

PARA.TAB: The centre is representative of Kakadu. It is a place with unique natural features which are globally and scientifically significant and which have the power to obviously impact deeply on visitors to the park. It is a major economic generator which draws visitors from all over the world and provides income and employment for thousands of people. It is a place where Aboriginal traditional owners share their knowledge and deep understanding of the land with all Australians and people from all over the world. The new visitor centre will further enhance the status of Kakadu which, along with Uluru National Park, is an internationally acknowledged and acclaimed model for the management of World Heritage areas involving indigenous people.

I would like to offer my congratulations—and I know Senator Reynolds does too—to Troppo Architects of Darwin and Glen Murcutt and Associates, who collaborated with the traditional owners and ANCA to produce what I think is a truly groundbreaking and magnificent building which symbolises the government's commitment to both nature conservation and the principles and practices of joint management of protected areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to the fact that in October of this year seven of the western provinces of southern Vietnam suffered the worst floods in 30 years, affecting more than one million people. Is the minister aware that members of the Unified Buddhist Church, who had assisted to arrange drought relief to the 900 poorest families in the area, have been intimidated and have had their relief aid confiscated and that several members of the church have been detained by the government as a consequence of their humanitarian endeavours? I have raised the Vietnamese persecution of Buddhists before and I ask the minister whether he will again take this matter up with the Vietnamese government—this particular incident and the persecution and detention of Buddhists generally in the country.

—I am afraid I am not aware of the particular circumstances to which Senator Reid refers, but I certainly am happy to look into them and, if appropriate, make representations accordingly. Certainly we are conscious of the extent to which over the years Buddhists—or particular groups of Buddhists anyway—have been the subject of excessive attention and inhibitions, restrictions and limitations on their freedom of religious activity and otherwise by the Vietnamese government. It has been a recurring matter of concern and it is something that I would certainly expect to be taken up by the parliamentary consultative delegation that we are trying to reinstate and, hopefully, will be able to be reinstated next year. Beyond that, I am certainly happy to look into the issue and make any more specific or earlier representations that may be appropriate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I ask: can the minister confirm that, if the privatisation of Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport proceeds, the government will have surrendered its power to divert air traffic to any other Sydney airport? Is it not a virtual certainty that a privatised Kingsford-Smith Airport close to the Sydney CBD will operate at full capacity because the airlines will want to use it in preference to a less central airport? Will the government abandon the privatisation of Kingsford-Smith Airport so that it retains the power to cut the intolerable noise pollution being suffered by so many residents of Sydney?

—Regardless of whether or not an airport is privatised, all airports will continue to be subject to Commonwealth regulation. That includes noise and environmental issues—the issues Senator Bourne has raised. Whether the airport is privatised or not is not the issue. The issue is ensuring that proper regulatory safeguards and enforcement mechanisms are in place. For that reason, when the government announced its decision to sell the airports, it announced that we were undertaking some scoping studies relating to the sales of those airports. Those scoping studies, as was announced then, are not simply into the commercial aspects of selling the airport; they are also into the extremely important area of the regulatory controls that such sales would bring about—precisely the issues that Senator Bourne has raised. The government will not be taking a public position on these issues until these major studies are completed, and they will take some time to complete.

PARA.TAB: I will give Senator Bourne, and the Senate generally, an indication of what is happening at the moment with Badgerys Creek and the time that will need to be provided for such an extensive development. The Badgerys Creek airport is being developed as quickly as possible to meet the rapidly growing demand for scheduled air services—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you say in 1991, Bob?
—Have a listen.
—You said it would be going in 1994.

—Senator Parer made an interesting omission, I note from the Hansard I just picked up. Senator Brownhill might be interested to know they left him out. Work is well advanced on the preparation of a new concept design. Estimates and an implementation program for the accelerated development were announced by the government earlier this year. Following the planned commissioning of a major aircraft runway in 1998-99, it is expected that further development of the airport will occur in stages consistent with aviation demand, and it is proposed that Sydney West airport will be curfew free. I remember all the calls from the opposition and the New South Wales government to have Sydney airport curfew free.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth is working with the New South Wales government on the timely provision of adequate land transport links to the airport—which, as I am sure Senator Bourne would agree, are vitally important otherwise the airport at Badgerys Creek would be virtually useless—to ensure that passengers and freight can be moved efficiently. An environmental impact statement on options for the national highway between Prestons and Cecil Park, for which the Minister for Transport has pledged $200 million, has now commenced.

Work is also under way on an engineering study to identify a rail corridor to Sydney West airport. A new task force has been established to coordinate planning by Commonwealth, state and local government for the western Sydney region, including the Sydney West airport and associated developments. The objective is to maximise the potential of the new airport and associated developments for employment generation and economic growth while managing the land use, transport and environmental impacts of those developments. While all this is going on, the scoping studies that I mentioned earlier are taking place. Those scoping studies are not simply to investigate the economic and financial aspects of selling the airports; they are also, very importantly, to deal with the regulatory matters that were raised in Senator Bourne's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Why is there a reported conflict between members of the National Council of the International Year of the Family and its chairwoman, Professor Bettina Cass, over the issue of means testing for a proposed child-care payment for parents with children under six years of age? Does this mean that there will still be child care for millionaires? Why did Professor Cass reverse the decision to means test without telling her colleagues, such as Professor Don Edgar, who, along with other members of the council, is allegedly disappointed with the final report?

—I received in my office last Friday a letter from Dr Edgar indicating his views about the matter that Senator Troeth has raised, adding, in particular, that his views are not necessarily shared by all members of the council, and going on to say that he supports all the recommendations except one.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make it clear, first of all, that most of the matters that the honourable senator has raised are matters for the Council of the International Year of the Family, not a matter for government. But what Professor Edgar says in terms of the disagreement about the major recommendation—about whether or not such a payment for children under six should be means tested—is of considerable importance. I would like to talk about it now, particularly because the coalition has come out strongly in support of this.

One of the things we have found in our examination to this point is that such a payment as per that recommendation would principally benefit families where both parents are working and currently having very low child-care costs. So there is a very important caution about rushing to support these recommendations, as the coalition seems to have done to this point.

The coalition has also come out opposing a number of things the government does in terms of support for families. This government's support for families is unquestioned, very targeted and very good, unlike the opposition's. For example, the opposition proposes income splitting to assist families—a method that will only benefit high income families—or there is Senator Minchin's proposal that we should—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. As Senator Crowley always does when she gets into trouble, she is now comparing coalition policy with government policy. The situation is very simple. The question should be answered. It is a question of relevance. The question is what is the government going to do about it, not what is coalition policy—which, by the way, Senator Crowley happened to get wrong.
—I ask the minister to concentrate on government policy.

—It is important to note, Mr President, that every time we start cutting close to the bone about what the opposition might do, those opposite get up and object. But I think that is perfectly reasonable for Senator Woods. I do not know why those opposite are so touchy. Senator Minchin has opposed in this place on a number of occasions some of the recommendations this government has put in place. This government's payments for families are targeted to the low-income end of the scale—and they are achieving huge benefits for families.
—Child-care changes?

—Indeed they are. Senator Hill may not know about child-care assistance, but that is one of the important matters we strongly endorse, as does our quality accreditation program. There is a caution—and we are aware of it—on the recommendation about which Dr Edgar has some difficulties because if it is not means tested, first of all, it will be very expensive and, secondly, our examination of that recommendation to this point indicates that the chief beneficiaries will not be parents where one parent is at home but will be two parents, both in the work force and enjoying currently very low child-care costs. Senator Woods may shake his head, but those are the facts. If he does not understand that, that indicates clearly that he is not aware of how best to assist families with the cost of children. This government's record stands—and those opposite only have proposals that indicate they do not know how to help.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If Senator Crowley's child-care policy is so well targeted, how is it that I have received notice of a documented case where a parent is able to claim both the home child-care allowance and the child-care rebate while she is on maternity leave? A mother of whom I have received notice has two children under school age; is on approved maternity leave; and, under the fourth priority child-care guidelines, is eligible for the child-care rebate. At the same time, she is at home not working, which makes her eligible for the home child-care allowance—and she is claiming and getting both. The minister must admit that this illustrates the bewildering complexity of the government's family legislation. What does she intend to do about this anomaly?

—Mr President, I take a point of order. There must be a limit to the extent to which supplementary questions—or indeed, any questions—can be cast as prose, and extended prose at that, rather than in the form of a question. Could you draw Senator Troeth's attention to the fact that her task is to ask questions, not to make debating speeches?

—On the point of order: during Senator Crowley's answer, she tried to maintain the fiction that the government home child-care allowance—and indeed the whole of the government's child-care policy—is very well targeted. My supplementary question illustrated very well the fact that it is not targeted; it is distributed indiscriminately to people who can claim both under the existing legislation.

—On the point raised by Senator Evans: if you, Mr President, are going to contemplate giving some instruction as to how questions ought to be asked, you will have to contemplate giving an instruction as to how they ought to be answered.
—You are correct, Senator Vanstone. That is a difficulty. In my opinion, the supplementary question was in order.

—Our payments are very targeted. Senator Troeth, if she examines the basic family payment, if she examines the additional family payment and if she examines the rent assistance—if she examines all those payments—will know that they are very well targeted.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I have asked Senator Crowley a very specific question: how is it that somebody can get both these payments? She is making no attempt to answer the question.
—I have no way of judging whether that was an appropriate answer. It seems to me to be generally relevant within the area of her responsibilities.

—It is, Mr President. Senator Troeth argues that our payments are not targeted. They certainly are—and some of them, as well, go to different areas. The home child-care allowance and the cash rebate have floated some anomalies of the sort she has just raised. One is whether people who are paying for child care to reserve a place should be allowed to get the cash rebate for that. This has been raised in relation to people with illnesses and those on holiday pay. Exactly the same thing may be happening with this woman on maternity leave and reserving a place. If Senator Troeth can give me the details, I will certainly look at the matter. But to float an anomaly or two does not deny the truth of our basic child-care payments and family payments.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions, and statements, be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 November I replied to a question from Senator Margetts about Australia's voting intentions at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development on the status of a proposal for a new power plant in Slovakia. I was asked a further question about when that decision would be made and some supplementary questions in relation to that, to which I now respond briefly.

PARA.TAB: Australia's executive director at the EBRD in London has advised that the Mochovce project is unlikely to be scheduled for consideration by the EBRD's board before late February 1995. The meeting on 6 December is a board workshop, an informal process to enable an exchange of views and information as part of the preparation of major projects or policy issues. Australia will therefore not be making a final decision on the issue until much closer to the time it is to be considered by the EBRD board and after careful consideration by departments of the range of issues involved. I can agree, however, that when the decision is made the government will make the decision and the reasons for it public.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) this day, to a question without notice asked by Senator Margetts on 30 November, relating to the Australian vote at a meeting of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) for providing this information, but unfortunately it says that when the decision is made the government will make the decision and the reasons for it public. That is not what in fact was asked. I asked when the decision will be made—all the answer said was that it would be made much closer to the time—and whether the reasons for the decision will be made available before the decision has been made.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, it is a kind of `we'll tell you when we've done it' response, which really is not good enough when it relates to Australia being involved in a situation where it may be promoting a type of nuclear plant that is considered unsafe. It might be better than some worse nuclear power plants, but it is not good enough that we once again, when we are being represented at international fora, take this attitude that we have no ability to find out the rationale of what official line Australia and our representatives are taking.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Parer this day, relating to the east-west runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins no doubt will leap to his feet and give some throwaway lines that he thinks might be witty, but let me address the real issue relating to the east-west runway. Senator Collins said this was a decision of the CAA and not of the government or the minister. This is the sort of deceit and lying that have happened and is why this government is now finding itself in trouble.

PARA.TAB: In 1993 Greg Marks of the Civil Aviation Authority wrote to Ms Sandra Kwa. Sandra Kwa had written to the CAA suggesting a method of operation which included the two parallel runways and the east-west runway. Greg Marks replied:
The suggested preferred runway usage outlined in your paper is a workable method of processing air traffic.

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 June 1994 the Airport Action Committee wrote to Mr John Cappelletti, Assistant General Manager, Air Traffic Services, Civil Aviation Authority. The committee pointed out that, following informal discussions with Mr Greg Marks—in fact, a telephone conversation—it sought written confirmation from the CAA on certain points. One of them was, as stated in the letter:
The CAA has received Instruction from the Minister that the following pattern of runway usage is to take effect upon the opening of the third runway—
and a series of decisions that were made was indicated. One of them was that the east-west runway not be used except in adverse weather conditions.

PARA.TAB: By that time the Civil Aviation Authority had obviously been given its marching orders by a minister who was trying desperately to get traffic off his own electorate, where, I might say, the traffic had been operating quite happily for about the last 30 years, and redirect it to the northern suburbs—

TALK.START.PARA: —Happily? Happily!

—As Senator Collins knows, people who buy under flight paths know what they are doing; no-one would dispute that. The concern is that there are 100,000 people in Sydney who are now getting flights across their roofs when they did not purchase under a flight path.
—That hardly happens.
—Obviously Senator Collins, with his babbling on, is trying to detract from the logical progression of what happened at Sydney airport. He claims it is the CAA. No-one believes that.
—No, not me; the CAA claimed. You weren't there.

—The CAA claimed under instructions from the government and the minister. What I am proving is that a year ago the CAA said it could be done. The Airport Action Committee wrote to the CAA to get that confirmed, and in June 1994 a response came from the CAA which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government granted approval for the development of the third runway, they also stipulated the operating mode of the airport post its operation.

The government stipulated that, not the CAA. In fact, the CAA knows darn well that parallel and cross runways exist all around the world. San Francisco is a great example. It is no good Senator Collins coming in here and pretending that he is holier than thou and listening to the CAA. The CAA is saying this because his government has told it to say it. He knows it and the 10,000 people at Leichhardt Oval know it. The other 1,500 or so at the meeting that I was at know it. Everyone is aware of the fact that it can be operated. The question I asked the other day to which Senator Collins did not give me an answer was: how come the main runway and the cross-runway were safe six weeks ago but they are not safe today?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because there are two runways, Senator, both of which have aircraft crossing the other one.

—Of course there are two runways; for goodness sake, Senator Collins will get his chance. The point I am making is that the advice the minister has given us is wrong. It is as deceitful as what Mr Brereton has said over the past six months about the hiding of the airport and the noise that was going to affect those people on the northern side of Kingsford-Smith airport. This government and the minister should be condemned for the deceit and damage they have caused to hundreds of thousands of innocent people in Sydney.
—If the minister believes it is unsafe to use the east-west runway—
—That is not what I said.

—Exactly! He has not said that, and I am glad the minister interjected because that is the issue. If the minister believes it is unsafe to use the east-west runway, let him say so. If he does not believe it is unsafe, let him shut up for a change. Let him pull his head in because he is continually giving the public the impression that there is a risk to safety by opening the east-west runway except in an emergency.

PARA.TAB: There are degrees of safety. There is total, absolute and complete safety, and that is probably a touch safer than absolute, total safety. That is the degree of difference between these two operations. Both of them are safe, and the minister knows it. The minister says it is a question of safety because there may well be, perhaps, possibly, a tiny diminution in safety from very total, absolute and complete safety to just total, absolute, complete safety. That is the issue. This minister has set out to mislead the public of Australia by continually saying the decision was made on safety grounds, conveying an impression that there would be a serious diminution in safety if the east-west runway were not used.

I ask him to respond in exactly these terms: would there be a serious diminution of safety if the east-west runway were used in the present configuration? I want to hear that answer because it will put the lie to the proposition he has been putting. I also think it would be nice if he could tell us whether, in fact, the minister who stood to gain from the closing of the east-west runway was advised of the operational decision, taken allegedly on safety grounds, before it was introduced.

I also want to comment on the minister's remark that the Premier of New South Wales called for Sydney airport to be curfew free. The minister knows perfectly well what the Premier of New South Wales called for. When New South Wales was having a competitive bid for the 2000 Olympics, he said that the bid would be assisted if there were a removal of the curfew, along with a massive upgrading of airport facilities for Sydney. That is absolutely true. It would have been.

In the end, we did not need that undertaking. We did not need that promise to have the removal of the curfew. We still got the bid. What Premier Fahey was saying was that it would have assisted the bid. In the end, we did not need it. The minister knows perfectly well when he comes in here trying to mislead the people of this country about what the Premier of New South Wales said that it related to the Sydney Olympic bid and nothing more. It was not a general plea for the removal of the curfew and the minister knows it. He set out deliberately to mislead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it was.

—It was not. How dare the minister suggest that the Premier of New South Wales was lying when it is quite clearly evident that his comments related specifically to the Olympic bid, and the minister knows it.

PARA.TAB: I think we will also have a little comment about Badgerys Creek from this misleading minister because in the Senate estimates committee hearings we heard from a CAA official—or was it one from the FAC?—that it would be very optimistic to think that Badgerys Creek could provide any relief by 1997. I wonder if this minister will eventually come clean and tell us, in his considered judgment, how it will be possible to have Badgerys Creek providing any kind of relief to anything other than light aircraft by 1997.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the deceit stakes, I have to say the federal opposition would have to be past masters on this particular subject. I refer all senators to the record of the Senate estimates committee where this matter was discussed last week. The minister is aware that the executive director of the board of Airline Representatives Australia has called for the use of all three runways at Sydney airport. The minister is also aware of claims made by Hazelton Airlines of continuing congestion at Sydney airport since the opening of the parallel runway, and Mr Hazelton's suggestion that commuter aircraft should be permitted to continue the use of the east-west runway in order to enhance capacity.

PARA.TAB: The government's policy on the use of the east-west runway is that it will remain in operation. But its uses will be restricted to those periods when weather conditions preclude the use of the north-south parallel runway system; that is, when wind conditions limit operations of the sole use of the east-west runway—which, historically, is about two per cent of the time.

Other opposition senators with a keen interest in this matter, such as Senator Brownhill—who has pressed me continually on this issue both inside and outside the Senate—know that this was always going be the case from day one with the use of the second parallel runway. This might be stating the obvious, but that is precisely why for years we have been dealing with predictions in the EIS of significantly reduced noise to the east and west of the runway. People are not protesting about it—I do not know why one would expect them to—because 80,000 people net to the east and west of the runway are now getting less noise than they were before. How can we have significantly reduced noise to the east and west of the runway, which is currently being experienced, without reducing the use of the runway? It was always going to be the case from day one. It is duplicitous to say, `We supported the third runway', but not remove the east-west runway from normal operations. It is an absolute nonsense.

The use of the east-west runway was evaluated by the Civil Aviation Authority. The authority advised the minister quite clearly that, on safety grounds, it does not recommend the use of the east-west runway while the parallel north-south runway systems are in operation. In a media release on 30 November—that is, last week—the CAA reaffirmed its position that, on safety grounds, it strongly advises against the use of the east-west runway in intersecting operations with the north-south runway system.

If Senator Baume wants a second opinion, I suggest that he talk to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which is fiercely independent of the Civil Aviation Authority. The officer in charge of air traffic control at the Civil Aviation Authority said on the record—it is in the Hansard—that he took responsibility publicly and clearly, which was reaffirmed subsequently, in the decision not to operate in normal operations the parallel runways with the east-west runway intersecting. That was always going to be the case.
It is pretty cute for the opposition to talk about deceit. I have extracted the Hansard reference—

TALK.START.PARA: —You people are past masters at it.

—Senator Ian Macdonald is a classic. I am glad that he interjected. He purported to quote—I have corrected the record in estimates—on this issue from a Hansard extract in Senate estimates. The Hansard clearly shows him saying that I had said at a Senate estimates committee I was `happy' with the way in which the Civil Aviation Authority was looking after air safety. He asked me whether I wanted to reconsider my statement. I said to him, `Senator Macdonald, I would not believe you if you told me the time. I am not going to respond to that until I read the Hansard.' I read the Hansard, which shows that I said exactly the opposite. I read it into the Hansard record at Senate estimates. Senator Macdonald is an Oscar winner in terms of deceit.
