PARA.TAB: In terms of the `baloney' remark, Senator Parer did not bother advising the Senate that I was responding to an interjection from his colleague Senator David Brownhill. This nails the duplicity and opportunism of the opposition on this subject. I said in reply to a question, `Ten thousand houses will be subject to noise levels of 25 ANEF or greater because of the third'. That is as far as I got. His colleague Senator Brownhill interjected, `Which is absolute baloney.'

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you say?

—I then went on to say, `Senator Brownhill is correct.' That is a nice, neat, deceitful omission from the Hansard record. I refer all honourable senators to the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport draft noise management plan, which indicates that those assertions are not correct.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Ian Macdonald proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The incompetence, divisiveness and political motivation of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner in his handling of the Oyster Point/Port Hinchinbrook project which has resulted in:

PARA.TAB: .the loss of 40 jobs
.the addition of one million dollars to the cost of the project
.the creation of a serious and real threat to the environment from the delay in finalising stabilising work on the site
.community division
.loss of investor confidence in the tourism industry in Australia by the overriding of decisions of a sovereign Government

INTERJECT.PARA: and the lack of any credible scientific evidence to support the Minister's ever changing position on the project and the need for urgent action to resolve the situation.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Macdonald, I inform the Senate that informal arrangements have been made to allocate speaking times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I will ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance sets out very clearly all the things that are wrong with Senator Faulkner in his role as the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and, in particular, in the way in which he has handled the Oyster Point-Port Hinchinbrook project. Unfortunately, the minister is not even in the chamber at present to deal with this matter. Whilst I do not like saying these things in his absence, I have no alternative. The minister has shown his complete incompetence in the way he has dealt with this matter. He has shown how he can be divisive purely for political purposes, regardless of the cost to communities. He has also shown that he has made decisions on the basis of political motivation rather than on the basis of good government and the management of the environment, which is the duty with which he is charged.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy President, you do not need to listen to me to learn of Senator Faulkner's incompetence; you just need to listen to the Queensland Labor Premier, who was asked this question in an interview:

SPEECH.PARA: So had Senator Faulkner made a fool of himself?
Mr Goss answered:
I'm not going to criticise Senator Faulkner; I think the record speaks for itself.

What a resounding endorsement by a Labor premier of the Labor minister for the environment! Mr Goss obviously has nothing but contempt for Senator Faulkner and the way he has handled this matter. Mr Williams, the developer concerned, was probably a little more accurate when he said of Senator Faulkner:
. . . I feel a little sorry for John Faulkner. I think he's been subjected to a bullshit-baffles-brains campaign, and I think the load got to be intolerable for him . . .
Mr Goss also said of Senator Faulkner:
. . . I think it's an example of a Minister being put under severe pressure by prominent members of the Green movement and one or two other members of the Senate, and responding to that pressure.

Senator Reynolds, who I see is listed to speak in the debate, was nominated by Mr Goss as one of those Labor senators who had put Senator Faulkner under pressure. With regard to the political motivation, I again quote Mr Goss, who said of this issue, `It has more to do with politics than the environment.'

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner and the Labor Party have for many years used the environment as a political plaything—something they can use to garner the second preferences of the Green candidates when it looks like they are about to lose an election. They are certainly in that category again. Senator Faulkner is trying to be the poor man's Richo—trying to do what Senator Richardson did in the 1990 election. But, regrettably for the Labor Party, Senator Faulkner is not anywhere near the same sort of competent minister as Senator Richardson when it comes to gathering these votes for political purposes.

Senator Faulkner has made an absolute hash of it all and, in doing so, has divided a town, has cost 40 jobs and has added $1 million to the cost of the project. My office in Townsville has been inundated with calls from people who had jobs on that project but who, because of Senator Faulkner's action, now do not have employment. Work which they were relying on in the lead-up to the Christmas period has now gone and they and their families will suffer as a result of Senator Faulkner's action.

Perhaps one of the worst aspects of this whole debacle is that Senator Faulkner has now single-handedly created what is perhaps one of the greatest environmental problems in North Queensland at present—that is, he has stopped all work on that site at a time when the work should have been completed and the site should have been finalised, so that in the coming wet season the site would have been protected.

As it is now, Senator Faulkner has insisted that Mr Williams stop work. He protesteth and says that he has not stopped work on the site. From my reading of the proclamation and section 10 of the act, that is not as I see it. I would like Senator Faulkner to explain that if he reckons he has not stopped the work on the site. The proclamation relating to section 10 of the act certainly indicates that. In any case, one cannot stop part of a proposal and expect the other part to go on around it. So Senator Faulkner has created an enormous environmental problem in that area. Even his workshop of experts has indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: The current state of the site poses a significant erosion hazard with the imminent onset of the wet season.

What has Senator Faulkner done about it? Absolutely nothing. He has had some talks. He said he wants to give some advice—advice, I might say, which was already being given by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—and he is talking about throwing in a little bit of money. Here we are a week on and nothing has happened.

PARA.TAB: This matter has now been going for, according to Mr Goss, over 10 months. Senator Faulkner and his department have known about it for 10 months but they did not do anything until 15 November.Why did they take action on 15 November? Senator Faulkner says they did so because he has got some new evidence. But when we ask what the new evidence is, we are told that it is advice to his department—which is a bit patchy anyhow and does not require, on the evidence that is quoted, the developer to stop work. They have recommended that work stop but they do not quote any telling evidence that supports that proposal. In fact, they mention and seek to claim some support from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. But in a letter the day before, that authority quite clearly said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is our belief that the effects of the dredging will be much greater, in terms of sediment release, than the removal of the mangroves, and that removal of re-growth mangroves presents very little threat to the seagrass beds.

What is more, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority specifically cautioned Senator Faulkner and his department about relying on the opinions of Dr Valentine or Mr Haig. I might simply say in passing: there goes another $15,000 that Senator Faulkner paid to Dr Valentine to bring in a report about which the respected authority, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, says, `Be careful of taking any notice of it.' So there is another $15,000 just wasted by this government and this minister as part of their campaign to try to garner a few second preference Green votes.

PARA.TAB: The Senate should be very aware of the loss of investor confidence. There are now seven projects in far north Queensland that are teetering on the brink. Seven lots of jobs, seven lots of places that would bring many millions of export dollars to Australia, are all teetering because investors cannot now be confident that the decision and approval a sovereign government—the Queensland government—will not be overridden by bully boys like Senator Faulkner playing political games. Mr Goss, in his very public letter, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: The handling of this project raises serious issues for federal-state relations, tourism and the environment. There is also concern about the impact of investor confidence.

Again, Mr Goss is concerned about what investors must be considering. As I say, there is no credible scientific evidence. Even the workshop of experts set up by Senator Faulkner quite clearly states that there is no long-term effect to the seagrass beds from the removal of the mangroves. There will be some moderate effect in the short term in the worst case scenario, but that will fix itself after 12 months.

PARA.TAB: In concluding, I say that there has to be some resolution of this matter. Senator Faulkner has played politics with this long enough. A real environmental problem has been caused to the site solely by Senator Faulkner playing politics. That needs to be addressed now. But better still, for the sake of the environment, for the sake of jobs in North Queensland, for the sake of investor confidence and for the sake of the environment and getting on with the job, Senator Faulkner should do the honourable thing and resign. If he does not, he should be sacked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that one of the most significant problems with this development has been the absence of adequate environmental information on which to base decisions about its future. I have consistently pointed that out in all my dealings with the Queensland government on this matter.

PARA.TAB: I have repeatedly informed the Queensland government and the developer that if it became clear that World Heritage values were likely to be damaged, I would consider invoking the relevant provisions of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. I made that very clear in correspondence to my Queensland counterpart, Molly Robson. In a letter to her dated 29 September 1994, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: if . . . it becomes clear that World Heritage values are likely to be damaged or destroyed through the proposed development, then it will be necessary for it to be amended in such a way as to avoid that damage or destruction. Otherwise I will need to consider invoking the relevant provisions of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. I would be grateful if you would make that clear to the developer.

It is not possible to make the position any clearer than I did at that time to my Queensland counterpart. In the weeks preceding the proclamations, I certainly received scientific information which indicated that mangrove clearing at Oyster Point might damage some of the Hinchinbrook Channel's World Heritage values. I also received other scientific information, including the Queensland government's report on seagrass distribution in the Hinchinbrook Channel. There was an accumulating amount of scientific evidence, and I made that available to Senator Ian Macdonald during question time last week.

PARA.TAB: It is important to understand that this significant new information, which the baseline study made available to me only on 14 November, was made available after the clearing of the mangroves at Oyster Point had commenced. This new information convinced me that the mangrove clearing would be likely to damage World Heritage values in the channel, particularly the seagrass beds.

On 14 November, my department advised me to this effect and made a number of recommendations. The recommendations were, firstly, that I approach the Queensland authorities with a moratorium proposal; secondly, that I agree to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the department convening a workshop of experts in order to produce a consensus on the impacts of specified activities on seagrass beds; and thirdly, should the approach to the Queensland authorities for a moratorium be unsuccessful, that I authorise the department to instruct the Attorney-General's Department to prepare the necessary proclamations. Again, nothing could be clearer than that. As I have stated before, this advice was supported by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, notwithstanding the authority's differing views about the scale of the impacts of mangrove clearing.

On 15 November I asked the Queensland government and the developer for a moratorium on clearing the mangroves, pending further scientific assessment. My request was not agreed to by either the Queensland government or the developer, Mr Williams. Therefore, as a last resort, I recommended to the Governor-General that he make proclamations over part of the Hinchinbrook Channel under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act.

My purpose in seeking those proclamations and subsequent regulations was to protect World Heritage values which were likely to be damaged by development activities at Oyster Point. The proclamations in fact cover part of the Hinchinbrook Channel adjacent to Oyster Point. They do not cover any part of Mr Williams's land. These legal instruments do not give me control over the Oyster Point development site. Mr Williams may proceed—as I have said time and time again—with any activity which would not damage or destroy the World Heritage property.

We have heard about the scientific workshop. That workshop confirmed the importance of the seagrass beds and the potential for turbidity to damage the seagrass. What the workshop has done is to add to the weight of scientific evidence about the nature and extent of the impacts of the development on the seagrass beds in the adjacent World Heritage area. The report makes clear that high quality site management is critical to avoiding damage to World Heritage values.

The report recommended that the remaining mangrove roots should be left in place in order to minimise further disturbance to the sediments. If the proclamations had not been made, those roots would have been removed. The root stocks would have been removed, with consequent damage to the seagrass. The report also recommended urgent short-term stabilisation works at the site in preparation for the wet season.

The scientific working group dealt only with the issue of the mangroves. There are, of course, other aspects of the development which could have an impact on the World Heritage area—all of them, I think, associated with the marina component of the development. They would include the construction of a breakwater, dredging and increased visitor numbers in the channel and the nearby islands.

A meeting was held last Friday involving Queensland and Commonwealth officials to discuss many of these issues. I also met with my Queensland counterpart, Molly Robson, to discuss ways of preventing adverse impacts on World Heritage values and the consequent modifications which might need to be made to the development plans. Significant changes were identified as being necessary. The discussions were constructive and, I hope, have opened a way to a resolution of the outstanding issues.

Importantly, it was agreed that a foreshore management plan would be prepared to address the problem of stabilisation of the foreshore and to ensure protection of the adjacent seagrass beds. I understand that Queensland officials will be talking to the developer, Mr Williams, today to discuss this and a range of other matters, including the need for immediate action to stabilise the site before the onset of the wet season.

I have said on a number of occasions that I hope that, through the use of cooperative mechanisms, we now have agreed with Queensland that the Port Hinchinbrook development can proceed in a way consistent with my World Heritage responsibilities. Let me emphasise that I intend to continue to discharge my responsibilities to protect those values. I will not resile one inch from my obligation and my responsibilities to protect the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage areas. The sorts of changes to the development we are currently discussing certainly are aimed at ensuring that I can fully discharge those responsibilities.

I am seeking to ensure that the Commonwealth is closely involved in the design of all baseline studies and the setting of appropriate standards, that the Commonwealth gets prompt access to baseline and other studies and that site management is of the highest quality. But what this particular episode shows is the need for a situation not to arise where baseline studies are being completed and conducted at the same time as a development is taking place. There is an unarguable case for a proper sequential process in which baseline studies are conducted first, standards are set and a monitoring program is put in place and that those activities precede approvals. The development can then commence with conditions, if appropriate.

There is no proper sequential process with the Oyster Point development. The baseline studies are being conducted concurrently with the development proceeding. I indicated from early days that I had very serious concerns about this development, and so did my portfolio. Time and time again we indicated the sorts of concerns we expressed about the possible impact of this development on World Heritage values. I indicated again to my Queensland counterpart, Molly Robson, on 29 September that I retained a number of serious concerns about the proposed development. In my letter I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, it appears to me that insufficient environmental assessment has occurred in relation to the proposal. This now manifests itself in the need for a detailed assessment of the baseline state of the environment that will be impacted by the proposed development.
I went on to say:
It has also led to the situation where studies are proposed concurrently with construction activities, rather than a proper sequential process . . .

The Commonwealth has always made its position on this matter absolutely clear. The portfolio agencies of the department of the environment have indicated their concerns over many months to Queensland authorities and I certainly have expressed mine to my counterpart in Queensland, Ms Robson.

PARA.TAB: I have also indicated, as every honourable senator in this chamber knows, that it has not been my intention to see this development stop. But I do not intend to see a situation where the development proceeds to damage or destroy the Great Barrier Reef. It just so happens that there is an environment minister on this side of the chamber who, unlike those opposite, takes seriously the obligations and responsibilities to protect these sensitive environments. I will not be resiling one inch from that. I will continue to protect and defend World Heritage values.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, Senator Ian Macdonald continues to talk about the lack of credible scientific evidence to support the position taken by the federal government and supported by others in this place. I wonder what it will take to convince Senator Macdonald. There are 160 scientists—doctors, masters and professors—mostly biologists, from institutions all over Australia who have written to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, expressing concern about this project. The scientific panel vindicated his position and I have seen many reports that also support his cautious approach.

PARA.TAB: The Valentine report, commissioned by the federal government, highlights the impact on World Heritage values, and concludes by saying that `the tenor, style and scale of this proposal are at serious odds with the values of conservation at this location'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been discredited.

—But just to satisfy Senator Macdonald, and Senator Parer, I will table another report. The state government of Queensland was strangely quiet about the Valentine report. We know it had engaged its own consultants, Loder and Bayley, to do a state report on the World Heritage values. Maybe it was trying to discredit Mr Valentine.

PARA.TAB: However, last Friday we received some FOI documents from the Premier's office in Brisbane. One of the documents was titled A Review of the Draft Valentine Report regarding the world heritage values and the Oyster Point Proposal, written and undertaken by John Wood of the Loder and Bayley Consulting Group. That report said that Peter Valentine was well qualified to do the assessment; that he worked through the issues in a systematic and thorough way; and `that in the absence of a public environmental impact assessment process, the conservative application of the precautionary principle is an understandable response to the uncertainties surrounding the proposal'.
In fact, when we read the document we find that the consultants agreed with nearly everything that Mr Valentine said. I quote from the Loder and Bayley review:

SPEECH.PARA: We agree with the Valentine report regarding the inadequacies of the EIS process, the lack of adequate baseline data, the lack of project detail, and the nature of the likely impacts.
So the Queensland government's own consultants agreed with Mr Valentine. No wonder it has kept it secret till now!

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald still does not understand that we are now in the 1990s. We cannot rob Peter to pay Paul. We cannot go ahead and develop without assessing the costs and minimising the impacts first. The Queensland government has tried to get away with fast-tracking a development and hoping that the public would not realise that it was taking such short cuts.

It does not have to be this way. We can have jobs and environment. We can have development. But we have to be realistic about the costs and the benefits. What is the net benefit of another resort like the ones we can find anywhere in Waikiki, Bali or on the Gold Coast? What is the net benefit after we take out the loss of the integrity of Hinchinbrook Island and the surrounding national parks, the cost of turbidity in the channel, the loss of species, the cost of the infrastructure falling on the state and the Cardwell shire, and the cost to the residents through rate hikes, increased land valuations and increased rents?

The public are more enlightened about environmental matters these days. They expect jobs but they also expect to have environmental integrity with economic prosperity. We have a choice. Either we ensure that our processes supply this or we can continue to go the way of the Queensland government and divide people. As we have seen with Hinchinbrook, it is far more economically and image damaging to ignore proper processes.

Senator Macdonald should be concentrating on that if he is focusing on the economics. The truth was always going to come out. It is better to ensure that we have the best type of development with the least impact on our environment from the start. Then developers know where they are instead of being in the dark, the federal government will not have to let the world know that the states cannot protect their environment, the community will know where it stands instead of succumbing to unsubstantiated promises, and everyone will be happy. I seek leave to table the document that I mentioned in the course of my remarks.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I could not help but note that when the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, talked about receiving scientific information to the effect that mangroves clearing may damage the Hinchinbrook Channel, he talked about expert advice which has since been totally discredited by the committee.Senator Faulkner has allowed himself to become the tool of extremist obstructionists. In fact, the genuine environmental scientists look on him as a laughing stock. There is no doubt about that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner actually said that his actions were supported by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I heard Senator Ian Macdonald ask him a number of times by way of interjection to provide a letter from that authority supporting that claim. Senator Faulkner ignored the interjections. On my reading of the situation, he probably does not have a letter because, if he did, he would present it.

When this issue blew up, some of us—including Senator Macdonald and myself—went to Oyster Point and had a look. That was the least we could do. But here was a minister who had stopped a $100 million tourist resort with a stroke of a pen and had not been to the site. He had not gone up and had a look himself. I am not a marine scientist, neither is Senator Macdonald—

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously.

—And neither is Senator Reynolds. But there are some lunatics at James Cook University who call themselves environmental lawyers and who pretend to be scientists. That is the problem. Those opposite have engineered those people. They got the numbers, they went around academe—we all know this is part of the game—and they got a list of names. Then they went off to Senator Faulkner and said, `Let's stop a $100 million resort.' But not once did this minister, who was stopping a resort, go and have a look.

PARA.TAB: I went and had a look. I went up with an open mind. There is not a person in this place who does not appreciate the Great Barrier Reef, the environment and the importance of it. In my earlier career, going back to the 1970s, I remember putting great restrictions on vessels coming into Mackay because they went through the Great Barrier Reef. We all have that sensitivity, but it is a matter of balance and commonsense.

When I went up, I took some photographs. I could not believe that this was the area being disputed. This is an area that was cleared seven years ago. It looks like a bomb site. The whole thing had been devastated. When I went to look at the mangroves I was expecting to see the big banks that we see from Moreton Bay through to Cape York and up into Papua New Guinea. I found an area of about 100 metres in length by 1.5 to two metres in width. Yet it was the clearing of this area that Senator Faulkner went to the Governor-General to have stopped. As I said, Senator Faulkner did not have the guts to go up himself. He should go up now and apologise to an awful lot of decent people who saw their future in this resort development.

The ironic thing about this whole matter is confirmed by Senator Faulkner's mate Dr Valentine. We now have a problem there that we would not have had if Senator Faulkner had not done what he did. Neither the minister nor Dr Valentine realised that the damage had been done—as I mentioned. The mangroves had gone and the only hope of avoiding the disaster that Dr Valentine warned about and that Minister Faulkner was using as his excuse to pander to these extremist obstructionists was for Mr Williams to proceed to stabilise the site. That was the key thing that had to be done.

The other thing that was very disturbing was the behaviour of the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee). When I was at Port Hinchinbrook I said, `Do you know we have a minister for tourism?' The people there said, `No, who is he? We would have thought that, particularly because of the predicted lack of resort accommodation in the north and far north of Queensland, the Minister for Tourism would at least show some interest.' Whether he agreed or disagreed with the development is immaterial. He would be expected to show some interest. He is very quick off the mark in going to conferences and taking credit for the success of other people in the tourism development that has occurred over the last decade and for which this country is very grateful.

But the silence on Port Hinchinbrook and Oyster Point from the Minister for Tourism, Mr Lee, was deafening. He did not show one bit of interest. He was keeping any interest to himself. Yet he is supposed to represent the industry which is the fastest growing industry in Australia and which has the potential to pick up and give jobs to a lot of the unemployed.

The developer, Mr Williams—whom I have met for only half a minute once in my life—has inherited a site which has been devastated. The damage had already been done. He spent months dotting his i's and crossing his t's and getting agreements with the Queensland government which had approved the site seven or eight years ago. He scaled his development down to 750 rooms. It would have meant employment during the construction period of up to 1,000 people and ongoing employment of 500 to 600 people—in a community of about 1,200 people. They did not know of any other developments in the area with the potential to provide them and their children with the long-term jobs that come with this sort of operation.

The town has very few jobs to offer. We have all had letters over this period from people arguing about the importance of this development. No-one disputes the fact that development has to be done in an environmentally sensitive way—there is no dispute from our side on that—but there has to be a balance. This whole matter was grossly unbalanced because the minister tried to make a name for himself. To see why he did that senators should look at the Bulletin from three weeks ago. In it, Senator Richardson said that Senator Faulkner had to make a name for himself. He could not do it in Tasmania because the Labor government made a deal with the Tasmanians not to pinch any more land. So if he wanted to make a name for himself Senator Richardson said that Senator Faulkner should look at Oyster Point up at Port Hinchinbrook. But he picked the wrong site. If Senator Faulkner had looked at it—and if he had half a brain—there is no way in the world he would have gone down the track on that one. All he has done is show his gross ineptitude and his appalling mismanagement. He picked the wrong place on which to make a macho stand to appease the extreme obstructionists. For these reasons he should resign; and if he does not resign, he should be sacked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been unable to work out just what Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Parer stand for in regard to the protection of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. It seems they want to use the platitude, `We believe in the environment; we believe in balance,' but they are prepared to ignore the facts that have been presented so many times in this place. Nevertheless, I will endeavour to restate some of those facts.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has acted totally in accordance with his responsibilities. His responsibility is to protect World Heritage values. He has worked consistently with the Queensland government, with scientists and with the developer because he wants the very balance that Senator Parer talks about. It is not his wish—nor has it ever been—to stop the development. He merely wanted to ensure that the developer worked with due consideration for World Heritage values. I do not know why I—and not the senator opposite—have to keep saying that there was no environmental assessment of this project. Senator Macdonald keeps defending the fact; but I really think our positions should be reversed.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an assessment.

—There was not; there was an environmental review. The department conducted its review in June 1994 using a draft report. There were some 192 highly critical submissions, including a Commonwealth one, expressing serious concern about several aspects. If the Coordinator-General had responded appropriately then, we would not have had this debate or the proclamation. Very clearly, the fault lies with the office of the Coordinator-General. He was so enthusiastic about wanting to get this development up and running that he and the department forgot to take into account World Heritage values. The department's final report, which is supposed to take account those submissions, has not even been made public. The deed of agreement drawn up between the government and the developer remained secret for some time.

PARA.TAB: The department, as recently as last week, gave a fascinating explanation when asked why the departmental review route was preferred to the standard environmental assessment. Departmental sources said, `Environmental impact assessments are inherently corrupt. Developers pay for them then governments have to get in and fix them.' That really makes me wonder about the attitudes in sections of that department in Queensland if, after all of this, it is doubtful about the need for an environmental impact study.

It is not only that we should be looking at the processes involved with Queensland's responsibilities; we should be looking at the precedent that Mr Williams established in going ahead with his Hamilton Island resort. Let us look at how successful that has been by 1990s standards. In the 1980s it was okay for Mr Williams to bulldoze the top off a mountain, clear the site and build a concrete jungle which we now call Hamilton Island. But let us consider what has happened. Hamilton Island Ltd was struggling to attract visitors and was unprepared to handle its own forecasts of increased demand, Island Traders said in a recent report.

Concerns were raised. They include lack of planning or initiative by the board, lack of staff accommodation—about five per cent of the resort's rooms were occupied by employees—undrinkable tap water, buildings such as restaurants which were a health hazard and in need of immediate repair and inadequate sewerage treatment facilities. I say to Senator Macdonald and Senator Parer that that is precisely why a full environmental and social impact assessment of the Oyster Point resort should have been done, but not because there is anything wrong with putting a resort on that site. A resort on that site is most appropriate but it has to be the right kind of resort. It has to be run in harmony with the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you changed your mind on that?

—I have always said that an appropriate development there would have my support, but not one that is simply recreating images of Hawaii and more concrete. We need to learn the lessons that were pointed out in a recent report which says that Queensland is missing out on the boom in ecotourism. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: NORTH Queensland offered numerous opportunities for ecotourism resort developments despite the Cardwell controversy, Brisbane-based architect David Toohey said yesterday.

PARA.TAB: But institutions and investors appeared reluctant to support ecotourism-linked projects and Queensland risked being left behind by overseas rivals, particularly south-east Asian countries, Mr Toohey . . . said.
He said the recent international Sustainable Design and Ecotourism seminar in Hobart was told the ecotourism industry was worth $320 billion world-wide this year.
The Australian industry was worth $100 million and was growing at three times the rate of traditional tourism, but more work needed to be done to encourage ecotourism . . .

SPEECH.PARA: This is what we should be emphasising. We should be emphasising to Mr Williams that this is in his interests. I do not know why I am constantly advising Mr Williams about the best way to go ahead with his resort—that is not my role—but Mr Williams would have a much more attractive resort if he would listen to ecotourism developers, take advice and learn that the 1980s style that he got away with on Hamilton Island and was acceptable in those days is now certainly not acceptable and not profitable because the world has changed. Yes, people want to go and stay at resorts, but they want resorts that are in harmony with the environment.

PARA.TAB: Mr Williams has this magnificent site with the potential for a unique resort, and he wants to put a beach on Hinchinbrook Channel. I challenge all Queensland senators on the opposition side to say whether they would swim in Hinchinbrook Channel just off Oyster Point. I ask Senator O'Chee whether he would swim in Hinchinbrook Channel just off Oyster Point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have.

—Senator Macdonald is a braver person than I am. People would have to deal with the sandflies, they would have to deal with marine stingers at certain times of the year and they would have to deal with the threat of crocodiles in that area, so I am amazed that Mr Williams continues to persist with this idea that he must have a beach on the Hinchinbrook Channel. What he needs to do is take his visitors across to the magnificent beaches on Hinchinbrook Island.
—That is where I have swum, actually.

—Yes, that is what I thought. Senator Macdonald has talked yet again about Senator Faulkner being responsible for division, for the loss of jobs, et cetera. The answer lies with Mr Williams himself. He stopped his development. He can go ahead, provided he goes ahead within the criteria set down by Minister Faulkner and Minister Robson. That would be in his best economic interests because he will have a resort that 1990s tourists want to go to.

PARA.TAB: Finally, while I accept there has been division in the Cardwell community, it is important to note that as recently as last week three mediators from the community justice program were in Cardwell in response to a call that I made a couple of weekends ago because I was so concerned and that community healing is taking place. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My friend on the other side of the chamber, Senator Reynolds, has just told the Senate that one of the problems with ecotourism in Queensland—and she quoted a Brisbane architect—was the reluctance of people to invest in ecotourism. I put the question to the Senate: why is it that investors are unwilling to put up their money to invest in ecotourism? The reason why it is so difficult to attract investors to the tourism sector generally and to ecotourism in particular is that they have to deal with a federal government which is indecisive, which is unclear in terms of its direction and which adds immensely to the costs for investors every time a federal minister intervenes, as Senator Faulkner has done, in the middle of the development of a project.

PARA.TAB: The key point is simply this: Senator Faulkner had the opportunity, when he was sent the draft tripartite deed, to peruse the deed, to make whatever comments he wanted and to apply whatever conditions he thought were appropriate under the federal legislation—at that point in time. But Senator Faulkner did nothing to make the Commonwealth's intentions clear. Senator Faulkner allowed the deed to be signed. Then, in the dead of night, Senator Faulkner rushed across to Yarralumla and had the Governor-General sign orders which prohibited further work on the development, and that was the end of that. The project has remained there ever since, because Senator Faulkner could not get it clear to start with about which rules were to apply to this particular development. That is where Senator Faulkner is to blame, and that is what is driving away investors from this sector: they have to deal with a government that cannot make up its mind.

Senator Reynolds has said that there was a flaw in the process. I heard Senator Faulkner say that as well. He said that there was a flaw in the process because the necessary environmental studies were not sufficient. There are two comments to be made on that. The first is this: zoning approvals and all necessary approvals were already in place for this development, except the approval in relation to the channel. So it is a nonsense to say that it was necessary to have an environmental impact study done because the environmental impact study would have applied principally to the zoning of the land and the application for the resort, and that was already in place. So it is absolutely ludicrous for Senator Faulkner to now say, `Oh, but we didn't have an environmental impact study.'

The other point to make is this: if Senator Faulkner is now of the view that there should have been an environmental impact study, why was he not of the view when he received the draft tripartite deed that there should have been an environmental impact study? Did Senator Faulkner say at that point that there should be an environmental impact study? No, Senator Faulkner was silent on the issue. It is no excuse for the minister to change his mind and say that this should have been done or that should have been done when Senator Faulkner had the opportunity to do so.

This matter of public importance addresses the whole issue of investor confidence. It addresses how difficult it is to attract new funds, to attract new investors and to attract people who want to build resorts and who want to create jobs when we have a federal government that does not understand how business works. Business works on a very simple proposition: it has a certain amount of risk capital. But the pool is not endless.

One developer on the False Cape project near Cairns said to me last week, `We are happy to put up the $600,000 necessary for the study that the government wants for our approval for the marina. But what we don't want to do is get to the stage where the federal government takes nine months to look at the study and then decides it wants further studies. We can live with losing $600,000, but we cannot live with losing $600,000 and then being asked to put up more money.' Business wants to know very simply: is a project to go ahead or is it not to go ahead? Business wants one simple thing from government: a minister who can make up his mind at the very beginning.

What we have in Senator Faulkner is a minister who is incapable of making up his mind. Senator Faulkner does not have the courage to make a decision. That is why we have the ongoing discussions with Minister Robson in Queensland; that is why we have the ongoing dillydallying backwards and forwards and the ongoing reports.

It is business that suffers. This development is losing thousands and thousands of dollars every day in holding costs while Senator Faulkner dithers on the issue. Other projects such as False Cape will be held up because Senator Faulkner simply cannot answer correspondence when he is requested to give some assurances as to how long it is going to take the Commonwealth to make up its mind on approvals. Other projects will not go ahead. Because of the indecision of this minister this country will suffer, the people of Queensland will suffer and the tourism sector generally will suffer. I say to Senator Faulkner, as I say to all senators, there is far too much suffering. It is time that the minister had the courage to make some decisions and let this project go ahead for the good of all concerned and for the good of the people of Far North Queensland.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! The time for consideration of the matter of public importance has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a resolution of the Republic of Portugal Assembly relating to the third anniversary of the Dili massacre.
—I present a response by the Ambassador of the People's Republic of China to the resolution of the Senate of 14 November 1994 concerning human rights in Tibet.
—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present Auditor-General's report No. 11 of 1994-95: Project Audit—ANL—Valuation Issues.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Ian Macdonald)—by leave—proposed:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the motion to take note of Auditor-General's report No. 11 on ANL valuation issues. Honourable senators will recall that the issue of valuation issues was very prominent in the media a few months ago because of the actions of the government, and in particular Minister Brereton, with regard to the potential sale of the ANL shipping line. I have had no time to examine in detail or to analyse the report that has just been handed down. Therefore, on this occasion I want to make just some brief comments about it.

PARA.TAB: The report makes clear—those who have been involved in looking at ANL have known this all along—that we get different numbers with regard to valuations, depending on the way valuations are carried out. It also reconciles the various valuations that have been carried out of the company, both as a going concern and as a wind-down.

In table 1 on page 12 of the Auditor-General's report there is a reconciliation of the detail between the high valuation and low valuation of the shareholders' funds—that is, between the valuation run by Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers and the report of the ANL board. I do not want to comment further on the detail of that because that is not the important political issue. The important issue is really the responsibility of the minister in carrying out the process of the proposed sale of ANL.

Paragraph 4.13 on page 16 of the report indicates that those involved in the sale process can influence the perceptions of potential buyers, and that this can result in a lower price for the asset. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a perception that a seller is a forced or distressed seller the value obtained will be lower than that for a `going concern'. . . What is clear is that the actions and statements of those involved in the sale process can influence the perceptions of the market to the point where the seller will be perceived as a `distressed seller'. This is most likely to result in a lower price for the asset. For this reason it is important that public officials involved in the sale of Commonwealth assets at all times act with discretion in order not to prejudice the Commonwealth's position.
In other words, it is important not to prejudice the position of all taxpayers.

PARA.TAB: What have we had in the case of ANL? We have had a classic case of a minister, Minister Brereton, damaging the value of this asset. On 22 August, the day he sacked the board, he said we could not give ANL away. What could one do that would be more damaging to the sale of that asset? Regardless of whether the actual value of the asset in the final analysis, depending on bids we get in for it, is negative or positive, by hurting potential buyers, by giving the indication that this is a fire sale, definite damage was done to the asset values that we, the taxpayers of Australia, have in that asset, the ANL shipping line. I believe that that was the wrong thing to do.

Everyone in Australia understands the concept of buying and selling, be it for a house or a car. When we go through the process of selling a second-hand car, the last thing we do is tell everyone that it is worthless. We invite bids and give the facts but we do not make a value judgment prior to the sale. It is quite improper for a minister of the Crown to be doing that. That is what has happened here. I am pleased to see in section 4.11 of the report that the audit office is sufficiently concerned that it is conducting a further analysis of the sale process carried out by the departments of finance and transport. I think that is most important.

This minister has been a minister for disasters. In recent times we have been through the disaster of the industrial relations policy for Australia, which has again set Australia back; we have had the CAA disaster; currently we have the third runway disaster; and in September we had the disaster with regard to ANL. The audit office shows quite clearly in the paragraph I read out that there has been damage to the perceptions of potential buyers in the marketplace of the value of those assets.

Attached to the report is a letter from, interestingly enough, the head of the Department of Finance, Mr Sedgwick. In that letter Mr Sedgwick makes it clear that he wants to distance his department and his officers from the final paragraph in the audit office's report—in other words, that it has been a distress sale and that actions by public officials involved could prejudice the value of those assets. Mr Sedgwick does not disagree with the substance of that paragraph but I gather from what he says that he is endeavouring to distance his office and his officers from what has happened. But that does not absolve the minister. It is the minister who made the damaging statements that the asset could not be given away. It is the minister who is responsible.

The correspondence between the minister and the ANL board, which was tabled in the Senate in the last couple of months, shows quite clearly that there was severe conflict between the old ANL board and the minister, and the minister was obviously not being cooperative. The facts of life are that when we look back we see it was the minister—therefore, the government—who changed the articles of association of that company back in February of this year. The government changed the articles of association.

So any action or decision by the board of ANL that may affect the long-term sale value of that asset must go back to the minister for agreement before the board can proceed. In effect, that meant the board was no longer operating as a board. It was, in fact, the minister operating as the chief executive of the company. As the correspondence which has been tabled in this place makes quite clear, for several months there was lack of communication or lack of agreement from the minister about requests made by the old board of ANL for decisions by the minister, which he did not fulfil.

So we have this minister who, I think, has really let Australian taxpayers down very severely. The opposition is in favour of privatising the ANL shipping line, but we are in favour of doing it through proper process. This indicates that the minister has not followed proper process and, as has been made quite clear in the audit report today, we believe it is the minister who has been responsible for down selling the value of the ANL assets. I am pleased that the audit office is going on and looking at the actual proper process—the process actually carried out by the two departments for the sale of those assets—to make sure that actual proper process has been carried out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add one thing. I support everything that Senator Gibson has said and I stress that the role of the Secretary to the Department of Finance is clearly to try to defend officials, which of course points the finger directly at the minister. I am not happy that the Secretary to the Department of Finance thought the best way to resolve this problem was to excise, to delete, the paragraph from the report. I think that would have been a wrong course of action for the Auditor-General to have taken.

PARA.TAB: It would have been appropriate, if the Auditor-General believed it to be so, that he perhaps could have added that there is no evidence that officials have acted in an indiscreet manner in this case. That might be a fair point. On the other hand, I do not know whether it is so. That is simply what is being asserted by the Department of Finance. In any event, the point is that the Department of Finance secretary is clearly, in effect, pointing the finger at the minister and nobody else, no officials.

However, there are two other points I would like to take up. Firstly, I totally acknowledge the point the Auditor-General has made that the difference between the valuations of the ANL as a going concern and that of it on a distress sale breakup basis are obviously very substantial. I see nothing improper about the Auditor-General's positive valuation, if we can call it that, of endorsing the board's view of what the company was worth as a going concern. It is natural that the much lower value, the minus value, on a distressed sale basis—which is the basis on which the Price Waterhouse and Salomon Brothers report was based—significantly reduced the estimated values by a respected valuer.

Secondly, the Auditor-General quite properly points out that he does not have enough power in these cases. That, I think, is a serious matter that the Senate ought to address itself to. On page 15, paragraph 4.12, the Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO's mandate currently does not allow it to conduct efficiency audits on GBE's like ANL without the approval of the relevant Minister.
The minister is the bloke who made the blue, so we are not likely to get him to give such approval. Then he goes on:

The new Auditor-General Act proposes to extend this to allow both Houses of Parliament to empower the Auditor-General to perform a specific audit. This does not go as far as the JCPA recommended in 1989 viz:
section 48C of the Audit Act 1901 to be amended to permit the Auditor-General to conduct a performance audit of an eligible corporation without a Minister's permission,
It goes on:
Clause 15(2) of the Auditor-General Bill should be amended to state that the Auditor-General may conduct a performance audit of a Commonwealth company that is a GBE, or any of its subsidiaries, if:
(a) both Houses of the Parliament, by resolution, request the audit; or
(b) the responsible Minister requests the audit; or
(c) an audit committee of Parliament requests the audit.

In other words, there should be power to the parliament. The Auditor-General should be responsible to the parliament. It should not be under the dictatorial control of any minister because we have seen how incompetent some of the ministers are in this government, particularly this accident-prone minister and his predecessor. The Auditor-General goes on in his report:

The current legislative proposals are unsatisfactory. The Auditor-General should not be constrained from being able to undertake quickly the necessary preliminary work in order to decide whether or not investigations required to prepare a report to Parliament should be undertaken and to undertake such work. The normal financial statement mandate, even if clear and unchallenged (which it has not been for the ANAO for some years) cannot provide an appropriate legal and practical basis for effective reporting to Parliament on all aspects of potential interest to it of a GBE's use of public monies and resources.

Hear, hear! The thing is that we have here a very large government business enterprise on which the government is now facing enormous losses if it is able to dispose of its asset—which was not, in fact, earning profits; has had a history of serious difficulties; and, of course, has had the misfortune to have incompetent ministers in charge of it.

PARA.TAB: I commend to the government the recommendations by the Auditor-General conveyed here. He should have greater power to investigate the financial situation of GBEs in terms of efficiency audits. I urge the government to take action. I do not expect it to, but I urge it to.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, I present the report of the committee entitled Operation and effectiveness of the child support scheme, together with submissions, transcript of evidence, minutes of proceedings and a summary document. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this, for those of us who have been serving on this committee, is a very significant day. It is a report that has taken quite a bit of time, and certainly a great deal of application by a lot of people. Before I get into the detail of the report, I think it is important that I mention those who, in fact, have been very involved and committed, other than those of us who were actually the members of the committee. It is often the case that the staff of the secretariat are left to last. In this case I say that they should be mentioned first.

PARA.TAB: Robina Mills was secretary of the committee for one year. Subsequent to that Jane Vincent became secretary—a difficult job to take over two-thirds of the way through a report and then be responsible for the report itself. Other staff members include Matthew Mason-Cox, David Wallace, Susan Cardell, Lesley Cowan, Debbie Devlin, Laura Gillies, Denise Picker, Kerry Warner and Geraldine Windsor.

In recent weeks, the secretariat members have worked above and beyond the call of duty by any standard. They have worked at nights and on weekends, making it possible for us to present the report today, 5 December. Without such commitment, it would not have been possible to complete a report this size and present it this year. It is not a case of our not wanting to or our arguing about it, but the amount of detail that had to be looked at and attended to was very large. This committee has received submissions in excess of the number received by any other parliamentary committee—6,197.

This inquiry came about from the Family Law Act review and a report entitled Aspects of its operation and interpretation—A report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, which was presented in the parliament in November 1992. There were many very significant recommendations in that report. The government has responded to them and now has before the parliament legislation arising from them.

One of the conclusions of that report, which appeared in chapter 16.29, relates to the committee's concern about submissions we received involving the child support scheme. The scheme was not part of the review of the Family Law Act; it has been set up under separate legislation. We received many submissions relating to the operation of the scheme. People's unhappiness with it and the fact that they were being forced to pay maintenance but were not able to get access to their children was an issue frequently brought to our attention. We said in that report in November 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's major concern is that in many cases the non-custodial parent is bearing a disproportionate cost of maintaining the children.
The committee was concerned about the intent that was put to us at the time. We also said:

The Committee considers that the Government as a matter of urgency must address the anomalies currently inherent in the Child Support Scheme so that both parents share an equitable burden of the cost of supporting their children after marriage breakdown.

All of us who worked on that committee were very pleased when, after the election in May 1993, when the parliament resumed, the committee was asked to review the child support legislation. The purpose of the child support legislation was to ensure that children are provided for by both parents. It came into the parliament during the 1980s. At the time, a number of us had some misgivings about how it might operate and what its impact would be. I think we said at the time that it should be reviewed—and certainly it should have been—but neither I nor any member of the committee came to the view that the scheme should in any way be abandoned. The concept is sound. It needs to be made to work properly.

PARA.TAB: The committee looked at the priorities of the scheme, what we felt was important about it and what tests we would use to determine how we would come to conclusions. They were in this order: that there should be adequate support for children; that the non-custodial parent should contribute to the cost of children; and that the Commonwealth's burden for supporting the children of a broken marriage who are living with a sole parent pensioner should be reduced as much as possible, although it was not the first consideration.

When I talk about the Commonwealth's responsibility, I remind the Senate that we are talking about the responsibility of one group of taxpayers for the liability of other people's children. I do not think the committee strayed from those three criteria in determining the 163 recommendations contained in this report. It is not possible or sensible to review 163 recommendations in speaking to the Senate this afternoon. I am sure that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would not want me to. However, I will speak about some of the things from the report that I think are important.

The message from the child support legislation of the 1980s, reconfirmed in this report being presented now, is that those who have children have the prime responsibility for supporting them. Other taxpayers will help as is required after that first test has been met. No senator in this place or a member in the other place has not had many representations from constituents about this scheme and its impact on both custodial parents and non-custodial parents. They fall into different categories. None of us would not have met constituents with enormous concern and anguish—I am thinking about non-custodial parents in particular at the present time—whose lives have been effectively shattered by the impact of this legislation from several points of view.

The way it has operated has frequently meant that the first people hear about their liability for maintenance is in a letter they receive from the Child Support Agency, a section of the Taxation Office, telling them that they already owe anything from about $1,100 to $1,600. That is one of the principal reasons why it has been almost impossible to get people to understand what the scheme is about and why it was meant to be operating as it was.

To start anything off with a debt of that size is absolutely hopeless. It has made it impossible for a man in that situation to reorganise his life in any way, having already gone through the shattering and traumatic experience of divorce. He has frequently been left with very little money to live on because of the other debts and commitments that he may have which, quite properly, are not really taken into account in assessing the formula. But that is the consequence of it. Most of all, the unhappiness of people who are being forced to pay maintenance without getting access to their children is very significant. That is the thrust of the first report I mentioned. It is still a real problem in this area.

I know people will say that a parent has a responsibility to support children. That is so, but the impact and attitude of a parent thus required to pay maintenance who is not able to get access to the children are perfectly understandable and are a serious difficulty with the whole concept.

There are two parts to the review: a review of the formula under which maintenance is assessed; and the operation of the agency established within the Taxation Office that is administering the scheme. We have suggested that it be reviewed in a few years. My personal view is that the Taxation Office is the appropriate place for this scheme to be administered. But I certainly support the recommendations of the report requiring the agency to do it somewhat differently from the way that it has been done in the past.

The agency started off with a brand new scheme from a standing start. In most instances, such institutions would have to wait for their clients to come in. Not so in this instance, where it started off with nearly 24,000 clients, which made it extremely difficult. That number has now risen to about 275,000 clients, or perhaps even more by now. So the impact on those in the Taxation Office who were required to set it up and administer it was great indeed. I understand the problems they faced.

I think we can question whether they had adequate resources to do what they were required to do—that is, assess debt, collect money and pay it out—and whether they had received adequate training to do it. But the impression I have certainly formed from the constituents who come to my office is that attitude is perhaps the biggest problem. Often, a perfectly reasonable person who is quite happy to pay maintenance for his children on a proper basis complains of being made to feel like a criminal when dealing with the Child Support Agency. I regard that as being totally unacceptable.

In my view, the Child Support Agency within the Taxation Office is required to regard both custodial and non-custodial parents as clients and to deal with them fairly. I have no doubt, from the number of complaints that I received about the way that people were treated, that it was not people's imagination, that people were made to feel like criminals and made to feel that they were in the wrong when they made inquiries and in many other ways. We have recommended that in the future the office have people responsible for cases so that what has happened in the past stops. If people ring up—anyone listening may have had this experience—they are never able to get on to anyone in the agency who can really understand a question or answer it. There have been instances of explanations being given by one office which were different from those given by another office. There are many things which I will not go into in much more detail. But the operation of the scheme must be carried out differently.

I draw the Senate's attention to the recommendations that we have made in the report. The initial operation of the recommendations will mean that the custodial parent should receive money more regularly and sooner and not have the incredible delays that some people have experienced in getting money that has been paid to the office. Most importantly, our recommendations will mean that a person encountering the scheme for the first time will not be met with such a debt as has occurred in the past. Those non-custodial parents will have a better right of appeal and review than has happened previously.

We also want to encourage voluntary compliance with the act. I believe that many more people would pay and would accept their responsibility to pay and that it is not necessary to divert so much of the agency's resources to collecting funds as is happening at present—withholding from wages and things of that nature. With regard to those who do not pay, we have very strict views on how they should be dealt with. But I think there is a great deal of room to encourage people to do this on a voluntary basis. People should be able to ring up the agency and find out what they have to pay, pay it and effectively have no involvement with the agency.

I believe there has been a change in community attitude so that there is now acceptance that non-custodial parents do become responsible for paying maintenance for their children. I feel quite confident that voluntary compliance will become more prevalent and the agency can then get on with dealing with the difficult cases and with the defaulters.

A particular area of concern is that most of my constituents are PAYE taxpayers who can be fairly easily caught up with under the scheme. But it was clear from a number of points of view that some people are able to avoid paying or are able to keep their income down. We have made recommendations that the Taxation Office should make assessments and deal with non-PAYE non-custodial parents more efficiently than has been the case in the past.

My attention was drawn to that matter during the phone-in that we conducted. It might be recalled that in July 1993 we had a phone-in in which thousands of calls came into the building. We reported to the parliament in a little document called Thanks for listening. A number of the people to whom I spoke were not getting the maintenance that they ought to have been getting because the non-custodial parents were not PAYE taxpayers. There are ways of protecting self-employed people who are very low income earners and those who are not, and we have dealt with that matter.

This package of 163 recommendations is interlinked. When we deal with the formula, a dollar here or a dollar there can make a great deal of difference. We have made recommendations for changes to the formula. We have said that that which has been called, for a non-custodial parent, a self-support component is not in fact a self-support component. It is an amount of income that should be disregarded before the formula operates. It might be thought that that is just playing with words but in fact it is a little more than that. When we look at the formula, we see that the amount of income disregarded is not the only amount left for a person to live on. There is money at the other end as well. However, we have recommended that the amount of disregarded income be increased—not by a huge amount, not by as much as some people would have liked, but by a reasonable amount which will make a difference. But it must be balanced at both ends. The whole package of recommendations must be integrated.

We have made a recommendation with regard to the income of the custodial parent that should be disregarded. We have made a significant recommendation relating to income earned by a custodial parent—that, for every $1 increase above the disregarded income level, the reduction should be only 50c, not $1. We were anxious to make sure that there were not disincentives for custodial parents to return to the work force. We wanted to make sure that we minimised any poverty traps which can always occur when dealing with social welfare payments.We have included fringe benefits to be assessed as part of income when determining the amount which should be paid.

As I have said, I have only touched the surface of the 163 recommendations which are now before the government. I urge the government to consider them quickly and to bring in legislation in accordance with the recommendations in order to make changes which I believe are very necessary for this community, as there are a lot of very unhappy people.

There are many other things that I would like to say but I will conclude so that others can speak. I say to men and boys in particular that if they have a one-night stand and they become the father of a child, they will be paying for it. I can vividly recall one young man who certainly got caught, probably deliberately. I did not doubt his story at all. But there is no way that this scheme can be made to work if we start to make that sort of exception. People need to know that if men father a child, they will be paying for it, not their neighbour, their friends or some other taxpayer.

We had difficulty with the concept of re-partnering—the impact on that family if a man re-partners with a woman, when he is paying maintenance for his child under the scheme, but she has children with her and for some reason is not receiving maintenance. Not every problem—and they are real problems—can be corrected. We have not been able to do so. I have no doubt that some people will be disappointed that we have not gone far enough, done enough or included everybody. But if people read the whole report, or even just the whole of the recommendations and conclusions, they will see the logic behind what we have done in preserving the concept of maintenance being paid, as set down in the legislation. They are recommendations which will make the administration of the scheme much better. There is a formula which, while not going as far as it might, will make a difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this report I would first like to thank the members of the secretariat, who have so ably and professionally assisted the work of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. I am sure they were instrumental in ensuring the production of such a high quality document which has canvassed so many complex issues in such a way as to highlight some real solutions to those problems. They may not be the solutions that everyone wants to see; they may not be the complete answers that we are looking for. But in terms of this report, they indicate a substantial body of work.

PARA.TAB: The research undertaken by the secretariat is in some cases probably the most up-to-date, most detailed research that has been undertaken in this area of family law. In terms of family studies, it is some of the most detailed research work that is available to date. In some senses it is difficult for other areas to challenge the expertise that has been available to this committee. Those involved in the professional areas of investigation could learn a substantial amount from the work undertaken by the secretariat of this committee.

Secondly, I would like to thank the other members of the committee I have worked with. It is one of the most beneficial committees I have been involved in in the period that I have been in this parliament. There have been very valuable meetings on a regular basis where people from all the different shades of opinion were able to speak freely to one another, communicate effectively and present quite complex and difficult issues to one another, and produce a result which is substantially agreed, with the odd difference which I am sure others will speak of.

The Child Support Agency has now been in operation for 6 1/2 years. It was established on 1 June 1988, and it is appropriate that this parliament undertake a comprehensive review of its operations. Given the level of public interest, as measured by the 6,197 submissions, it is quite clear that this review is long overdue. The largest number of submissions that has ever been received by a parliamentary committee was presented to this committee and reflected very deep concerns within the community about the nature of this scheme.

I would like to reiterate Senator Reid's comments. There is no-one on this committee who would challenge the benefits of the social reforms introduced by the establishment of the Child Support Agency. The fundamental commitment right across this parliament is to the continued work of the Child Support Agency. It has to be acknowledged that there have been enormous achievements in this area of social policy. However, I think it is also very important that parliament understands that the nature of the work we undertake in establishing government bodies like these has to be measured in terms of the impact on the community which is affected.

In this particular area of social policy we found that 90 per cent of custodial parents—a very large number of clients—are sole parent pensioners, extremely low income people. In terms of the non-custodial parents, 81 per cent of the client base earns less than average weekly earnings. The agency is a body that this parliament has established essentially to police the social, the economic, the familiar relationships between working class people in this country. It is a body that—whether or not we understood it the time—is effectively geared towards the very poorest and, in many respects, the weakest in our community. It is because of the nature of the issues that are involved—the protection of children and the provision of basic financial survival assistance for children and custodial and non-custodial parents—that we can understand that the stakes are very high.

The government—the state agency—has contact with people at a time in their lives, immediately after separation, often when they are undergoing a most severe trauma and when relationships and emotions are at their very rawest. It should be understood that emotions are going to be at their highest and levels of tension are going to be at their greatest. But we are also dealing with people who often are least able to express their demands and their grievances and defend their interests when it comes to dealing with the state apparatus. For me, it is a bit of a challenge in a personal sense because I am one of those who believe that the state is the best vehicle for liberating people and for ensuring that they get access to proper services, quality of life and adequate standards of living.

When the state operates as has occurred through this agency and becomes effectively a harsh, oppressive instrument, and people react in ways in which they are not able to defend themselves and which are often not in their own interests, it becomes quite a conflict for my philosophical position. This is a case where the state has not always been able to present the best possible position to ensure that people do have the best services that are available.

The committee has once again come up against that basic problem that in family law there are no absolutes. We have tried to provide a report which reflects the complexities of the issues, and provides real balance in the interests that are being expressed between separated and intact families, children of first and subsequent families, custodial and non-custodial parents and parents and taxpayers generally. This report seeks to establish a balance that allows for this complex interrelationship between social and economic forces that are measured in the way the state operates by instituting laws concerning taxation, social security, family law and the Child Support Scheme itself. It is in that context that we understand, when we say there have been some achievements, just how great those achievements have been.

The most fundamental achievement of all is that there has been a successful transformation in attitudes within this community about the way in which there should a universal system for the collection of child support and, therefore, a change in the attitudes about the way in which parents should take responsibility for the support of their children. We have discovered that this change in attitude has not necessarily been as a result of a perfect scheme. In fact, there are huge weaknesses in the way in which this scheme currently operates. I take the view that there has to be substantial reform to that scheme to protect a very valuable social reform in total.

What has to be understood is that because there are so many people trapped within the scheme who are often so weak, special measures have to be taken by the government to ensure that the interests of both custodial and non-custodial parents are protected. It is ironic that the wealthiest people in our society—the people that can afford the lawyers, and can afford and have access to the education and the various facilities that wealth brings with it—are able to stay outside of this scheme. So we have a scheme that is universal in theory that applies only to the poor. In that sense there is a fundamental inequity.

There are many other inequities in this scheme as it currently exists.
