Sir Ninian speaks about a democratic deficit in relation to treaty making activity.

PARA.TAB: I think it is a pity that this particular committee did not come to grips with this problem but tended to be dismissive. If we are dismissive of the problem, therefore it makes it more difficult to address the fundamental issues such as: what role should this parliament have in relation to treaty making activity? What role should the states have? What is the process of consultations with Australians? If we are worried about human rights, we are worried about the rights of Australians and the human rights of ordinary Australians to determine the laws which affect them. Therefore, it seems to me that this committee above all should have shown a bit more courage in addressing this issue.

Sir Ninian Stephen is not a member of the League of Rights. He is not renowned as a fanatic. Sir Ninian sees a problem with sovereignty. He sees a democratic deficit problem in relation to treaty making activity and he points our attention to the fact that other nations have been more effective in protecting their component parts than Australia has. If this committee is going to address treaty making and the roles of states, why did it shy away from the sort of analysis that Sir Ninian pointed us to?

Having said that, I accept that this committee has shown some movement. For example, honourable senators would be aware that there has been quite a bit of debate in this chamber and elsewhere about the procedures of UN human rights committees. Paragraph 2.30 in the committee's report says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this committee believes that the principles of natural justice should be incorporated into the proceedings.

That is, the proceedings of UN human rights committees. No-one would argue with that, but it is a pity that the committee did not assert that point more firmly in reaching its conclusions. It is true that it recognised that reform of the UN Human Rights Committee needs to occur and there is a recommendation to that effect. But the reform directs our attention to the independence of members of that committee from their governments. It points to a number of other procedural changes.

PARA.TAB: It did not strongly assert—as honourable senators would expect a human rights committee above all to assert—that natural justice should apply to these proceedings; that is, that it is the right of all defendants so described to appear, that hearings, where appropriate, should be held in public and that there be cross examination of witnesses—the sorts of things that we take for granted in this country. I regret that the committee shied away from this. I have to say that it went significantly further in conceding that there was a problem in this area than the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) was ever prepared to go.

I welcome that but, in my view, on that particular issue it simply did not bite the bullet with the facts staring it in the face. If people expect these committees to have a role in our legal system, it seems to me that the onus is on the committees to make sure that their procedures and membership meet Australian standards. I think the report shows that, regrettably, these committees simply do not meet Australian standards.

The other point I wish to comment briefly on is the role of the states in the treaty making activity. The government has tended to pretend that everything in this garden is pretty rosy and that extensive consultations occur with the states before treaties are signed. Of course, we know of some quite infamous cases where that did not happen. Just before the last election we saw a rash of treaty making activities which would cause concern to anyone interested in human rights and proper procedure.

This report illustrates, in an interesting manner, the problems which have occurred in the area of consultation with the states. I think this is a very valuable part of the report. Whereas Senator Evans and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) ceaselessly assure us that everything is all right, this report points to very real problems in this area. It recommends that parliament should have a greater role in treaty making activity. Recommendation 12 calls for:

SPEECH.PARA: the further streamlining of the processes of the Commonwealth/State Standing Committee on Treaties to improve the collection and dissemination of information between line departments and the coordinating agency at both the State and Commonwealth levels . . .
Recommendation 13 states:

The Committee strongly endorses the move to inform the Parliament at an early stage in the treaty making process by tabling treaties in the Parliament before signature and recommends that the Minister for Foreign Affairs should use the forum of the Parliament to raise international human rights issues.

I think that is good, and it is certainly a help. But it does not consider to any great extent the argument of whether the parliament should establish, for example, a treaties committee to examine more controversial treaties which are brought before the parliament, and it does not consider to any great extent whether parliament should have a legislative or veto role in relation to treaties. I think that is a pity.

PARA.TAB: The report points to real problems in relation to the states and treaty making activities. Honourable senators will be interested to read the evidence that was given by Senator Evans to the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee on Tuesday, 29 November. I am referring to page 158 of the transcript. I asked Senator Evans at what stage treaties would be laid on the table of parliament for debate. Senator Evans replied:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not proposing to make a commitment that the government will wait for any specified period of time following the tabling. The idea is to provide information to parliament about the treaties. We will do that through this tabling process and through the explanatory note that we have also agreed to make part of that process. But tabling treaties is not intended to be an exercise in ascertaining parliament's views about whether or not Australia should become a party.

TALK.START.PARA: —What date is that?
—This is on 29 November; just last week. Senator Evans goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: That decision is the responsibility of the executive under the Constitution, and it will remain so.

This committee has correctly seen the need to more appropriately involve parliament. I stress that the committee's recommendation is for the treaty to be laid on the table before signing. While this report was being printed, Senator Evans was pulling back, certainly in spirit, from the document which he and Mr Lavarch tabled with such fanfare in October and which dealt with Australia in relation to international treaty making.

PARA.TAB: This report, in looking at the relationship between the states and the Commonwealth, draws our attention to some real breakdowns and problems in this area. The people who put the report together probably thought the recommendations were in line with the new spirit of consulting parliament that they saw coming from Senator Evans and Mr Lavarch. I have to say that the Evans and Lavarch statement has turned out to be a damp squib. Senator Evans has pulled back from the spirit that he attempted to convey to the press at that time.
The final point I wish to make relates to the issue of sovereignty. Paragraph 2.31 of the committee's report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The independence and sovereignty of the nation state is preserved at a number of stages in the process. The state chooses to be bound by the treaty, it chooses to respond to the assessment of the committee and it also chooses the remedy it will apply, appropriate to its domestic legal or social framework.

The committee points to where there has been a treaty breach. Under international law, a country in breach of its international obligations is required to rectify that breach. Sir Ninian Stephen also addressed this issue in his speech. He spoke about the view that Australian sovereignty is protected because parliament must pass enacting legislation; in other words, we can go away and ratify the treaty, but do not worry, because parliament still has a role—it must pass the enacting legislation. Sir Ninian said:

The doctrine familiar to English law, though not applied in the US or in most continental legal systems, that treaties entered into by the executive do not have effect as law of the land unless implemented by legislation, may be thought to mitigate the absence of parliamentary consultation. The doctrine was an outcome of England's 17th century constitutional settlement, reflecting the desire to limit prerogative power and, in particular, the power of the crown to change the law of the land by a mere exercise of that prerogative. However its mitigating effect is reduced by the fact that, once the executive ratifies a treaty, so that the State becomes a party to it, the legislature will have little option but to enact any necessary enabling legislation; not to do so would be tantamount to repudiation, a failure to honour the country's international obligations.

I make that point to show that—with some of the real intellectual challenges in treaty making, with the appropriate processes as we approach the 21st century, and because we have a government which has shown enormous enthusiasm for international treaty making—it is a pity that the sort of analysis Sir Ninian laid down just some weeks before this report was tabled was not effectively addressed in this report. That is why I believe that in some areas the recommendations simply do not go far enough in relation to the treaty making processes and the role of UN human rights committees. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the seventh report of 1994, relating to the proposed new laboratory complex at DSTO, Salisbury, South Australia. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the tabling statement incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's seventh report of 1994 deals with the proposed construction of a new laboratory complex at DSTO Salisbury, SA.

DSTO Salisbury is located 22 kilometres north of Adelaide. It accommodates DSTO's Electronics and Surveillance Research Laboratory which primarily undertakes research into electronic-based Defence systems.
The present research facilities are spread over one thousand hectares and six hundred and fifty buildings, many of which were constructed for the manufacture of explosives in 1940.

The proposal examined by the Committee involves concentrating DSTO research activities into a two hundred and eighty hectare site and provide a new laboratory complex which will accommodate five hundred and forty five research and support staff.
The Committee has recommended that the project proceed at an estimated out-turn cost of $50.714 million.
The Committee concluded that facilities at DSTO Salisbury represent a substantial investment by the Commonwealth and occupy a much larger than necessary site.
The Committee notes that arising from the Defence White Paper there will be no change to the direction in which DSTO is proceeding nor will there be a change in the need for the laboratory complex.

The Committee was advised some six weeks after the public hearing that the plans and drawings of the proposed complex presented to it at the public hearing had been changed. The Committee was extremely concerned about the changes which were made to the design and made its displeasure known to Defence officials at a subsequent meeting at which the background and the substance of the changes were discussed.
The Committee concluded that the revised design represents a major departure from the design originally submitted to the Committee by the Department of Defence.

Whilst the Committee agrees that the revised design is an improvement, the circumstances surrounding the development of the original design lacked the rigorous analysis necessary for a special purpose building such as this.
For these reasons the Committee has recommended that Defence should review procedures for the testing of schematic designs against user requirements to minimise changes.
The Committee has also recommended that the Department of Defence should consult with staff associations regarding the revised design and report to the Committee about these consultations.
The question of the effectiveness of open plan offices in increasing productivity was raised by a number of staff associations during the public hearing.

The Committee believes the time has come for the Department of Defence to undertake or commission a study of the impact on staff efficiency and productivity of open planning and other forms of office accommodation. Other recommendations in the report deal with heritage matters, consultations with state and local governments and soil remediation of the greater Salisbury site.
I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO ESTONIA, LATVIA AND LITHUANIA AND THE 92ND INTER-PARLIAMENTARY CONFERENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and the 92nd Inter-Parliamentary Conference, and to move a motion and make a short statement in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and the 92nd Inter-Parliamentary Conference held in Copenhagen during September 1994, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the opportunity to say a few words about this particular report. I was deputy leader of the delegation, which was led by the Speaker, Mr Martin, and included Mr Harry Quick MP, the member for Franklin, Senator John Woodley from the Australian Democrats, and Bill Taylor, the member for Groom.

PARA.TAB: Our delegation to the Baltic states was the first parliamentary delegation to visit there since the states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania gained their independence. Whilst they may be old countries historically and have suffered many different regimes, Lithuania became an independent state in 1990 and the other two countries in 1991. As Australia was one of the first countries to recognise the independence of the Baltic states, it was most important that we showed in a more tangible way our support for their independence.

I would like to express on behalf of the delegation our appreciation to the chairs and members of the Riigikogu, which is the parliament of Estonia, the Saeima, which is the Latvian parliament, and the Seimas, which is the Lithuanian parliament. They went out of their way to extend to us very generous hospitality. I am pleased to say that one of the things we did while we were there was to offer an invitation to members of their parliament to visit us here. I am pleased to say that at the end of this week I will be hosting a dinner for the President of the Estonian parliament, Mr Ulo Nugis, and the Speaker will be having a lunch for him. I am pleased to see that the Estonians have accepted our invitation.

I would also like to thank Anne Hazelton, our secretary, for the wonderful work that she carries out. She not only has to put the reports together but also has to act as a girl Friday for all the wants and needs of a delegation.

During our visit it was interesting to note the situation the three Baltic states are in after only two or three years of parliamentary democracy—having been through similar problems to all the other states of the former Soviet Union—and to see what has happened with the breakdown of communism. There are similar problems with all the states.

Being a farmer myself, I was interested to note that, with collective farming breaking up, the people were having tremendous problems trying to establish ownership of land and to get their small family farms operating again. There was certainly—to the casual observer, anyway—a noted lack of stock in the paddocks. I suspect that they have either been eaten or sold, or both, because of the conditions that have existed there.

Nevertheless, we were very impressed with the advances and the pace with which those countries have moved since they have gained their independence. For instance, the Estonians are having elections in 1995. Their major concerns were the tensions between themselves and the state of Russia. They have a border dispute at the moment and they brought that forward to the IPU conference in Copenhagen.

One of the major concerns they have in Estonia is the issue of retired military personnel. It was an eye opener for all members of the delegation to visit a former military base that had been evacuated by the Russians only three days before. Not to put too fine a point on it, what was left was really a wasteland. It was a scene of total devastation. Everything that was nailed down was taken and everything that was not nailed down was taken—from taps to door handles. Even the culverts and pipes under the road were taken. Wash basins that we would not even consider using here were taken. Mirrors were taken off the walls. Everything that was of any basic use at all was taken. If they could have scraped the paint off the wall and taken it away, they probably would have. If that is any indication of the legacy of the Russian troop occupation—and I believe it is, because we heard similar stories in the other two Baltic states—and of what is left behind or not left behind, there is a problem.

Environmental damage was also occasioned by the occupying troops of the Soviet Union. For instance, in Estonia there were 570 military bases, so one can imagine the number of installations. When the occupying troops left, a lot of the officers retired. Up to 80 per cent of the Soviet forces stationed in Estonia were officers, and a lot of them have retired. Something like 10,500 retirees have been foisted upon the Estonian system. They are being paid a pension by the Russian government; nevertheless, it is causing some problems.

Likewise, the major problem in Latvia is that almost 50 per cent of the population is Russian speaking and is topped up with a lot of retired Russian military personnel. The parliament of Latvia has a preoccupation with what is going to happen with all these Russian speaking people. Will they form their own party and will they be subject to a similar situation they have been through? They, too, have the same problems we saw in Estonia, with the breakup of their farms.

The Australian government has programs of exchange with Latvian parliamentary people. I am pleased to say that not only have we invited the President of the Saeima to send a parliamentary delegation to Australia, but also Harry Quick and I have invited a member of the Latvian Farmers Union to visit Tasmania, and I believe that invitation has been accept ed.

In Lithuania, the problem with ex-Russians is not so great. Only 8.5 per cent of the population is Russian speaking. Lithuania was the first Baltic state to gain independence. We all remember the vivid scenes of confrontation culminating in the killing of 13 people by Soviet forces at the Vilnius television tower. We visited that site and it was a most moving experience. We also visited the Drobe woollen mill, which processes some 400 tonnes of Australian wool per year and is getting a lot of assistance from our technology. I was very impressed with that particular mill.

We were inspired by a living skills centre in Vilnius for children with intellectual and multiple disabilities. It was established primarily through the efforts of two Lithuanian-Australian women and funded largely by the Lithuanian community in Australia. It is a model for other centres that may open in the Baltic states. Until the centre was opened, the children were regarded as idiots; they were drugged and lived in appalling conditions. It was through the efforts of these two women—Dana Baltutis and Gaila Muceniakas, who are from South Australia—that this centre was started. We were most impressed with what they had achieved.

I am looking forward to again meeting the President of the Estonian parliament later this week. I hope that the very good links that exist between Australia and the Baltic states continue. After all is said and done, Australia was one of the first countries to recognise the independence of the Baltic states. While trade is growing from a low base, it is becoming reasonably important. The Baltic states are looking to us for support through the World Bank.

The 92nd Inter-Parliamentary Conference was held in Copenhagen. Here again, I believe our delegation was very successful. At the previous conference in Paris, the Australian delegation had flagged a supplementary agenda item, but we were unsuccessful in having it included. In Copenhagen we were successful in having included on the agenda a supplementary item concerning the implementation of commitments agreed to in the Uruguay Round of the multilateral trade negotiations. Given the debate on this particular matter this week, it is important for me to mention that our delegation was successful in getting substantial motions moved through the Inter-Parliamentary Union which were carried unanimously by 123 countries. Basically, they called on all these countries to ratify the agreements and to get moving as quickly as possible. The Speaker and I both spoke on these particular matters.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would know, the IPU also organises very important meetings for women parliamentarians. I am pleased to say that Kathy Sullivan, who has played a leading role for women parliamentarians in the IPU, attended under her own steam and did a great job.

The Hon. Clyde Holding represented us on the Human Rights for Parliamentarians Committee. He was obliged to attend as a substitute member at very short notice. He is held in very high regard by all countries and has a great knowledge of the abuse of human rights of parliamentarians around the world. I am quite surprised to learn that there are 88 former and serving parliamentarians in 14 countries who are either subject to disenfranchisement or are actually in gaol.

I am pleased to say that I was elected as a vice-chairperson of the Committee on Parliamentary, Juridical and Human Rights Questions. I will have to wait until the next conference to find out what that entails but at least it means that I will have something tangible to contribute, I hope.

As has happened before, the delegation took the opportunity to become part and parcel of the Asia-Pacific group and to use our influence with members of that group, as well as with the 12+ group. One of the major parts of the conference was the election of a president for the next four years. I can tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, if you think a lot of lobbying for positions goes on around this place, the contest between Dr Sorour from Egypt and Mr Valdes Subercaseaux from Chile was likened to the election of the head of the United Nations. That is really what the IPU is, the United Nations of politicians. When the announcement was made, and Dr Sorour was successful, the Muslim countries, at least, were overjoyed.

I am looking forward to continuing my work—as is, I presume, the Speaker—at the 93rd conference to be held in Madrid. That is, of course, unless something more important in Australia intervenes in the meantime. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO FRANCE AND THE EUROPEAN INSTITUTIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Acting Deputy President, I present the report of the Parliamentary Delegation to France and the European Institutions, which took place during September and October 1994. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to that report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate Roger Price, the Labor member for Chifley, on his leadership of this delegation. He did a very good job. For a Labor man he has remarkable commonsense. He really should be in the Labor ministry, although that may well be the kiss of death. Lou Lieberman, the Liberal member for Indi, also did a very good job as the deputy leader of the delegation.

PARA.TAB: I place on record my thanks and the thanks of the other members of the delegation to the delegation secretary, Michael Salkeld, who did a great job for us, as did his executive assistant, Mrs Sue Cox, who is responsible for preparing this report. I make special note of the contribution to the delegation's success of Ambassador Ted Pocock and Mrs Meg Pocock, our representatives in Brussels, who must be one of our most outstanding ambassadorial couples.

There was an enormous interest in our delegation in Europe. There was a lot of concern about APEC and where that was heading but a great awareness of the opportunities for using Australia as a gateway to Asia, as long as the government's attitude on tax and industrial relations does not preclude European companies setting up headquarters in this country.

The European Union is at an absolutely fascinating stage of its development, with the widening of the European Union that is currently occurring and the discussions about extending its reach into European decisions and legislation. It is critical that Australia remains actively focused upon Europe and does not become blindly obsessed with the opportunities that exist in Asia. Europe remains our biggest trading partner—something that many of us forget—and it would be a tragedy if we did not keep our minds on the opportunities that present themselves in Europe.

As a result of this trip, I am extremely optimistic about the opportunities for Australia in Europe. The economic liberalisation of Europe is tremendous and gives great cause for optimism about world trade and world economic progress. The major difficulty in Europe at the moment is the very high level of unemployment. This contrasts with the United States where the unemployment rate is only half that of Europe. Europe has a lot of work to do in liberalising its labour market in particular, as well as its product markets. It must take a lead from the United States if it is to overcome the problem of unemployment. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to one of the most critical problems facing rural Australia today. I am referring to the level of farm indebtedness to financial institutions, which stood at $17.3 billion as of June 1993, according to the latest ABARE farm survey. The combination of the worst drought this century and the aftermath of the recession with its crippling interest rates has led to unprecedented levels of rural debt.

PARA.TAB: Average farm business debt for Queensland farms currently stands at $181,000 for 1993-94 and the average farm business debt for farms Australia-wide stands at $126,000. Debt levels have dramatically worsened over the past six years. Figures supplied by the South West Financial Service show that in 1988 the average equity ratio in a property was 85 per cent. By 1994 average equity is down to 54 per cent. By a happy coincidence, Senator Collins is in the chamber. I would like him to listen to the views that were expressed by a group of people at the farm debt summit. He is getting it straight from the horse's mouth.

The situation will only deteriorate with the latest Bureau of Meteorology reports that the drought is unlikely to break before autumn. The latest ABARE report on the effects of the drought states that the drought will result in a reduction in the net value of agricultural production of almost $3 billion for the 1994-95 year. The drought has also resulted in wheat production falling by more than 50 per cent—this year's winter wheat crop will be the lowest in over 20 years. We are now seeing wheat imports being given the go ahead for daily bread supplies. It is the first time this century that significant quantities of wheat for bakery supplies have been imported.

Interest rates are starting to take off again and further rises are anticipated. The recent one per cent rise in the official reserve cash rate acted to impose an additional debt payment of around $170 million on the farm sector. This rise effectively negated the $164 million drought relief package that Senator Collins pushed through the parliament. Further tax hikes have not been ruled out by the government, leading to speculation about the likelihood of a mini-budget. This all points to many more difficult months ahead for our drought-stricken rural communities.

The social and economic impact of high debt levels and negative cash flows is simply not being addressed by the government. The government's drought package, which provided a drought relief payment to affected farmers, is a welcome short-term assistance measure for farm families, many of whom may not have had an income for up to four years. However, the industry assistance measures in the package, including the additional $25 million for RAS funding for drought exceptional circumstances, and the increases in RAS subsidies from 50 per cent to 100 per cent, are ultimately inadequate, because the fundamental problem of RAS's restrictive eligibility criteria, which precludes many farmers from accessing the funding, remain unchanged. Senator Collins has promised me, on numerous occasions, that he will be changing the eligibility criteria.

Of the three elements involved in drought response—immediate assistance to affected families, industry assistance through the rural adjustment scheme and financial reconstruction—it is the financial reconstruction that is the most difficult to address. We are all waiting for the second part of the government's drought package in the hope that a long-term strategy encompassing such vital elements as tax incentives for farm storage and water facilities, and taxation and income equalisation deposits, will be included. I would like to take this opportunity to say to the government that, two months after its handing down of the drought package, it must now look at long-term farm viability strategies as a matter of urgency.

Recently I attended a very effective debt summit at Capella in the central Queensland highlands. The purpose of the summit was to look at ways that primary producers and small business operators could restructure their debt burden. Over 150 people attended the summit, representing a broad cross-section of the community, including producers, small business operators and representatives from local government and financial institutions. The Capella branch of the Queensland Grain Growers Association made thoughtful recommendations regarding taxation incentives, which are essential to enable producers to return to profitability once the drought breaks.

As put forward by the Capella branch, the taxation incentives that are most urgently needed include the availability of an investment allowance to encourage increased investment in modern plant, equipment and technology, and improved deductibility measures for self-reliance strategies such as water storage facilities. Improving tax arrangements to take into account producers' fluctuating and uncertain incomes was also raised at the summit.

Revamping the existing income equalisation deposit scheme was designated and called for as a matter of high priority. The Capella branch also called for the existing income equalisation deposit scheme to be revamped as a matter of priority. Reforms to the IED scheme should encompass such provisions as no withholding tax; interest payable on total deposit; and being taxable at a relevant rate when brought back into the taxable income of that financial year.

It is important to note that what the participants of the Capella drought summit were calling for is, for the most part, simply a return to what used to be fundamental elements of the primary industry policy of the National-Liberal government when it was in power. Income equalisation deposits and taxation incentives for water and fodder storage are all measures that this Labor government in its 11 years in office has systematically stripped from the farm sector.

In May 1983 the government cut general depreciation allowances and abolished special depreciation allowances for on-farm fuel storage. That year it also scrapped the arrangements for tax averaging and increased the margin paid by farmers under the fuel freight subsidy scheme. Later that year the government abolished tax incentives on income equalisation deposits. The IED scheme was reinstated in 1989 but in a greatly diminished form.

The Capella debt summit also highlighted the difficulties that rural small businesses are currently experiencing. A machine dealership owner presented evidence about the decline in his industry as a result of the fluctuating fortunes of primary industry. He pointed out that in 1984 there were approximately 2,700 machinery dealers in Australia selling about 15,500 tractors per year. In great contrast this year there are about 700 surviving machinery dealerships selling around 5,500 tractors per year. This contradiction in the industry has led to a dramatic decline in employment. If each of the 2,000 dealerships that have gone out of business had employed 10 people, this would translate to 20,000 put off over the last 10 years in rural and regional Australia.

According to this dealer, the only reason that his business has survived is that he and his wife have worked seven days a week and for as many hours a day as were required to sustain the business. The dealer pointed out that in the township of Emerald six dealers had gone out of business, and in his own dealership his staff numbers have been halved. The submission of this machinery dealer highlighted vividly the extremely difficult circumstances that many rural small businesses have had to battle with throughout the drought years.

The recently published Yellow Pages small business index found that one-third of small businesses in the worst hit areas of Queensland and New South Wales are in danger of closing. The Queensland Retail Traders Association has released figures stating that many small businesses are carrying longstanding debts on droughted farmers to the tune of $150,000 to $200,000, yet at the same time these businesses are having to pay their suppliers on a seven-day basis.

It has been well recognised in drought regions that many small businesses stepped in to help the farming sector when banks and lending institutions wrote them off—despite last year being a windfall year for the banks, with huge profits posted by the big four. While the state governments of Queensland and New South Wales have both introduced schemes to assist drought affected small businesses with their interest bills, to date the drought affected small business sectors have received no direct Commonwealth drought assistance whatsoever.

Submissions by small business representatives highlighted the need for taxation incentives and lower interest rates. One small business operator presented a submission that small business directly involved with primary industry should be permitted to purchase IEDs with 100 per cent deduction in the year of the investment and that provisional tax be levied on only the taxable income after the IED is deducted. This operator also submitted that a 20 per cent investment allowance on all new plant and equipment, water conservation, soil conservation and grain storage be reintroduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of this speech in Hansard?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows—

Another small business representative highlighted the need for lower interest rates by pointing out that Australia's interest rates are 3%—4% above most of our trading nations particularly those in Europe.
This small business owner called for low interest loans with a moratorium on capital repayments during drought, to be implemented as a matter of absolute priority.
One constructive initiative raised at the debt summit was a proposal to introduce mandatory debt mediation.
Debt mediators would act as independent third parties and review farm circumstances where operations were in severe financial difficulty or were faced with an imminent seizure of assets.
Under this proposal a farmer facing a seizure of assets could apply for a review of their financial affairs and apply for a stay of proceedings.
A voluntary agreement between a farmer and his/her creditors would then be sought for a mutually satisfactory arrangement.
Rural adjustment in this country is a process that has been on-going for many years now. Most producers on uneconomic holdings have already exited the land.
By the turn of the century the number of farms in Australia will have dropped from the present number of 120,000 to around 70,000, from 170,000 in the early 1980s.

The government must implement a long-term strategy to assist producers and small businesses that have a future, but are presently undergoing difficulties due to a combination of drought and rural downturn.

The government must take the necessary measures to provide for rural reconstruction once the drought breaks. It is absolutely imperative that these steps are taken as a matter of priority, if an irretrievable collapse in the rural sector is to be averted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks about a disturbing trend which is emerging in police services around the country. The trend is towards providing police, firstly, with more and more powers and then with more and more weapons. We have all been dismayed in recent times as members of the Victorian police force have been involved in shootings of mentally ill people as a direct result of a lack of alternative means of handling such people. The combination of insufficient training for police, whose duties should not involve being mental health professionals, and the ready availability of guns when police are on duty has resulted in a series of tragedies which show no signs of having ceased.

PARA.TAB: As a result of these tragedies, a great deal has been said about issuing police with `non-lethal weapons'. In particular, research has been conducted into using aerosol sprays based on the active ingredients in certain vegetables, particularly those in the pepper varieties. These so-called capsicum sprays are already used in other parts of the world, and there are strong indications that the term `non-lethal' should not be used in reference to them.

A report available in the United States of America investigated the deaths of 30 people exposed to such sprays. The report concludes that the deaths were due to obesity, drug use and positional asphyxia. However, whether or not one agrees with the report's conclusions, it is obviously unacceptable that people should be put into a life threatening situation because they are exposed to police operations.

I am sure all honourable senators would have seen film footage of police operations in which tear gas is used and would have noticed that there is a considerable amount of wind drift and random application involved with such chemicals. The same problems of ensuring that only those targeted are sprayed arise with capsicum sprays. It is in the very nature of a sprayed chemical that bystanders are in danger of being sprayed. I want to draw the attention of the Senate to the level of toxicity of the chemical component of such a spray. The chemical in question is capsaicin (8-methyl-n-vanillyl-6-nonenamide). Pardon my pronunciation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope Hansard has that.

—I will ensure that Hansard gets the right spelling, and I apologise for my lack of ability to pronounce the chemical's name. This particular chemical in question is, when transported in bulk, handled only in wax-coated blocks. Workers involved in its preparation and shipment wear gas masks, body suits and gloves. The chemical has the potential to damage skin, nerves, the respiratory system, the eyes and the nose. It is a possible carcinogen, and tests on animals indicate potential reproductive dangers for women.

PARA.TAB: I have in my possession two reports on the capsicum sprays. One was prepared by the Coalition Against Repressive Police Equipment and Training in Victoria, known under the acronym of CARPET. The other is by the American Civil Liberties Union. The titles of the reports are, in the first case, Capsicum gas: should the police have another weapon? and, secondly, Pepper sprays: a magic bullet under scrutiny. I seek leave to table both reports.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time of the last shooting of a mentally ill person by police in Victoria a senior police officer from the metropolitan police in London was interviewed on the ABC radio. The contrast between the approach in Victoria and that in England could not have been more marked. The English police officer spoke of police squads having special training in dealing with mentally ill people on the streets. The training was based on the notion of building sufficient trust between the police officers involved and the person. There was special mention of the police being trained to act in a non-threatening manner—speaking quietly and sitting on the ground so as not to pose a threat, especially if the person is armed. The focus was very much on reducing the individual's fear of his surroundings or of other people in the vicinity, as this is often the presenting problem which triggers an incident. I ask honourable senators to contrast that scenario with the situation of one or more police officers with revolvers raised and ready, shouting at a mentally ill person in the street to drop his knife, axe or whatever.

PARA.TAB: I do not want it felt here that I am in any way criticising police, who are placed in very invidious situations. I think the onus is on the community to ensure that police officers, who often are in very difficult situations of panic and anxiety by fear-inducing circumstances, are ill-equipped by their training to deal with those situations in the best manner possible to ensure not only that the individual is protected from harm but also that the capacity of them and any bystanders to experience harm is reduced. It is notable that the metropolitan police in England do not carry firearms under general duty conditions and, as the officer being interviewed said, `There is no push from the police or the community to change that situation.'

This issue is about a great deal more than police use of weapons, be they lethal or otherwise. There is a mood in our society which wants to run away from the problems which exist by the simple expedient of giving police more and more powers to deal with those who do not fit our ideas of acceptability. It is not only the mentally ill who have been deinstitutionalised without proper community facilities who are at risk here.

The same attitude exists towards young people who are homeless, jobless or both, people of other ethnic origins and our own indigenous people. As these groups are more and more denied access to the common wealth of our society and are allowed less and less of a voice where and when it matters to be heard, we leave it to the police to deal with them when they infringe on our notions of propriety.

We see this in the police operations in Western Australia in which young people are denied their democratic right to congregate in public areas, and we have the wonderful euphemism that we are moving them on because they are in `moral danger'. We see in this move the ever increasing powers being handed to police to deal with such groups. The police are not intended to be, and should not be, used by the community in such a way.

In Victoria the government has amended the Crimes Act to increase on the spot fines. That may seem harmless enough until it is realised that to challenge such a fine requires a quite extraordinary presence of mind, command of English and a highly developed knowledge of one's legal rights. The amendments also have the effect of significantly shifting the onus of proof by requiring defendants to reveal their defence before a plea of not guilty can be entered. Similarly, police powers to require people to give their name and address to a police officer have been broadened and the rules concerning fingerprinting have been altered to reduce the rights of people apprehended by police. In fact, reasonable force can now be used where the person does not consent to being fingerprinted.

The recent mass strip search of patrons at a night club does not give one much confidence that the police in Victoria will be reluctant to use powers given to them by the legislation. Similarly, in South Australia the changes to juvenile justice legislation have resulted in disturbing new powers which effectively put police officers in the position of being both the arresting authority and the judicial authority.

But neither can we simply say that these powers are obviously necessary because of increases in crime. There is nothing obvious at all about the crime waves which we are constantly told about. In fact, often these are beat-ups and generally serve electoral ambitions of political parties and vested interests, as we have witnessed time and time again in Western Australia with juvenile justice issues.

We cannot say that these powers are constantly being requested by the police themselves. I commend the police commissioner in Western Australia, Mr Robert Falconer, for his recent comments about the limitations of policing. He pointed out that the debate in Western Australia about how many extra police each of the major parties would give if in power was really nonsense because such promises are not answers to the problem. The problems have to be addressed by the whole society, in the way people relate to each other, how they value each other and how they enable people to make contributions to the community. There are alternatives to weapons and sprays. We need to look at the training of police; we need to look very much at the modelling of appropriate social behaviour which they have in their power. To address problems in policing and crime with a bandaid, ad hoc approach is an invitation to produce different and possibly more serious problems later on.

We really do need to address a long-term view. In the long term, if we give police more weapons then those weapons may in turn cause problems by imitation. Do we really want to see our young people with the capacity, as outlined in the media, to use sprays when fighting with each other? (Time expired)

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to recent changes to the Corporations Law, and in particular to the requirement that prohibits more than 20 new shareholders in a company in a single year without issuing a prospectus:
(1) Is this change intended to apply to co-operatives.
(2) Are there different interpretations of this change to the Corporations Law between States, depending on individual co-operatives legislation.
(3) Is it possible for registrars of co-operatives to effect general adaptations and modifications with respect to this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Corporations Law provides that where not more than 20 offers or invitations in relation to securities, or issues of securities, are made personally to a person within the preceding 12 months, a person is not required to comply with the prospectus requirements of the Law.
This exclusion has been in the Corporations Law from the date of its commencement on 1 January 1991.
The intrastate fundraising activities of co-operatives are not subject to the requirements of the Corporations Law and are regulated under the relevant State or Territory legislation.
The prospectus requirements of the Corporations Law do apply to any interstate fundraising activities of co-operatives. However, the 20/12 exclusion will also apply.

(2) The Corporations Law is administered at a national level by the Australian Securities Commission. Interpretation of the Corporations Law does not depend on individual State and Territory co-operatives legislation.

(3) In so far as the Corporations Law applies to interstate fundraising activities of co-operatives, exemptions or modifications of the prospectus requirements may be given effect at an administrative level only by the Australian Securities Commission. State and Territory Registrars of co-operatives do not have powers to effect general adaptations or modifications to the prospectus requirements where applicable.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to recent meetings of State registrars of co-operatives which have discussed, amongst other things, the need for uniform national co-operatives legislation:
(1) Does the Government acknowledge that present legal arrangements may be hampering the development potential of co-operatives; if not, why not.

(2) What action, if any, is the Government taking to review and/or reform the legal framework for co-operatives (including details of review guidelines, legal models and personnel involved in any review, together with the timetable for activity).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government acknowledges that the present lack of uniform legislation is an impediment to the growth of the co-operative sector, particularly in agriculture.
(2) The review and reform of the legal framework for co-operatives is not the responsibility of the Commonwealth, since co-operatives are primarily governed by State and Territory legislation.

This issue is currently on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. A working party known as the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General Working Party on Consistent Co-operatives Legislation is progressing the matter. The working party was formed after concerns expressed by the Australian Agricultural Council that the lack of consistent legislation between the States was a major barrier to the growth of the co-operative sector in agriculture and a barrier to greater export effort by agricultural co-operatives.

The working party has produced a draft model Bill. The draft Bill aims to create an Interstate Division for inclusion in the relevant State and Territory legislation, setting out the minimum requirements needed to enable interstate co-operative operation, consistent with appropriate prudential standards.

There are some matters outstanding concerning the interface between the Interstate Division in the model Bill and the Corporations Law. The working party intends to liaise with the Ministerial Council for Corporations on those issues, and will present its final report to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General following that process. The Working Party has indicated it expects to be in a position to present its final report to Ministers in February 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to reports that the financial and capital raising powers of co-operatives are being eroded and that this is forcing people to use non-co-operative financial institutions:
(1) Is the Government aware of any policies operating in any of the States to remove the deposit and loan powers of co-operatives.
(2) Is the Government aware of any instances where co-operatives have failed through the use of deposit and loan powers.
(3) Does the Government have any comparative data on the failure rates of co-operatives compared with other organisations such as companies, particularly in relation to finance and capital raising.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am not in a position to answer questions concerning the policies of State Governments.
(2) Co-operatives operate primarily under State and Territory legislation. Failures, if any, due to the use of deposit and loan powers is not a matter within my sphere of ministerial responsibility.

(3) Co-operatives operate primarily under State and Territory legislation. Failure rates of co-operatives generally, and particularly in relation to finance and capital raising, is not a matter within my sphere of responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the impact of maritime disputes on Tasmania, which as an island state relies on shipping as a life-line, what action has been taken since the recent Australian maritime dispute to permanently exempt all Bass Strait shipping from further disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Government's shipping reform initiatives over the past decade have seen significant structural changes occur in the Australian maritime industry largely in an atmosphere of industrial co-operation.
During the national maritime dispute in September 1994, I understand the Spirit of Tasmania was exempted from industrial action.

As a result of talks between the Government and the unions on 12 September 1994, I was able to announce a wide ranging package of measures, aimed at enhancing the ability of the Australian shipping industry to compete with vessels from overseas, which typically take advantage of tax free regimes and low cost third world crews.
Accordingly, under the package the Government has, for its part, agreed to consider a range of fiscal measures designed to directly reduce costs to owners of Australian flagged shipping.

For the union's part, they have agreed to consider negotiating an industrial reform package which will include measures to further improve the efficiency of industry employment arrangements, a long-term wage agreement, reduced training costs, and the entering into of an industrial peace accord.

The successful implementation of this total package, including the basis of an industrial accord, will also improve the efficiency and reliability of Australian domestic shipping services, and will provide direct benefits to the Tasmanian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 7 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have there been any complaints from recipients of the naturalisation ceremony held in Launceston in June 1994 relating to the provision of party political material stapled to official folders.

(2) If it is not appropriate for members of Parliament to be providing promotional material to newly naturalised citizens at naturalisation ceremonies as detailed in the answer to question on notice no. 1484 (Senate Hansard, 23 August 1994, page 157), what procedures will be taken to ensure that it does not happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The department is not aware of any complaints in relation to any party political material being provided to candidates at the Launceston citizenship ceremony held in June 1994.

No `official folder' is provided to candidates by the Department at Launceston ceremonies. Each candidate is publicly and individually presented with their citizenship certificate, pledge card, and pledge poster to children, and mementos from the Good Neighbour Council, the Country Women's Association, the Bible Society, the Migrant Resource Centre, the Launceston City Council (a plant) and the State Government (a Tasmanian flag badge).

(2) The official guidelines in relation to the conduct of citizenship ceremonies are contained in the booklet `Australian Citizenship Ceremonies—A Handbook for Local Government Authorities'. The most recent update of this booklet was distributed nationally to local government authorities in January 1994.

The guidelines advise `It is essential that the dignity and bipartisan significance of citizenship ceremonies are not eroded by their use as forums for political or partisan expression.' Local government officials and official guests are expected to conduct themselves in accord with the guidelines and if specific evidence was produced that a local government authority was not observing the guidelines, I would ensure that the matter was taken up with that authority.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Kangaroo `95 defence exercises:

(1) (a) Which countries have been, or are to be, approached to be involved in the Kangaroo `95 defence exercises in August 1995; (b) how were these countries approached or how will they be approached; (c) what was the response of each of those countries; (d) is there a cut-off date for their response; and (e) when, or how, will it be decided to involve them in the exercises if they respond.

(2) (a) Has the Indonesian Government responded to the invitation to be involved in Kangaroo `95; (b) when did it respond (c) how did it respond; and (d) if it has not yet responded, how is it indicated that the Indonesian Government will respond.

(3) (a) What is the decision-making process for how the different countries will take part in the Kangaroo `95 defence exercises; (b) do countries submit views on how they should be involved or does Australia specify how a particular country would be involved; (c) have any of the countries invited to take part in Kangaroo `95 submitted proposals on what role they would play, and what are the roles of each country's forces; (d) have any countries received information from Australia about how Australia would like them to be involved in Kangaroo `95; if so, for each country, how does Australia envisage their involvement.

(4) (a) Drawing on all the current information available, which nations will be involved in the Kangaroo `95 defence exercises; and (b) what will be the number of troops involved in the exercises for each participating country.
(5) How much will each nation pay towards the costs associated with the exercises.

(6) (a) Please provide details of the equipment to be used in the Kangaroo `95 defence exercises including numbers and types of tanks, aircraft, naval vessels and arms; (b) will landmines be used in these exercises; if so, what are the number, types and the country and company of manufacture; and (c) in approximately which areas will mines be laid and what method will be used.
(7) Which particular units of the Australian Defence Force, including all army, air force, navy, ready reserves and reserves will be participating in Kangaroo `95.

(8) Has there been, or will there be, any environmental impact assessment done on the area in which the Kangaroo `95 defence exercises will take place; if so, will this document be made available to the Senate; if not, why not.

(9) (a) Will chlorofluorocarbons be used or produced by military equipment during Kangaroo `95; and (b) how will they be used, what will produce them and how much will be released into the atmosphere from each operation.
(10) What is the breakdown of all the costs associated with Kangaroo `95.

(11) (a) Will the Joint Defence Facility at Pine Gap be involved in Kangaroo `95; if so, what is its role, and how will it be involved; and (b) what other communications intelligence facilities in Australia will be involved in Kangaroo `95, and what will be their role and involvement in the exercises.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) The United States, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and Papua New Guinea have been invited to participate in Exercise Kangaroo `95. An invitation for participation by a naval element of the United Kingdom is under consideration.
(b) Invitations have been, or will be, issued by letter from the Chief of the Defence Force to his counterpart in the country concerned.

(c) Relevant authorities of the United States, Malaysia and Papua New Guinea have responded favourably to the invitation to participate. The authorities of Indonesia and Singapore have yet to respond.
(d) There is no cut-off date for responses.

(e) The methodology for involvement in the exercise of each nation's forces has already been determined in broad policy terms. Detailed arrangements for the involvement of overseas forces are progressively being developed by the Joint Exercise Planning Staff within Headquarters Australian Defence Force as specific unit allocations and periods of availability are advised.
The Indonesian Government has yet to respond to the invitation to participate in the exercise.
(d) There is no indication at present as to how the Indonesian Government will respond.

(3) (a) Proposals for the involvement of overseas forces in Exercise Kangaroo `95 were developed within Headquarters Australian Defence Force on a case-by-case basis as for any other defence exercise. Considerations involve strategic guidance, extant international policy issues, interoperability prospects and requirements, likely asset availability and the particular objectives of the exercise. Proposals are staffed through normal departmental processes, considered by the Chief of the Defence Force and are subject to ministerial approval in each case.

(b) Some countries do occasionally indicate preferences for the type of forces or nature of training or exercise activity which would be most beneficial in terms of combined exercise participation. Where they occur, such indications are most often provided informally at routine meetings of operational staffs and are largely based upon the availability and state of training of force elements under consideration. When Australia is the host country, it determines how invited overseas forces will be employed in any given exercise and this is broadly specified in the invitation.
(c) No country invited to participate in Kangaroo `95 has submitted proposals on the role which their forces would play. In regard to the role of each country's forces see 3 (d) below.

(d) Invitations for overseas participation in Kangaroo `95 suggested the type and number of force elements which might be appropriate for the purposes of the exercise. Those suggestions are subject to further discussion with the armed forces of the countries concerned and are not a matter for public release at this stage.
(4) (a) In addition to the Australian Defence Force, only the involvement in Kangaroo `95 of the United States, Malaysia and Papua New Guinea can be confirmed at this stage.
(b) Information on the number of troops of other nations to be involved in Exercise Kangaroo `95 is not yet available. Details will be provided at an appropriate time.

(5) It is envisaged that the United States will bear the full cost of its forces' participation in Exercise Kangaroo `95. Arrangements with other countries vary but, in general terms, the parent nation covers the costs of its forces' salaries, allowances and deployment to Australia. Some direct operating costs of those forces whilst within Australia (eg. rations) are met by the Australian Defence Force in its capacity as host. Precise costings will not be available until after the exercise concludes.

(6) (a) The full range of defence equipment relevant to short-warning conflict will be employed or simulated during the exercise. The information sought would indicate the specific Australian Defence Force units participating in the exercise which remains classified until immediately prior to the movement or involvement of those units. In general terms, the exercise will involve the operation of some 14 tanks, 16 ships and 110 aircraft.
Landmines will not be used in Exercise Kangaroo `95.
(7) Information regarding the tasking or movement of specific units of the Australian Defence Force remains classified until immediately prior to such movement or related involvement.

(8) The Australian Defence Force is justifiably proud of its record in environmental awareness and protection and the related aspects of Exercise Kangaroo `95 have been thoroughly addressed. An environmental impact assessment is incorporated in a document entitled `Kangaroo 1995 Environmental Safeguards' which was produced after consultation with some 64 concerned organisations and subsequently approved by the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency. Arrangements have been made for a copy of that document to be placed in the Parliamentary library.

(9) (a) Chlorofluorocarbons will not be produced by military equipment during Exercise Kangaroo `95. Some use will be made of dichlorodifluoromethane and trichlorotrifluoroethane in conventional applications.

(b) Dichlorodifluoromethane is used in some air-conditioning and refrigeration equipments. These are closed-loop systems and none is intended to be released into atmosphere. Trichlorotrifluoroethane is used in some solvents having specialist applications for which no suitable alternative has yet been identified. Some release to the atmosphere is possible in these applications but the quantities are negligible.

(10) The current estimate for the total cost of Exercise Kangaroo `95 is $64.298 million at December 1994 prices. Of that amount, some $8 million is provided for the planning, management and evaluation of the exercise, including deployment of forces to and from the exercise area where civil assets are employed. The remaining amount of approximately $56 million is required to be absorbed from within existing Service allocations. This is managed by cancelling other routine Navy, Army and Air Force training activities and subsuming those activities in the larger exercise.

(11) (a) It is Government policy not to comment on the role and activities of the Joint Defence Facility at Pine Gap beyond acknowledging that it is a satellite ground station which collects intelligence data supporting the national security of Australia and the United States.

(b) A variety of portable/mobile communications equipments are routinely deployed on Defence Force exercises to provide training and experience in the interception and/or jamming of opposing forces' communications. Operation of these equipments is strictly limited to assigned military frequencies. All fixed Australian military communications facilities are likely to be used at various times during the exercise for the transmission and reception of exercise-related communications.
